SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

(1) leadership in developments within CHOGM, and
(2) his endeavours to remove impediments to world trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House supports this Government's contribution to local government and condemns the action of the New South Wales Government in withdrawing support from local government in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the fact that three young South African anti-apartheid fighters and members of the African National Congress, namely, Mogoerane, Mosololi and Motaung, have been sentenced to death because of their legitimate actions for freedom. I ask the Minister whether any representations have been made to have the sentence commuted to a lesser one than death. If no action has been taken, will he intercede with the President of South Africa to ask that the death sentence not be imposed for the reasons that I have mentioned, bearing in mind that previous representations in similar circumstances have been successful? If no action has been taken, will the Government take action urgently in the interests of those young men?

—As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, the Government has on previous occasions interceded when death sentences have been passed in South Africa. Some of those intercessions have been successful. The Government is currently examining all the details of the three cases to which he has drawn attention. When I have had a chance to examine all the material which has been presented to me, the Government will make a decision whether to intercede on this occasion.

—Has the Minister for Health yet examined the 1981-82 annual report of Medibank Private which was tabled yesterday? If so, has he understood that the autonomous and separate Victorian fund has 80 per cent of Medibank's national reserves, that in the year past the fund went down the tube in two States and that in three others its reserves come nowhere near the two months' level required to ensure that the membership is protected in the event of a flu epidemic or the like? Does the Minister feel that less than a week's reserve in Australia's most populous State, New South Wales, makes a mockery of the Chairman's report when he referred to encouraging news and substantial progress?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is being a little unkind when he refers to the performance and the management of Medibank Private-the Health Insurance Commission. Having looked at the report which was tabled in the House yesterday- it is in the Table Office for any honourable member who would like to look at it -I must say that I saw some encouraging movement. The Chairman, Mr Millar, and the General Manager, Mr Wilcox, should be congratulated on the job that they have been doing under very difficult circumstances. As I have pointed out before , this fund operates under the severe restrictions of government ownership. It has to maintain superannuation payments which are in excess of those provided in the private sector. It must follow staffing levels and awards which are more expensive than those in the private sector. I am very conscious of the restraints under which a good management team and the commission operate.

ANSWER.PARA: As I mentioned to the House before, I am looking very closely at ways and means of improving the capacity of Medibank Private to achieve the kind of objectives that the honourable member wishes it to achieve. In no way am I criticising the honourable member for keeping a close watch over the operations of Medibank Private. I have no quarrel with him on his analysis of the statistics. He does his sums very carefully. But the very things he points out highlight once again the grave difficulties one gets into with government-run operations, particularly in the health care field. I point out to honourable members opposite that if they are thinking of having a generalised government-run insurance system, which is in their platform, they are looking at a much higher cost option than we have with the private fund system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Health. Have negotiations been held between a number of health funds, the Federal Government and the Victorian Government concerning the imposition of charges on the health funds for hospital treatment of patients eligible for free hospital treatment between 1976 and 1978? Was agreement reached last year on $5.9m being the amount overpaid by the health funds? What steps are being taken by the Federal Government to refund its share of approximately $3m to the benefit funds?

—I will have to look into the precise figures in more detail for the honourable member and take the question on notice. It is a very complicated issue. To try to explain it here in a minute or two is very difficult, but I understand his interest and I will certainly give him an answer soon.

—Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Social Security aware of continual criticism by some State Ministers of funding for child care programs? Can he inform the House of the steps the Federal Government has taken concerning child care funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government in this year's Budget continued to support the States in their efforts in the field of pre-school education. In addition, it made very substantial increases in the funds available for child care. The aim of this substantial increase in the funding provided for this purpose was, firstly, to enable existing child care facilities to operate effectively and, in some cases, to enable them to expand in some minor ways. The second way in which the Budget made very substantial contributions in the field of child care was to enable a great deal more to be done for children and families in need. Between $6m and $ 7m, if my memory serves me correctly, has been allocated for this purpose. A similar amount is also being made available for the provision of new child care services in areas in need.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has been very conscious of the special needs of families for child care facilities. In this year's Budget, sensitive as it was to the needs of families with children, a very substantial increase was made available for this Government's child care effort. In co-operation with the States putting their effort into pre-school education, the Government recognised the special needs of needy families and needy areas by the allocation of these additional funds this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that the rate of home ownership as surveyed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics has fallen from 73 per cent in 1978 to 71.9 per cent in 1980, and further to 68.2 per cent in 1981? Is this fall in home ownership a result of this Government's policies? Since the Minister has accepted responsibility for housing assistance, what changes to Government priorities has he promoted to improve access to home ownership in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very sensitive to the needs of the housing sector, both the needs of individuals and, indeed, the needs of the industry. The housing industry is very sensitive to general economic conditions and has always been characterised by cyclical movements in activity. The industry has been experiencing difficulty. I have mentioned that in the House before. Activity fell sharply in 1982 as housing demand was constrained by high interest rates, reduced availability of housing finance and general economic conditions. I have also pointed more recently to the indications that there is an upward turn. We have, of course, responded vigorously in our home ownership policies. The 1982- 83 Budget complements and extends the measures of the March housing package and the 24 June Loan Council decisions. It will relieve the burden on home buyers and boost the housing industry by significantly extending tax rebates to cover all home buyers, by the substantial increases in housing programs-including an increase of 28 per cent in the home deposit assistance, I think a 27 per cent increase in the welfare housing payments and a 34 per cent increase in expenditure on supplementary rental allowances.

ANSWER.PARA: From the answer I gave last week the Government's measures are already having an impact. Lending by savings banks has improved over the three months or so to August-September, dwelling approvals appear to have bottomed out and building and financial institutions have reported increased inquiries in the last few months. That shows that the pick up is on the way. The measures contained in the Budget apply from 1 November and I would look for a further upward movement.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH-STATE MEETING OF POLICE MINISTERS AND ATTORNEYS-GENERAL

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Acting Attorney-General seen reports that two States will not be attending a proposed joint meeting of Commonwealth and State Attorneys and Police Ministers on 5 November? Will that meeting take place? What is the present position on a co-operative approach on fighting organised and sophisticated crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far as the Federal Government is concerned the meeting on 5 November will take place. I urge all State Attorneys and Police Ministers to attend that meeting and to participate with the Commonwealth in furthering the co-operative effort that has been proposed to fight sophisticated and organised crime. I am glad the honourable member based his question on that co-operative effort because it is indeed at the very basis of the proposal that the Commonwealth has made.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been said quite wrongly that this is a proposal to increase the power of the Federal Government. That is not the case. It is a proposal to decrease the power of criminals. We have proposed a co-operative effort which we would urge all States to take part in, under which in appropriate cases and at the discretion of the States concerned the States can transfer a particular function and an investigative process to the Commonwealth. In addition there would be cases on which we would also advocate a meeting of joint Commonwealth and State investigative bodies. That proposal has been made for a considerable period. It is still there. It was on the table at the last meeting of Attorneys and Police Ministers. We believe that is an effective method of tackling the problem of serious crime in this country.

I turn now to the last part of the honourable member's question. It is unfortunate that it seems now that the Australian Labor Party is to oppose the proposal to establish a national crimes commission unless the Government accepts its amendments to the scheme which would in fact weaken very substantially the proposal for the crimes commission. It is also quite extraordinary that the Labor Party should propose to delete from our proposal one of the most significant areas that we believe requires investigation and which I am quite convinced the Australian public accepts requires investigation-that is, offences which our established and traditional institutions have had difficulty in investigating and remedying. It is one of the very bases of a national crimes commission that it should be able to investigate those matters. It is very unfortunate indeed that the Labor Party should now seek to oppose the establishment of a crimes commission which would investigate those very serious crimes, which as I say is one of the very reasons why we want the body established. The situation is that the Commonwealth proposal is still there. It will be proceeded with. I would urge all States to continue with the co- operative effort upon which we started. I urge the Labor Party to join us and support this very significant proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Administrative Services a question supplementary to that which I asked him last week regarding the use of the Government Information Unit. Did he state that no officer of the Government Information Unit had done work for the Liberal Party? Did he not in fact mislead the House? Is it true that Mr Bruce Montgomery, an officer of the GIU, worked for the Tasmanian Branch of the Liberal Party prior to the Tasmanian elections?

—I can only repeat what I said in response to the honourable member a couple of days ago. The GIU officers work as Press officers for Ministers who do not have Press officers and they therefore work for the Government. I am not aware of Mr Montgomery indulging in any of the activities that the honourable member has--
—I have the minutes of the Tasmanian branch which show he worked for your party.

—I ask the honourable member to let me finish. I am not aware that Mr Montgomery has been working for the Liberal Party, but if the honourable member has any information that he wishes to give me I will be quite happy to investigate it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Cohen

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the minutes of the Tasmanian branch of the Liberal Party.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. As there was some further increase in indirect taxes in the Budget I ask: Will the average Australian family be worse off as a result of those increases in the light of other Budget tax measures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —When judging the impact of the Federal Budget on families one has to look at all the measures that have been introduced into the Budget and see how they impact on individual taxpayers or on families in particular. The Budget overall gives very real and lasting benefits to Australian families, and to Australian families with children in particular. The tax cuts totalling $1.5 billion in this year are obviously of benefit to all taxpayers, including families. The increase in the tax free threshold is obviously a very useful increase. The reduction in the standard rate to 30c will benefit all taxpayers, and the increase in the middle threshold should help many Australians and prevent them moving into higher tax brackets if they are on or around average earnings or if they earn more in a particular period because of overtime.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to that there has been an increase in the dependent spouse rebate in cases in which there are children. The housing rebate, which is of significant assistance to people purchasing a home, and the increase in family allowances, which brings the increase to 50 per cent over the last two Budgets, are obviously of enormous interest and help to Australian families. For a husband and wife with two dependent children on average earnings with a home loan of, say, about $30,000 at 13.5 per cent the personal tax gains will be between $10 and $11. The home loan rebate will be worth around $6, and the family allowance about $4.25 a week, bringing the total benefits to $20 or $21. Against that we have to offset the impact of indirect taxes of about $3 a week for the same family. That of course leaves a net benefit of somewhere between $ 17 and $18. That represents a very significant benefit to Australian families and it is one that I am certain will be very much appreciated. It is equivalent to a wage increase of $25 or $26 which many employers are not able to afford at present.

The Budget provides a basis for wage restraint and a basis which will assist Australian industry again to become competitive. That contrasts very much with Mr Cain's Budget in Victoria where, according to Mr Risstrom, State taxes will cost Victorian families an average of $12 a week. So they are about $18 a week better off as a result of our Budget, and the Cain Labor Government's Budget will rip $12 of that back off them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, deals with tax avoidance and evasion. I preface my question by saying that the revelations in the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Costigan reports, but more particularly the 500-page telephone directory which he tabled a month ago, clearly set out the delay which occurred through the necessity to refer legal issues to the Solicitor-General's Department. To overcome this deficiency I ask: Is it a fact that in the field of taxation law expertise in corporate liquidation and bankruptcy law is essential if enforcement is to be efficient? Will he take steps to set up within the Australian Taxation Office its own legal division to ensure that the Office will be self-sufficient and accountable in the field of taxation litigation and recovery?

—I agree with the honourable member for Hawker that experience in company liquidation matters is an important part of any effective anti-tax avoidance armoury on the part of this or any other government. In response to the second part of the honourable gentleman's question, I inform him that some weeks ago I raised with the Commissioner of Taxation the very proposal to which the honourable gentleman has referred. I have sought his comments on it. When I have those comments I will have further discussions on the matter with the Commissioner, the Prime Minister and the Acting Attorney-General.

—Can the Minister for Transport and Construction assure the House that under the Roads Grants Acts and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program funds for national highways will be adequate to meet the Commonwealth's objective of providing a dust free and virtually flood free national highway system by 1988, including a four-lane Hume Highway between Sydney and Melbourne, especially between Gunning and Gundagai in the well represented electorate of Hume?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the concern of the honourable member for Hume and no doubt some of his constituents as a result of the nonsensical statement released by the honourable member for Shortland in respect of the magnificent Bicentennial Road Development Program. I cannot understand why the honourable member for Shortland does not embrace it. I thought it would have done him good to see some good in a really worthwhile and constructive policy for roads. I have not had the opportunity of seeing anything constructive that the honourable member for Shortland has advanced in respect of the Opposition's transport policy on roads.
—I ask the honourable gentleman to speak about roads rather than the honourable member for Shortland.

—'Roads' was the last word in that sentence-and it is not my last word on roads. Mr Speaker, I assure you that the Bicentennial Road Development Program will in fact achieve the stated objective of a dust free and virtually flood free national highway system around Australia. The great advantages of this program will be demonstrated in the not too distant future when projects commence all around Australia providing jobs for 20,000 to 30,000 people. Why would anybody knock a program that will provide such social benefit at a time of great distress to families throughout the nation?

ANSWER.PARA: I thought we would have achieved a bipartisan approach to a really great objective, that is, to get Australia's roads right by 1988. This program will achieve that aim. This year we will see a 33 per cent increase in funds available for roads over and above last year. We will see a 76 per cent increase in 1983-84 over and above 1981-82. I have seen the statements by the honourable member for Shortland. I absolutely refute them as being entirely irresponsible. The Government has set its targets and it will achieve them. So far it is quite clear that what we have said in terms of the program will be achieved. This is based on discussions that we have had with officials from the States. The road program is up and away and we will have our roads right by 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the Prime Minister's latest attitude to the advice from the Attorney-General's Department that Federal powers do exist to save the Franklin River? As he has already stated that his Government will not withdraw the nomination for World Heritage listing, but that this does not necessarily mean that the dam will not proceed, will he please now inform the House how much longer he intends to fudge and defer--
—Order! The honourable gentleman is not entitled to use those words.

—Mr Speaker, I conclude by asking: Will the Prime Minister please inform the House how much longer he intends to defer this vital national and international environmental issue? Is there any hope that he may eventually take a principled decision on this matter?
—The Government's position is very plain. The listing proceeds.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Australian High Commission in Nairobi, Kenya, close at any time during the attempted coup in that country in August? If so, was this the proper course of action?

—I presume that the honourable member is referring to criticisms which were made in this House about a fortnight ago by the honourable member for Grayndler on the role of the Australian High Commission in Nairobi during the attempted coup in Kenya in August. I have looked very closely into the points raised by the honourable member for Grayndler. I am satisfied that the Acting High Commissioner at the time effectively carried out the full range of the mission's responsibilities in very difficult circumstances of widespread civil disorder. These responsibilities, of course, included consular advice and assistance to many Australians, not merely the parliamentary delegation which was in the country at the time. I regret that criticisms have been levelled against a very hard pressed staff endeavouring to cope in such conditions.

—Following the very successful Australian Film Institute Awards last night, I ask the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment: Is he aware of the rapidly deteriorating condition of hundreds of Australian nitrate-acetate cinema films held in the national film collection in the National Library in Canberra? Is it a fact that these films date from the earliest days of cinema in Australia, some from around the year 1900? Is it a fact that the films have acquired a yellow powdery bloom and that this is followed by a rapid and disconcerting transformation of the film stock into powder? Is it a fact that strong representations have been made for funds to preserve this vital element of Australia's cultural history but that the Government has failed to respond? Will the Government, as a matter of urgency, provide funds for conservation?

—The answer to the honourable member's first and second questions is yes. I do not know the answer to the third question which he asked as I am not up in the field of film preservation. In reply to his latter two questions I indicate to the honourable member for Lalor that the Government has this matter under very close investigation at the present time. Officers are going to all areas of Australia in a conscious attempt to find and isolate the films. They even found a pornographic film the other day, I think underneath a house in the honourable member's native city. We are determined to ensure that early films which are an essential part of our heritage and which reflect the growth of our nation are preserved. When we have all the available evidence the Government will be taking appropriate action to preserve these films.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Construction. What benefits are there for Australian industry arising out of this year's program for construction works? In particular, will employment opportunities be enhanced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The civil works program this year will increase by 26 per cent in money terms, which will give a tremendous boost to construction works right around Australia. We have also embarked upon the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. One should add the effects of the civil works program to the additional jobs that I referred to earlier. The Government was extremely generous with the States this year in respect of its capital works programs and also in respect of its borrowing entitlements through the Loan Council.

ANSWER.PARA: On the initiative of the Government we have relieved the State governments of having to operate through the Loan Council with respect to electricity undertakings. The Government has embarked upon a very substantial program of capital works. I am certain that the benefit of this will start to feed into the employment system right throughout Australia, certainly in the second half of next year. I did have some statistics on this that I thought might have been of some value to the honourable gentleman. The total public works program, including the airport construction program and the defence development program, plus the State's loan borrowing entitlements through the Loan Council, will exceed $3,256m this financial year.

I have had talks with the Minister for Aviation about a number of aviation projects to see whether it is possible to move forward some of the intended start dates so that we can pick up some of the employment opportunities that will be available from those works in various parts of Australia. As honourable members would know, a very substantial airport redevelopment program is envisaged throughout Australia. We have very substantial works to be carried out at the Brisbane Airport, we have works to be done at Sydney Airport, Melbourne Airport, Tullamarine, and wide-bodied extension works to be constructed at the Adelaide Airport. The international airport development has just concluded at Adelaide. There is also the work in Perth. I know that the Minister for Aviation has many works in mind, particularly with respect to the local ownership development plan and also the provision of facilities to allow the F28s to operate their services right throughout the regional areas of New South Wales and into part of Queensland.

The honourable gentleman will appreciate that a tremendous public works program is in operation. I am certain that this will help to ameliorate some of the difficulties that are being occasioned by the current world wide economic recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the Auditor-General's criticism of accounting procedures at the Australian Wheat Board, why are records of the Board now being pulped when such documents have not been subject to a proper audit?

—So far as the Auditor-General's qualification of the Australian Wheat Board's accounts is concerned, I think I have said before to the House or in another place that the Wheat Board has put its accounting procedures under review to meet the requirements of the Auditor-General. That matter is progressing satisfactorily. I think everybody, including the Auditor-General, is satisfied with the progress that has been made. I know nothing of the assertion that papers have been pulped. I will have an inquiry conducted and I will notify --
—You know nothing generally about your department. That has been well established.
—When the honourable member learns to count he can learn to talk.
—The honourable member for Blaxland will remain silent. The Minister will ignore the interjections.
—Well, he doesn't even know anything about his department.
—The honourable member cannot even count. I will have an investigation made into the assertion that Wheat Board papers are being pulped and notify the honourable member of anything I discover.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAPTAIN BLIGH OPEN BOAT VOYAGE 1983 RE-ENACTMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce received a request from Captain R. W. Ware, the expedition leader of the Captain Bligh open boat voyage 1983 re-enactment, for exemption from Customs duty and sales tax with reference to the importation of an exact replica of an HMS Bounty longboat which is to be presented to the Sydney Maritime Museum after its use in the 1983 re-enactment? Will the Minister give favourable consideration to any such request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is singularly appropriate that the honourable member for Phillip has asked the question as he, indeed, is the only member ever of the Federal Parliament directly descended from two members of the First Fleet, which was very appropriately led by Captain Phillip. It is correct that I have received and have now acted upon representations from Captain R. W. Ware who, as the honourable member has said, is the expedition leader of the Captain Bligh open boat voyage 1983 re-enactment. Captain Ware, incidentally, is a direct descendant of Captain Bligh's daughter Mary.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal is to construct an exact replica of the longboat used by Captain William Bligh and his loyal crew members following the mutiny on HMS Bounty in 1789 and to repeat exactly the epic voyage which is renowned throughout the world and which has never to date been re-enacted. I am able to advise the honourable member and, indeed, the House that accordingly I have approved the issue of ministerial determinations under item 27 of Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Customs Tariff Act to enable the longboat to enter Australia absolutely free of Customs duty. I am pleased to advise the honourable member also that the longboat is exempt from sales tax under item 119 (1) of Schedule 1 of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The Government applauds the proposed re-enactment of this historic open boat voyage and the intention to present the longboat for permanent keeping at the Sydney Maritime Museum. I believe all honourable members present would wish Captain Ware and his expeditioners the best of luck, and I believe that this event will attract world-wide and very favourable media attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister alleviate the anxiety of his members on the Government side and give an answer yes or no on whether there will be a general election this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In April the honourable member for Blaxland started to float the idea of knocking off Supply. That indicated that the Australian Labor Party had no principled attitude to this matter.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I had the distinct impression that the Prime Minister floated the idea in 1975.
—There is no point of order. It is a point of argument.

—The honourable member for Blaxland must have a very faulty memory. We did not float the idea; we did it, because we had a government we had to get rid of, and our decision was confirmed three times by very large majorities through the highest court of appeal, to all the people of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The difference, of course, is that members of the Australian Labor Party have claimed that they would never knock off Supply under any circumstances. The honourable member for Blaxland last March or April started to float the idea that it might be a good idea to do so. In spite of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition had earlier said that the Budget and its related legislation would be passed about two weeks ago he had a rush of blood to the head and made one more erratic move. He said that he was going to call a special executive meeting to reassess his attitude to the Budget. He even started using that word that somebody else had used before him-'reprehensible'. As a result of this the media came to all sorts of conclusions, starting to speculate again on the Australian Labor Party's attitude to what might happen to Budget legislation. Of course this gets back to the situation in which a government that does not control the Senate cannot give a blank cheque to the Australian Labor Party because plainly its word cannot be trusted in relation to these matters, and certainly the word of the Australian Democrats cannot be trusted. Last year both parties said they would allow Budget legislation through and once when certain legislation was held up one of the Democrat senators said that, after the symbolic three months, of course they would let the legislation through. However, they ended up not letting it through. We will not give a blank cheque to the Australian Labor Party, to the erratic Bill Hayden and all his motley crew.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the greatest liar--
—Order! The honourable member for Newcastle will withdraw.
—Withdraw what? That he is the greatest liar of a Prime Minister the country has ever known?
—The honourable member for Newcastle will withdraw. If he does not, I will name him.
—I will withdraw; it is not worth getting tossed out over.
—Order! The honourable member for Newcastle will withdraw unqualifiedly.
—I withdraw unqualifiedly.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that on 5 June 1982 the Prime Minister announced a National Tree Program? Can the Minister tell the House what action, if any, has been taken since the announcement to allow the States, particularly the State of Victoria, to carry out this program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The announcement by the Prime Minister on 5 June referred to by the honourable member for Mallee has been very well received in all areas of Australia. I am delighted to know that there has been great co-operation between all sections of government following the Federal Government's initiative. In answer to the particular query raised by the honourable member, I am delighted to be able to inform him that on this occasion the State of Victoria is not, as has been the custom, being Cained. It has indicated its agreement with all the other States to co-ordinate its activities. Only last week I indicated on behalf of the co-ordinating committee that the half a million dollars allocated this year would be distributed as follows: To each of the States, $42,500; to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, $27,500 each. These amounts of money will be made available for demonstration projects and also to allow the necessary arrangements to be made. I make a special appeal to all sections of the community, including people in private enterprise, to participate in the program. The Commonwealth will make available $2 for each $1 made available by local authorities and community bodies because it is absolutely essential that we arrest the decline in tree numbers in Australia. I particularly hope that the State of New South Wales is not influenced by a report put out by a fellow named Eric Rolls in which he indicated that the number of trees in Australia is greater than it was in 1788. That is not a fact, and the incidence of the distribution of trees is more important than the total number of trees.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that all people energetically pursue this excellent initiative which has been well received by all sections of the community. I make a special appeal to my colleague the Minister for the Capital Territory to ensure, in overseeing the program in this part of Australia, that, as my colleague the honourable member for New England says, some trees will be planted around the High Court and the National Library. When going past the Lodge recently I thought it might be appropriate to ensure that more trees are planted around it also.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Communications by reminding him of the stand down last week of 800 workers at the Goodyear factory in Granville, Sydney. Does the Government have a policy of supporting local industry by giving preference, through government and semi-government instrumentalities, to locally manufactured goods? Does the Minister's Department conform to this policy? Is the Minister for Communications aware that, although the local tyre industry has announced unscheduled shut-downs and has pending claims of dumping in this market, his Department has just let large tyre supply contracts to Toyo, a Japanese company with no local manufacturing facilities? Is it true that the losing tenderer was Goodyear Australia?

—It is true that the Government has a policy to achieve what it can with government contracts carried out by Australian manufacturers employing Australians. Indeed, in my Department and those instrumentalities under my responsibility that policy is, without any doubt whatsoever, carried out in practice. In the case of Telecom Australia and the Australian Postal Commission, I have a responsibility, for instance, of approving contracts of the value of $ 500,000 or more. I seem to spend a fair proportion of my life reading the contract documents sent to me by Telecom and the Postal Commission. I can assure the honourable member and the House that in every single one of them there is an analysis of the proportion of the work which will be done within Australia by Australian manufacturers. There is also an analysis of the compliance with the offsets program. This is something that I look to in some detail, and I analyse the material put forward by the authorities on that aspect.

QUESTION.PARA: That same requirement on me applies to Aussat Australia Pty Ltd. I think that if the honourable member casts his mind back he will recall that, when we announced the contract for the communications satellite, emphasis was placed on the fact that this would lead, for the first time in Australia, to the development of subsidiary industries which would contribute directly to the space industry. The same can be said, without my giving too many details, for virtually-so far as I know-all the contracts let by the statutory authorities under my responsibility.

I do not know whether the contract for tyres was a contract for more than $500, 000. If it was less than that amount it may be something that Telecom Australia or the Postal Commission has had regard to itself. I do not know particularly what it is proposed should be done with them but I will make specific inquiries. I repeat, however, that with respect to every contract that I have had regard to since I became the Minister, not only have Australian manufacturers and Australian employment been given particular attention by statutory authorities but also our goal in that respect has been achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do, Mr Speaker.
—Does he wish to make a personal explanation?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—The Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt), in reply to an arranged question asked earlier by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), seriously misrepresented the attitude that I had expressed on behalf of the Opposition to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program and seriously misrepresented the accuracy of the information I quoted. I and the Opposition have supported the objectives of the Program, not opposed them as stated by the Minister. We have not knocked the Program because it is the Australian Labor Party's roads program of 1974 dressed up in new clothes. He questioned also, and sought to ridicule, the statements I had made that the work proposed for construction can not possibly be carried out with the funds that will be available. To validate the statement I made, I quote from a letter of 20 October from Mr Whelan, the Minister for Consumer Affairs and Minister for Roads in New South Wales. With reference to the cost of the works that have been promised under the ABRD Program, Mr Whelan, referring to New South Wales only, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The estimated cost of the works which Mr Hunt indicated he expected to have completed by 1988 is $1,725 million. The funds which are estimated to be available for construction under the Roads Grants Acts and the ABRD programme total $660 million, so there is an estimated shortfall of $1,065 million.

Clearly, the projects being promised by the Government in this early election grab bag of projects cannot possibly be carried out with the moneys that are likely to be available. I mention also in support of my explanation that the Notice Paper has carried since yesterday my notice of motion given on 26 October condemning the Government for not providing a set allocation of funds for national highways to the States and the Northern Territory under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. The Minister, if he wished to challenge the accuracy of what I said two days earlier, has had ample opportunity to bring that matter on for debate, but he has not done so. In support of my statement I point out that for the first time in roads legislation no allocations to the States for national roads have been written into law. I conclude on two points. Firstly, the work in this grab bag of promises cannot possibly be carried out by 1988 with the funds that are likely to be available. Secondly, there is no guarantee to any State-to Queensland for the Bruce Highway, to New South Wales for the Hume Highway, to Western Australia, Victoria or to anywhere else-that it will receive the moneys that have been indicated by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is now arguing the issue.
—I will conclude, Mr Speaker. There is no guarantee that the money will be available because it has not been written into law.
—Does the Minister wish to respond to that personal explanation?
—Just briefly, Mr Speaker.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, indeed.
—The honourable gentleman wishes to make a personal explanation. He may proceed.
—The honourable gentleman has misrepresented me and, indeed, the program. It was quite clear--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The Minister was responsible for the program. The program cannot seek a personal explanation in the House, surely.

—I allowed the honourable member for Shortland very considerable latitude in making his personal explanation. I allowed him to present what amounted to argument. I think it is fair to allow the Minister to respond.

—I make two points. In my second reading speech I made it clear that the reason why no set amount was allocated to any State in the national highway program was that flexibility was needed to ensure that by 1988 we were able to complete the objectives of the program. That was to complete a dust-free, virtually flood-free national highway system by that date. Of course, in order to achieve that some flexibility is required in the way in which those funds are allocated over the period. It was not wise to set a specific amount in 1982 to each one of the States. The other important thing is that the honourable gentleman seems to have missed a very important element. For his benefit and for the benefit of the House I make this one point clear. When tallying or adding up the amount of funds that are to be available, it is necessary to add the supplementary funds that will be available from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program to those which are currently available under the Roads Grants Act until 1984-85. A new provision under that program will be necessary beyond that date. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable gentleman wishes to make a personal explanation. He may proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) gave an answer earlier today to a question from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) regarding the closing of the Australian High Commission in Nairobi during an attempted coup in Kenya earlier this year. The honourable member for Higgins asked the Foreign Minister whether the Australian Embassy had been closed during that period. The Foreign Minister then made a reference to a statement I had made in regard to the tabling of the report of the parliamentary delegation in Africa in which statement I spoke about this matter. The Foreign Minister then went on to say, in so many words, that I had not been quite telling the truth and that the Australian High Commission had not closed down.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what information has been given to the Foreign Minister, but both the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) and I were in Kenya at the time and attempted on the day of the coup and the day after to make contact with the High Commission. We rang the High Commission and there was no answer. That was after we had been turned away by an army patrol on the road into Nairobi. We rang every number in the Nairobi telephone book that was given for members of the Australian High Commission. There was no answer to those telephone calls. There had been an attempted insurrection in the country and we were not able to contact our diplomatic representation. The next day we were successful in getting back into Nairobi and we contacted the High Commission. We were told by the Acting High Commissioner, Mr Les Luck, that he had sent the staff home. We were further told by Mr Luck that the High Commission would be operating only on a limited basis that day and the staff would be going home early. Mr Luck further informed me however that the Commission would be putting an answering machine on the telephone number there. It did not do that because later on that day I had cause to ring the High Commission to make inquiries and there was no answer once again.

I further inquired of Mr Luck what the Commission had done to contact Australians who were in Kenya at the time. His response was that they had contacted those people who worked for the Government there. I would have thought that the High Commission would have been trying to do something about the tourists who were there. Representatives of the Japanese Embassy, the Canadian High Commission and the American Embassy had gone around the hotels in Nairobi to seek out nationals from their countries and to place notices in the foyers of those hotels. I asked Mr Luck, who was the Acting High Commissioner, whether he did not think that would be an idea for the Australian High Commission, seeing that the Commission did not have a list of Australian tourists in Kenya at the time. He said that he had not thought of doing that and that he would proceed to do so. It took him about 24 hours to get around to doing that-at least at the Hilton Hotel where the parliamentary delegation was staying. I think I quite properly criticised the activities of the Acting Australian High Commissioner and his staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is now arguing the matter. He has stated the facts.
—Mr Speaker, with due respect, the Foreign Minister was most critical of me in his reply and said, in effect, that I had overreacted to the situation.

—The honourable gentleman is arguing the matter. He is entitled to state the misrepresentation; he has done that. He is entitled to state the facts ; he has done that. I cannot allow the matter to proceed as a matter of argument as to whether the criticism was justified or unjustified.

—Mr Speaker, I will continue with the matter of the misrepresentation. I completely reject the answer given by the Foreign Minister in reply to the question. I know the facts that were pertaining in Kenya on that day as does the honourable member for Hume. I suggest that the Foreign Minister should get proper advice from his Department, not the type of advice he gave in answer to the Dorothy Dix question he was asked today.

—by leave-I make two points. First of all I state that I certainly did not accuse the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) of telling lies. I did regard the criticism that he made as unjustified. The second thing is that I did not say, as he alleges I did , that the High Commission did not close. I made no reference to that. I merely comment now that, as I recall, the coup took place in the early hours of a Saturday morning or a Sunday and that certainly communications were very difficult. That might have been one of the reasons the honourable member had trouble contacting the High Commission. Nevertheless I will look at the Hansard record for today in the light of the honourable member's comments today and try to give him a more detailed reply in due course as soon as I can.
