SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) asked a question without notice concerning the award of a contract for coastal surveillance to H. C. Sleigh Aviation Ltd of Melbourne. I was unable to provide all the details that he sought at that time but promised to provide them as soon as possible. I have written to the honourable member. I know it would be his wish to have that letter incorporated in Hansard. Therefore, to save the time of the House, I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard.
—I think the Minister ought to read the letter.
—The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Holding,
This afternoon you addressed to me a question without notice about the award of a contract for coastal surveillance to H. C. Sleigh Aviation Ltd of Melbourne.
I was unable to provide all the details you sought, but promised to provide them to you as soon as possible.
A full answer to your question is below.

Did the Minister cause a Press Release to be issued in his name on the 1st October 1982, indicating a contract worth about $11.4m had been let to H. C. Sleigh Aviation Ltd of Melbourne for coastal surveillances.
A:
Yes.
Did the Minister's Press Release state that this contractor would be using New Rockwell Shrike Light Twin Aircraft.
A:

No. My statement referred to new aircraft beginning operations in early 1983. In this context the term ''new'' referred to the up-graded arrangements and equipments being fitted and was not intended to apply to the actual air frames being used.

Was the unsuccessful tenderer for this contract Air Queensland, who tendered on that basis of using Nomad 24 Aircraft, in accordance with what the tenderer believed to be stated government policy, to use Nomad aircraft for surveillance work.
A:

Air Queensland was one of several unsuccessful tenderers. The tender document specified a suitable light twin-engined aircraft for the coastal sectors and clearly stated the technical requirements, but did not specify the use of Nomad aircraft.
Was the Nomad subject to test audit on climb performance while the Shrike was not so tested.
A:

The Minister for Aviation advised me that both aircraft have been tested to the appropriate Australian performance certification standards, the Shrike Commander aircraft in 1971 and the Nomad aircraft earlier this year. In each case, this involved a test of climb performance with one engine inoperative and the current certifications for these aircraft require their ability to meet these test requirements at the approved gross weights.
Has it subsequently been found-
(1) the Shrike aircraft contemplated for use, are not new as stated in the Minister's Press Release,
(2) that subject to the same audit test as the Nomad, it did not perform nearly as well.
Is it that-
(3) The gross weight of the Shrike Commander for I.F.R. operations, had been overstated by 400 lb, thereby rendering the aircraft ineligible for the award of this contract.
A:
(1) Not applicable. See answer to 2 above.
(2) See answer to question 4.

(3) The Minister for Aviation advises me that the answer to the question is No. The gross weight for I.F.R. operations for the Shrike Commander aircraft is 7150 lbs, at which the aircraft type was demonstrated in 1971 to officers of the then Department of Civil Aviation to be capable of meeting all of the performance requirements for Australian airworthiness certification. Some slight deterioration in performance with age occurs in all aircraft but there is no reason to believe that the Shrike Commander aircraft to be used in fulfilment of the contracts are unsafe or unable to satisfy the performance requirements set out in the tender specifications.

How does the Minister explain the gross irregularities, continually occurring in his Department, in the technical evaluation of tenders, and the granting of a tender, which on the face of it was clearly contrary to expressed government policy.
A:

The allegation is incorrect and no explanation is required. In this case the Tender Assessment Committee comprised representatives from my Department, Department of Finance, the Department of Health, which is the major user and the Department of Aviation which provided technical advice on whether the aircraft being offered met the tender specification.
Kind regards,
Yours sincerely,
RALPH J. HUNT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reports and Ministerial Statement

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr STREET

TALK.START.PARA: —(Corangamite-Minister for Foreign Affairs) For the information of honourable members I present two reports on the Government's ongoing activities in the field of arms control and disarmament. These reports are: First, the report to the Parliament by the Australian delegation to the Second Special Session of the General Assembly of the United Nations devoted to disarmament, UNSSOD II; and, second, the report of the Australian delegation to the 1982 session of the Committee on Disarmament. I seek leave to make a statement outlining the Government's ongoing activities in the area of arms control and disarmament.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr STREET

TALK.START.PARA: —In tabling the reports I also draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that last Sunday, 24 October, was United Nations Day, and the first day of what the world community annually celebrates as disarmament week. Each year during this week world attention is focused on the issue of arms control and disarmament. It is an opportunity for governments to inform their people about their respective policies on disarmament and arms control and to explain what they are doing to promote disarmament. So far this year, for example, the issue of arms control, disarmament and nuclear safeguards has been debated in this House on several occasions, and I have also spoken on this issue both within and outside the United Nations.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Australian Government has supported actively and continues to support actively the concept and objectives of Disarmament Week. The Government recognises that the only proposals likely to succeed are those which take full account of the need for states to be confident that such proposals contain proper verification and compliance measures and do not impair their basic national security. Today, I do not intend to discuss the contents of the two reports in great detail. They stand in their own right. I propose instead to look at the results of UNSSOD II; briefly cover developments in the Committee for Disarmament during 1982; say something about the arms control and disarmament process; and, finally, review the Government's policies in this important area of its foreign policy.

The results of UNSSOD II fell far short of the expectations of many governments and individuals. Strenuous efforts and long hours of negotiations failed to reach agreement on the main elements of its proposed final document on a comprehensive programme of disarmament-CPD-and review of progress in disarmament since the first special session in 1978. Failure to agree on the review was, to a considerable extent, due to the refusal by the Soviet Union and its allies to accept any responsibility for the erosion of international confidence since UNSSOD I. The split between supporters of East and West within the non-aligned states, and rivalries and conflicts between members of the movement, also undermined the chances of agreement.

The work of CPD was similarly frustrated. Some states attempted to gain unilateral propaganda advantage by seeking to dictate the terms of the international disarmament debate with superficial, one-sided and unverifiable proposals. In addition, the determination of the nuclear weapons states to hold to their established defence policies and the insistence by non-aligned countries-including a number which are themselves significant military powers- that only the nuclear weapons states had obligations proved damaging to the work of the session.

The second Special Session took place against an unstable international background. In mid-1978, when the first Special Session on Disarmament met in New York, international confidence was reasonably high. Since then events in many parts of the world, including Cambodia, Vietnam, North and South Africa, Afghanistan, the Persian Gulf, the Middle East, Poland and the South Atlantic, as well as the unrelenting arms build-up by the Soviet Union have badly shaken that confidence. Clearly too, some of the hopes for the Special Session were unrealistically high, and took too little account of the fact that disarmament cannot operate in a political vacuum. Further, the process of restoring confidence and turning our hopes for disarmament into actual measures requires a calculated and practical approach. Many delegations approached their task acutely aware of the world situation but, ironically, this sapped rather than stimulated the will of some delegations to negotiate.

What, then, did the Special Session achieve? First, it helped to establish among the community of nations a better understanding of the essential basis for progress in arms control and disarmament. Secondly, all member states of the United Nations reaffirmed their commitment to the final document of the first Special Session. Thirdly, the Session put the full weight of the General Assembly behind other crucial arms control negotiations. The Session endorsed the start and intermediate range nuclear forces negotiations which are under way between the United States and the Soviet Union. Similarly the Session endorsed the work of the Committee on Disarmament on a new and stronger convention to ban chemical weapons and on the nuclear test ban question. Fourthly, the objective of a comprehensive program of disarmament was reaffirmed. The session agreed that the draft CPD should be referred back to the Committee on Disarmament for further work. Finally, the second Special Session launched the World Disarmament Campaign, designed to mobilise public opinion world wide. The campaign is to be funded from within the existing United Nations budget.

In supporting the World Disarmament Campaign the Government is particularly aware of the need for it to be implemented in countries where citizens do not have access to an unhindered flow of a broad range of information and opinion on disarmament issues and are not assured of the right to express their views freely and publicly. In Australia the campaign will support continuous efforts to inform and mobilise public opinion on disarmament. Another limited, but timely and related decision taken at the Session was that the number of United Nations fellowships on disarmament should be increased. In short, the Special Session neither damaged, watered down the existing disarmament agenda, nor set back the negotiations now in train. It may even have given impetus and purpose to them, and established a more realistic and stronger base for future negotiations.

We should not expect immediate results from the negotiations to which I have drawn attention. They involve sensitive and complex matters going to the heart of the national security of states. That is not to say I am pessimistic about the outcome. It is simply that effective disarmament measures inevitably take time to negotiate.

Throughout the Special Session the Australian Delegation made strenuous efforts to achieve a consensus for further progress. Our delegation participated fully and constructively in the formal proceedings of the Session and was very active in informal discussions and drafting groups. In my speech to the Special Session I spelled out the several priorities which Australia hoped the Special Session would give close attention. These were:
One, halting the nuclear arms race;
two, revitalising and strengthening the nuclear non-proliferation regime;
three, a comprehensive and fully verifiable ban on nuclear tests;
four, an effective and verifiable ban on the production, use and stockpiling of chemical weapons;
five, the drawing up of a comprehensive program of disarmament;
six, measures to encourage a reduction in the conventional arms race; and
seven, developing a framework for building confidence and trust.

I now turn to the Committee on Disarmament. This is the only permanent multilateral negotiating forum concerned with arms control and disarmament questions in which all the regions of the world are represented. Australia was a founding member of the Committee and has ever since played a very active role in its work. The delegation's report shows that during 1982, the work of the Committee, like UNSSOD II, was greatly affected by the unfavourable international climate. Nevertheless, it continued its work in a number of fields , particularly in areas to which Australia gives a high priority.

First, work has proceeded in the Committee to draw up a convention to impose a comprehensive and verifiable ban on chemical weapons. Australia has always favoured pressing ahead with this work, especially in light of the persistent reports in recent years that chemical weapons have been used against both combatants and civilian populations in Indo-China and Afghanistan. As confirmation of our concern at these allegations, the Government had samples of material from Indo-China, which were said to have been chemical warfare agents, examined by the Australian Defence Laboratories. Although these particular samples did not contain chemical warfare agents, worrying reports of the use of chemical agents persist. The Australian Government believes that a continuing effort by the international community is necessary to ensure that whatever evidence becomes available is thoroughly investigated. Australia remains prepared to examine any tangible evidence of chemical weapons use which it considers merits study. Several countries including Australia are presently consulting about the possibility of setting up a permanent mechanism in the United Nations to investigate reports of chemical weapons use.

Secondly, there is a genuine concern among many Australians and among citizens of other countries that there should be an end to the nuclear arms race, and we have made it clear that we support the major nuclear arms control negotiations which are going on between the United States and the Soviet Union. We must all remain sensitive to the tremendous dangers of nuclear war; but we must not assume that to be the only danger. The past 37 years of the nuclear age have, in fact, been an age of non-nuclear wars. In this current year alone, for instance, there have been about eleven military conflicts, all of them non-nuclear, though some involved nuclear powers.

The well-meaning activists for nuclear disarmament sometimes give the impression of believing that the world would become safe, and the welfare of humanity secure, if only there were no nuclear weapons. Others put forward the proposition that nuclear vulnerability contributes to peace while a credible nuclear deterrent contributes to war. There were no nuclear weapons in 1939, or in 1914, but untold millions lost their lives. The basic task of diplomacy, to my mind, is to reduce the likelihood of war, most especially to prevent those wars that might become nuclear, and limit those wars which cannot be prevented.

The Government's unqualified support for a strengthening of the nuclear non- proliferation regime, through its active participation in the Non-Proliferation Treaty and its uranium safeguards policies, are now widely recognised. For five years the Government has been a leading proponent within both the United Nations and the Committee on Disarmament of the early negotiation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. A working group has been established to study aspects of what would be needed to verify such a treaty. This was an important practical step towards the goal of the early negotiation of a comprehensive test ban. The United States, the USSR and the United Kingdom have agreed to take part in that working group. The Government hopes that France and China will also agree to do so. Australia will continue to promote the CTB objective within the Committee on Disarmament.

Progress in disarmament is dependent on a number of factors. There is the need for disarmament to focus on real issues and practical solutions. Disarmament goals should not be oversimplified, although they all too often are. Unrealistic slogans and proposals merely discredit the disarmament cause and its processes. Disarmament is not something which can be achieved by gestures and by posturing. Proposals have to help build confidence. They have to be devised in such a way that participants can be confident that the commitments that they have entered into would be honoured by treaty partners. That is, disarmament measures must be transparent and verifiable. If agreements do not contain these essential verification and compliance measures, they will be ineffective. Arms control and disarmament measures must always take full account of the need for states to be confident that the agreements do not impair their basic national security. No state would ever enter into a disarmament agreement if it believed that by so doing its security could be threatened. Arms control cannot be divorced from international confidence and mutual trust.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the need for progress in arms control and disarmament grows ever more pressing. The Government is pursuing realistic, practical objectives compatible with the defence of our national security. The Government will continue to work for real disarmament within the United Nations and the Committee on Disarmament. I present the following paper:
Arms Control and Disarmament-Ministerial Statement, 28 October 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This is a most important matter. It relates to the peace and stability of the world. I welcome the fact that, after some delay, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has decided to make a foreign policy statement in the House. Not too many foreign policy statements are made here these days, but they are very important from the point of view of informing not only the House but also the people of Australia as to what Government policy is and whether the Opposition thinks it can be improved. I think it is better to be discussing matters relating to foreign policy rather than just tabling statements. Recently the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) came back from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting and merely tabled a statement on what he said was a successful meeting. However, we did not have any discussion on it in this Parliament. Let me quickly advert to what are some of the keynotes of the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I look at, for example, page 6 of the statement which has this expression:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the special session neither damaged, watered down the existing armament agenda, nor set back the negotiations now in train. It may even have given impetus and purpose to them, and established a more realistic and stronger base for future negotiation.

I would like to think that this would be the case, but the facts of the matter are not really that way. Honourable members will notice that matters of disarmament are always raised by members of the Opposition in this Parliament. We raise them in the knowledge that prospects for peace and stability in the word are deteriorating. The last time that we raised this matter was as recently as April last, in a matter of public importance. We expressed the hope that the special session on disarmament would be a success. Of course, it was a bitter disappointment-not because of any failure on Australia's part but because the super powers in the world cannot see their way clear to talking about a reduction in armaments. It is a very difficult matter for them because they are basically confronting each other in terms of the improvement of weaponry. There are 40,000 nuclear weapons now between the two super powers. Yet, in looking at this in the context of whether the world can afford it we find that half the world is starving, half the world lacks health care. The world is now spending at the rate of $1m a minute on armaments. Most of the world's scientists, engineers and construction capacities are now being devoted to methods of destruction. The most recent bomb developed has the capacity of 1,400 Hiroshima bombs. This gives honourable members an idea of the extent of development of destruction. I think it is important that we get this message across to our Australian people.

One of the matters raised in the recent session on disarmament was the need for public participation and discussion. I notice that the Minister talks about that in this statement. In that context I think there has to be more leadership, bearing in mind that we are a founding member of the Committee on Disarmament. We are very concerned, for example, about matters in Indo-China. I think that is very relevant to our very survival. Diplomacy again is mentioned as being an affective method to use. I have no doubt that it is but we have to do more than that-we have to take positive initiatives. In the few moments we have on this matter we have, in my view, to talk about some of the initiatives that we in the Australian Labor Party feel-as Australians, not in any political view-we should be taking. The Minister, I note, delivered a policy speech in Brisbane on 21 October. He was quite critical of the United Nations, saying that it was ineffective and that its mandate was habitually ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Security Council.

—The Security Council. He put forward, I think-I am not trying to misquote the Minister-on that basis an untenable reason as to why we had to participate, for example, in the Sinai peacekeeping force. We have said enough about it. I have listened to what Mr Mubarak of Egypt thinks. I have looked at the recent difficulties, particularly in Lebanon, and the massive loss of life. Let me make it very clear that whilst one might claim the peacekeeping force is effective there has been no peace in the Middle East since we went there. It has nothing to do with the force. It was very clear that not many people thought it was going to be a solution. In fact there has been a horrific loss of life. There is now an international inquiry as to the reasons for the loss of life particularly among women and children. The Minister said that United Nations peacekeeping forces were ignored-in fact they were overrun in respect of Lebanon ; they counted for nothing. The Minister made the point that the Western Alliance states had no choice but to put together alternative peacekeeping forces. I think there is a choice. It is not a question of advocating an alternative approach when we are talking about international peace. The issue is to get the real intelligence resources together to guarantee that the situation cannot escalate into open warfare.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister again mentioned that he speaks frequently on the subject of disarmament. I applaud him for that. But what about all the rallies and other discussion groups that take place in Australia? We never see one Minister of the Government there. I can understand, perhaps, that they think it would be better not to go. But, if we are talking about leadership and the issues of the alternative position it is important to show leadership in this area of bipartisanship. But it is always left to us in the Labor Party to go along to the marches and talk to the people about what we think. It is not just a policy for Australia; it is a policy for the world on how we think there has to be a solution. The solution has to be achieved by dialogue. Because of the failure of the recent conference on disarmament I am mindful, as always, of what a learned Chinese diplomat said to me. He said that between every conference on disarmament the world gets more armaments than ever. He is right. If one really wanted to do an audit on it one would find that between each session on disarmament we have more arms than ever.

I recently put forward a proposal which had Australian content in it. It was that we establish in the Southern Hemisphere a nuclear weapons free zone-not a nuclear free zone; a nuclear weapons free zone. I have suggested-in fact, when we achieve office-that we convene, as Australians, an international conference of all the parties involved in the Southern Hemisphere plus the super powers. This will not affect the super powers' ability to traverse the oceans with their weapons in terms of where they see their strategic importance; but it would guarantee that all the other nations in the Southern Hemisphere would be able to say: 'We are not going to have any nuclear weapons. We are not going to fire any nuclear weapons from the Southern Hemisphere. We ask that no weapons be delivered to the Southern Hemisphere'. There is a precedent for this. There are various such treaties that relate to Latin America, the treaty of Tlatelolco, and the treaty of Antarctica. They have been agreed to by the super powers.

The Minister would be on record as saying that his Government supports plans for nuclear weapons free zones, particularly in the South Pacific and in the Indian Ocean. Certainly there is one already in Antarctica. The Government in 1975 voted for the United Nations resolutions calling for the establishment of nuclear weapons free zones in the South Pacific as well as the Middle East. I believe there is a need for a bipartisan approach for these zones in the areas that I have mentioned. Ambassador Garcia Robles was recently awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his achievements in Latin America. I had a chance, as many others would have, to congratulate him on his achievement. If we cannot get the world to disarm in nuclear terms perhaps we can get regions to disarm. Robles's concept of the treaty of Tlatelolco clearly showed the way. It was pioneering work. He was properly rewarded for it. When I took the iniative recently of writing to the concerned nations in respect of the Southern Hemisphere proposal, as well as to the two super powers, I understand that Robles said that he would support such a proposition. Also, I am delighted to read-in fact according to the Standing Orders-into Hansard a letter dated 18 October from Mexico City from Senor Martinez Cobo, the Secretary-General of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons in Latin America. He says:
Dear Mr Bowen:
I am glad to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated September 24, 1982.

Your proposal to establish a nuclear weapons-free zone in the Southern Hemisphere is of great interest to me. It will complement the Latin-American zone-which is already a reality-and those initiatives unfortunately not yet established in Africa and South Pacific.

If the whole Southern Hemisphere were a nuclear weapons-free zone, it would effectively contribute to the objectives envisaged at the moment of the creation of nuclear weapons-free zones in different parts of the Planet.
I shall distribute your memorandum to the members of the Council of OPANAL, which will convene on November 4, 1982.

I give that as an example of something that can be done. I am mindful of the fact that at the present time in the United States of America, because it is a democracy-the Soviet Union is not-there is free and fair discussion. At the present time the Catholic bishops of the United States are leading a campaign on behalf of what they term their own brethren, who are 60 million strong, suggesting that the United States policy of escalating nuclear armaments can lead to annihilation and to war. That is because the policy appears to be to give the United States a capacity for first strike and to build up enough weapons to guarantee that the Soviet Union will be forced to surrender. Can we imagine anything more horrendous than the concept that a country expects to get such a superiority in weapons that the supposed enemy will surrender without a fight? It is ridiculous. That is the worry I have at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put it around the other way and what happens?

—Put it around the other way so that the country we expect to surrender does not surrender. The other way is annihilation. I want the honourable member to think about what the United States is saying.
—Do you expect us to surrender?

—I am amazed to think that the honourable member, who normally makes no contribution to debates, offers such an interjection on the basis that he expects the United States to get peace by guaranteeing that it has so many weapons that it assumes the Soviet Union will give up. Is he mindful of the problems of Poland? Is he mindful of the divisions between the Soviet Union and China? Is he mindful of the fact that China now has a nuclear capacity? Does he expect these countries to give up? What nonsense. Why does he decry the efforts of people in the United States? I make it clear that President Nixon's disarmament negotiator, Mr Gerard Smith, is not supporting President Reagan in these issues. How stupid it is to think that we can get so many weapons that we are able to guarantee peace. The words that come to mind are: 'Isn't it better to try to light a candle than to curse the darkness?' Is that not what it is all about?

SPEECH.PARA: We all agree with the points made by the Minister, but where is the commitment, the leadership and the follow up? When does Australia ever take any initiative? When do we ever do anything as Australians? Why are we so subservient to everybody else's foreign policy in this important matter, particularly in our region? That is the point. We all want disarmament but, as the Minister said, we have been through two world wars-1939 and, before it, 1914. By the way, we fought on the side of the Soviet Union in both wars. One can see the graves in the Soviet Union which show that they are ever mindful of the death and destruction those wars caused. But there have been 135 mini-wars since the Second World War. We ought to put that on the record. My view is that the Government has not given the leadership that is required and it has not been very critical of a number of the nuclear weapons states. Certainly, and quite rightly, it is critical of the Soviet Union and it is equally wary of the fact that the Soviet Union will build up arms. But the Soviet Union is saying it is building up arms because the United States is also building up arms.

How long can we continue that argument before war starts? Is it not important to talk about the removal of arms? That is the important point, because nuclear weapons are an enemy of humanity. They are not limited to any one country; they are related to our entire planet. Look at France, to which we seem to be anxious to sell our uranium. I am not talking about peaceful uses for uranium either. France can use other uranium as a substitute for ours. It may well be using uranium from other sources for its underground testing in the Pacific. It has carried out 50 underground tests in the Pacific since 1974. This Government does not do anything about it. It takes the view that because France no longer accepts the International Court of Justice we can do no more than register a protest. When China explodes a nuclear device we express the sentiment that perhaps we can understand it. How can we understand it in terms of our own region, if there is to be some danger of nuclear surgical strikes between China and Vietnam? Of course, the Vietnamese are getting Soviet help. We ought to be talking about a world disarmament campaign which focuses on public opinion and strengthens the concept of international peace and security. I note that the United Nations budget will have some provision for such a campaign. Australia is to consider making a contribution, and I hope we do. I guarantee that if this Government does not, a Labor Government will.

I again praise the work done by our Australian representatives on the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva, and the excellent work being done at the United Nations. The Government must do more, though, than just rely on diplomats and scientific experts to say the right thing. We have to be positive; we must follow up those statements with practical propositions both with regard to leadership within our own country at all levels and in terms of taking initiatives in respect of our own region. Reason, determination and hard work will always be the requirements for disarmament. The question is an emotional one. It requires a commitment of the heart as well as intelligent control of the head. Whilst we applaud what has already happened in terms of the Government trying to help, it has to take some leadership in this country; it has to take some initiatives and it has to encourage regional nuclear weapons-free zones. The sooner it stops harping in a critical fashion, saying it cannot do anything unless something is done by the super powers, the better off we will be. The world would be better off if we would get the states in the southern hemisphere and the super powers to concur on a regional nuclear weapons-free zone. If we did that, half the world would be free of nuclear weapons and so we would have taken at least a very substantial step along the road to peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I also seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE OF INQUIRY INTO TELECOMMUNICATION SERVICES IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I table the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia and ask leave to make a statement on the Report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be no doubt in the mind of anyone who reads these three volumes that this a momentous report. The inquiry, which has now become widely known as the Davidson inquiry, has clearly applied itself vigorously and thoroughly to its task. Its report will be a milestone in the history of telecommunications in Australia. It is necessary to mention only a few of the recommendations in the report to realise just how significant it is. I will mention some of them.

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The Australian Telecommunications Commission should be abolished and replaced by an incorporated company-Telecom Australia Limited-owned 100 per cent by the Commonwealth Government.

2. Telecom Australia Limited may enter joint ventures or partnerships as well as form or participate in the formation of subsidiary companies which have as an object the operations of telecommunications systems.
3. Unrestricted use and resale of leased Telecom capacity should be permitted.
4. Independent networks should be permitted subject to ministerial authorisation.
5. There should be no restrictions on the use of independent networks in respect of the classes of traffic carried.
6. Independent networks engaging in common carrier activities should be subject to an endorsement to that effect as a condition of authorisation.
7. Telecom should be permitted to compete on an equitable basis with independent network operators engaged in common carrier activities.
8. Users should be permitted to lease satellite capacity for incorporation in leased or independent networks.
9. No restrictions should be placed on the classes of traffic carried over, or the use of leased or independent networks using satellite capacity.
10. Telecom networks and independent networks shall conform to approved technical standards.
11. Interconnection should be permitted between leased Telecom networks and national terrestrial public switched networks, subject to:
(a) Compliance with appropriate technical standards; and
(b) Payment of a time-based local call fee at each point of interconnection and any other appropriate facility charges.
12. Interconnection should be permitted between independent networks and the national terrestrial public switched network on the same basis as leased networks, provided that:
(a) Ministerial authorisation has been given for interconnection; and
(b) The interconnection agreement is available on public record.
13. The private sector should be permitted to participate in all aspects of terminal equipment marketing.
14. The private sector should be permitted to participate in wiring in customer 's premises.

15. Responsibility for technical standards for terminal equipment should be transferred from Telecom to an independent standards authority and that the Standards Association of Australia-SAA-be so designated.
16. Telecom's network interface should be at a junction box at the boundary of the customer's property or on the outside of the building as appropriate.
17. Current Telecom practice of supplying public access telephones should continue.
18. Local councils, Australia Post or community organisations should be free to provide public telephone services.
19. Leased coin operated telephones-Redphones and others-should be regarded as part of the open terminal equipment market.
20. Australia Post should assume the role of principal rather than agent in the management of the public telegram service.
21. Telecom's pricing policy should:
(a) reflect costs to a substantial degree
(b) minimise price discrimination and
(c) adopt timed local calls.
22. Cross-subsidisation should be reduced to levels which Telecom can absorb yet remain competitive.
23. Direct subsidy funded from sources external to Telecom should be introduced for any class of subscriber which government wishes to assist.
24. Telecom should develop greater business orientation.
25. Telecom should accelerate the introduction of call charge recording-CCR.
26. Telecom should not be subject to Government direction on staffing levels.
27. Telecom's borrowings should not be subject to Loan Council approvals.
28. Telecom should pay all taxes, rates and charges.
29. Telecom should review its present policies on use of its own work force for capital works and adopt a target of 50 per cent use of contractors.

The fact that I mention some only of the recommendations should not detract from the significance of the other recommendations, all of which are important and all of which deserve serious study. All of the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry will be closely examined by the Government over the coming months. The Government welcomes and in fact encourages community comments on the report, which comments should be directed to my Department. In view of the breadth of the report and the detail involved, it is proposed to allow three months for comments to be made.

It is clear that the Committee has proposed a major restructuring of telecommunications in Australia. I expect, therefore, that the debate will be a vigorous one. I would ask that it also be a rational and sensible one. If it is, the Government will be greatly assisted in considering the recommendations and in making decisions that will be in the best interests of all Australians.

I place on public record my appreciation for the way in which the Committee members have discharged their responsibilities. In the relatively short period of 12 months they have produced a report of great significance to the whole Australian Community. The Government therefore extends its sincere thanks to Mr Davidson, Mr King, Mr Dick and Professor Karbowiak for their work in producing such a major report on telecommunications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government announced the Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia just over 12 months ago. It is important to remember that when this inquiry was established it was not an inquiry into the effectiveness of Telecom Australia or its future directions but rather an inquiry quite specifically into the opportunities for private enterprise participation in what is now the Telecom monopoly of telecommunications services throughout Australia. I think that point has to be remembered very clearly. When the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown) says that he wants a vigorous but sensible and rational debate he has to remember that the inquiry was not established in a neutral way. The inquiry was established to pursue a particular ideological line. The membership of the Committee was carefully picked so that it would come to the same conclusions as the Government had come to already prior to the inquiry being established. It was really an inquiry to pursue the doctrinaire preoccupations of the Government at the time. Honourable members will remember that at that time, a year ago, there was a spurt of ideological enthusiasm on the part of the Goverment. It wanted to see what opportunities there were for riding this hobby horse right through Telecom.

SPEECH.PARA: At least now we have a much better Minister than we had at that time but the circumstances for pursuing those sorts of obsessions are very much more adverse. At a time when jobs are evaporating all round the community and at a time when inflation is about to break into a new gallop we should not be faced with distractions such as this. It is important to remember that there has not been justification for many of the things which the terms of reference required the Committee to consider. When the Minister says that the recommendations of the inquiry are momentous he could not be more accurate.

The implications of some of these recommendations are extremely broad indeed. Take just one of the recommendations which, for some reason, the Minister did not even bother to mention. At page 32 of volume 1 the report states that the current practice of Telecom giving preference to local manufacturing industry will not now be a requirement of the new Telecom company. That is, the new Telecom company will make its purchases in any areas where there is a commercial interest for it to do so. What has to be remembered in that context is that Telecom itself has estimated that 14,000 or 15,000 jobs in Australia-outside Telecom, within the private sector, mainly in the Australian electronics industry-rely almost totally on the business that firms get from Telecom. That is a recommendation which the Minister did not even bother to mention even though it has implications for 14,000 jobs in a very vital part of Australian manufacturing industry. It is not worth pursuing ideological obsessions if 14, 000 people are to suffer as a result.

I do not want to be critical of the Minister. He did list many of the important recommendations; he did not try to argue for them; he did not try to justify them; he did not indicate that the Government was going to accept them and I want to make it clear that I am not suggesting that it should. But it is important when the Minister talks about the recommendations being momentous that people should understand just how momentous they may be. For instance, there is a recommendation that the new company should be liable for all Federal, State and municipal taxes and charges. That involves increasing Telecom's costs by about $500m or 20 per cent-an enormous increase which, of course, will have to be borne by the users of the Telecom network.

Another proposal is about introducing a time-based charge for local calls. At the moment local calls are unlimited. The proposal is that the standard rate should be for a call of a specified time; and that if people go over that time they should pay more for a call, as they do now on subscriber trunk dialling. That has enormous implications for people in the capital cities who are used to having unlimited time to make their local calls.

The third important recommendation relates to an elimination of cross- subsidisation. Cross-subsidies have been very useful in the past for trying to use the efficiency of the metropolitan concentration of telecommunications services to subsidise the very great cost of providing those services to the sparsely populated parts of Australia. Let me take just one example. In Bathurst , a normal telephone service loses $192 a year. That cost has to be met by other subscribers to the Telecom service. If cross-subsidisation is to end the implications for someone in Bathurst are, of course, extreme. He will be up for an additional $190 on average for the cost of his telephone service. The cost of telephone calls from, say, Bathurst to Townsville might increase fourfold as a result of removing cross-subsidisation. The use by independent networks of the Telecom capacity is really what the report is all about. A few people wanted to establish an alternative to Telecom for their normal telecommunications needs and also in particular for the expanding area of data processing and data transfer. This is really what the report is all about. The Government must take this very seriously indeed.

I am particularly alarmed that the recommendations go along the lines that independent operators should have access to the Telecom network at the discretion of the Minister. I am not saying that the current Minister would abuse that sort of power. But it is potentially a very profitable area which is very attractive to a number of operators. I compare the leaving of that discretion to the Minister with, for instance, the issue of broadcasting licences, where very rigorous public procedures have to be gone through. The report suggests that that sort of concession should be given to people on the say-so of Ministers. Enormous opportunities exist therefore for corruption, for milking the system, for some unscrupulous Ministers or political parties to use that sort of power, authority, and ability to dispense favours to finance their operations. I predict that if the Government accepts that recommendation members of the Liberal Party would not hang on to communications for very long. The National Party would wrench it from them because it would see that as a heaven- sent opportunity to continue to bankroll its political operations.

There are more matters of concern than for joy in this report. Indeed, there are very few matters for joy. But I would not allow our ideological preferences for retaining Telecom in the public sector to lead us to dismiss completely all the recommendations. We would similarly expect the Government to abandon its ideological preferences for handing the whole lot over to the private sector, which is really a central feature of the recommendations of the report, even though it is intended that the central operation should remain in public ownership. We must approach this sensibly. We have not dismissed all of the proposals. But there are an enormous number of areas of concern for the Australian community and for Telecom subscribers. I seriously urge the Government to think very carefully indeed before it pursues this path any further.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr N.A. Brown)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Notice of Motion No. 1 for General Business Thursday No. 10 being called on and proceeded with forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government for its failure to devise a national industry development strategy which is capable of leading to full employment within the next decade.

This motion has been on the Notice Paper for some time and I am grateful to the Government for suspending Standing Orders to allow me to move it. Record unemployment, spiralling inflation, accelerating deindustrialisation and a disintegrating social fabric are rapidly becoming the hallmarks of the Fraser Government which this country continues to suffer. In the last few weeks and even days we have been confronted with sackings and factory closures on a scale not hitherto seen in Australia since the time of the Great Depression. Nor is this a temporary phenomenon. Australia's economy has been progressively weakening virtually since the Government took office. Over the last few years this deterioration has become really pronounced.

The House should consider, for example, a key indicator of Australia's overall economic performance-the balance of payments. As the latest issue of the Australian Economic Review points out, in 1979-80 the ratio of the current account deficit to gross domestic product was 1.8 per cent. In 1980-81, however, it increased to 4 per cent and in 1981-82 it was 6.1 per cent. No improvement is forecast for the coming year. All the indicators point in the direction of worse to come. Australia's imports are running out of control. Despite the downturn in the domestic economy, imports continue to increase. Last year the value of merchandise imports rose by 21 per cent. The rate of growth in manufactured imports accelerated from 16 per cent to 25 per cent. As the Review points out, these account for more than 75 per cent of total imports. This acceleration is the main reason for the $4,000m increase in the value of imports in a single year.

The growth in imports of machinery and transport equipment was even higher than that in manufacturing as a whole, increasing by 33 per cent. In volume terms imports accelerated from 12 per cent to 17 per cent in 1981-82, at a time when total domestic demand was decelerating. This extraordinary growth in both the value and volume of imports-despite one-off factors such as increases in energy and transport equipment investment-accounts for much of the deteriorating employment situation from which we are suffering in Australia today.

I singled out the balance of payments figures because it is here as much as anywhere else that the signal failures of the Fraser Government's industrial strategy are most obvious. But I could have used instead unemployment figures and pointed out the tragic events and situations that exist at present in Wollongong, in Port Kembla, in the Newcastle region, in Dandenong or Geelong in Victoria; indeed, in my own city of Adelaide or in Whyalla. I could have used employment as an example of the terrible situation that has been allowed to arise in Australia's economy over the years of the Fraser Government. But I certainly would not be doing so in the context of not having any hope for the future. That is the sort of message that is coming from the Government side of the House. Indeed, if that message comes from this side of the House I shall refute it. I will argue that the Government's failure to devise a national industry strategy has led to the present unemployment figures. Had we had a national industry strategy and better economic policies we would have been able to plan for full employment in this country over the next decade.

The current industrial and economic strategies being pursued by the Government will lead instead to record unemployment and industrial decline. If we are to have these messages of no hope from members of the Government, let us put them on the spot and get them to propose specific policies to help lift us from this situation. I repeat: At the moment the Fraser Government has no strategy. The Government believes in the overriding efficiency of market prices as an allocative mechanism. It has a blind faith in the view that if only the Australian economy can be exposed to the forces of international competition, most of our problems will be solved. This is the message that is coming from the Government. Thus in a halting and hesitant manner the Fraser Government has repeatedly expressed the view that, irrespective of general economic circumstances, the level of support and protection for Australian industry and Australian workers' jobs would be reduced.

Industry might have coped with the situation had it known in advance that its markets were to disappear to low cost imports. Industry might have taken steps to deal with that situation through new investment, retraining and so on. But the on-again, off-again nature of the Government's stance on this issue of general levels of tariffs-often, for the most part, the on-again, off-again stance being determined by opportunist political reasons-has created the worst of all possible worlds for industry and employment. The levels of uncertainty are now so high and the unpredictability of Government responses are now so great that business confidence has fallen dramatically. This has seriously damaged investment intentions in terms of both new products and new processes. More importantly, I believe the Government free market ideology, even if inconsistent in practice, had led to a number of seriously damaging policy stances which go beyond its inconsistent stance on tariffs.

The conventional wisdom among orthodox economists in this country appears to be that Australia has failed to grow at a faster rate because of our failure to structure our economy more in line with world trends. The post-war world, they argue, has been characterised by rapid growth in liberalisation of world trade. This pattern has been associated also with a rapid growth in specialisation in world production. As a result, so the argument goes, world income has been higher than it would otherwise have been and each country has been better off since it has shared in the gains from trade which this specialisation process has made possible.

Australia's problems, according to that view, stem from the fact that we have failed to enter into this specialisation process and we have accordingly been denied access to our share of the growth in world trade. This is, in my view, just stuff and nonsense. The growth in post-war world trade has been characterised by increasing diversification, not specialisation. The developing countries of this region, for instance, have without exception diversified away from primary production into manufacturing. The industrially developed economies have equally diversified their industrial bases. They each now trade with each other in the same type of goods and services. The fact that the British now buy larger quantities of German Mercedes whilst the Germans purchase more Rover cars is a reflection of the growth in the sophistication of their respective advertising and marketing expertise rather than of any restructuring according to the canons of comparative advantage. All of the studies of the structure of the Western European economies show quite clearly that the process has been one of convergence rather than divergence, which is what one would have expected had greater specialisation occurred.

There are lessons for Australia in that. Australia's flagging share of world trade stems from the simple fact that we have been overspecialising in those commodities which on average have experienced slower growth in world trade. In 1980-81 manufactures accounted for 20 per cent of Australia's exports. They accounted in the same year for 55 per cent of total world exports. Moreover, 75 per cent of Australia's exports are concentrated in those sectors which are growing at below the average growth rate of world exports. The evidence suggests that we concentrate too heavily on those sectors where value is growing more slowly than for the world as a whole. For example, the average annual growth in the value of Australia's agricultural exports was almost 15 per cent. The corresponding world figure was almost 18 per cent. In manufacturing the disparity is even wider, with 14.2 per cent and 19.6 per cent for Australia and the world respectively.

I believe that these facts are sufficient to explode the conventional wisdom so unwisely held by my political opponents and indeed, by others. Serious as this is, the free trade, free market ideology has even more disastrous consequences for Australian industrial development. The Government, it seems, is blinded by the elegance of general equilibrium economics. It cannot see the many opportunities which exist for industrial development in the fields of mineral investment and processing, in manufacturing and in exports. Many of these opportunities exist in the field of producer goods industries-basic industries which supply a wide range of increasingly sophisticated inputs into the many spheres of production. Australia's import bill for this type of producer goods commodity amounted to $4.25 billion in the first 10 months of last year-almost half of our record end of year current account deficit. Again, the conventional wisdom holds that Australia is denied access to the manufacture of this equipment because of superior economies of scale enjoyed in the larger economies of the Western world and Japan. I believe this to be only partly true. The government should have done some basic research in this area. I believe such research would have killed that idea. I quote from the New Scientist of July 1980, which states:

Only a small proportion of goods are made with traditional automation where thousands of identical items are produced in one run. About 75 per cent of British metal goods which encompass anything between TV components to parts for combine harvesters, are made in small batches of a few hundred at a time, where orthodox automation is ruled out because it is too expensive.
Honourable members may be thinking that this is a British phenomenon. However, the article continues:
In any industrial country, the average machine tool is in use only 16 to 20 per cent of the time . . . and most people believe that a productive time of 16 per cent cannot be bettered.

There is not much scope there for economies of scale. In truth, the superiority which many of our imports have over domestically produced equipment arises from the fact that governments in the countries of origin of those imports pursue far more progressive and effective industry policies than we do in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for precedence to General Business has expired. The honourable member for Adelaide will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day under General Business for the next sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: ULURU (AYERS ROCK-MOUNT OLGA) NATIONAL PARK PLAN OF MANAGEMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sub-section 12 (1) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 I have pleasure in tabling the plan of management for Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park, together with copies of representations received in connection with the plan and the comments of the Director of National Parks and Wildlife on these representations. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park was declared a national park under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 on 24 May 1977. Shortly afterwards the Director of National Parks and Wildlife published a notice stating that a plan of management was to be prepared and inviting representations. Nine responses were received and taken into account in the preparation of the plan. In accordance with the provisions of the Act a notice was published on 20 April 1982 stating that a plan of management had been prepared and seeking representations by 27 May 1982. This notice was published in the Commonwealth Gazette and major Australian newspapers. Copies of the plan were made available at a number of locations throughout Australia, including major libraries and environment centres in each State. Copies were also made available to a number of interested individuals and organisations. Fourteen representations were received, some after 27 May. The Director of National Parks and Wildlife considered all the representations in finalising the plan.

SPEECH.PARA: In preparing the plan of management the Director of National Parks and Wildlife has been very conscious of the national and international importance of the natural and cultural values of the park. Whilst the massive geological features of Ayers Rock and the Olgas dominate the park, it also contains representative arid ecosystems and plant and animal communities peculiar to the special environments around Ayers Rock and the Olgas. Furthermore, the area is of great significance to Aboriginal people. Aboriginals have lived as part of this arid environment for many thousands of years and retain a deep attachment to the land and features of the park area. The park is an important component of the tourist industry and is an important tourist destination. The plan provides a framework in which management may proceed in an orderly manner, striking a balance between different interests. The major components of the plan of management relate to the conservation and protection of the park's natural resources, the management of visitor use, the provision of visitor facilities, and the involvement of Aboriginal people in the park and its management. The development of the Yulara Village on the boundary of the park has been taken into account and prescriptions made with regard to the phasing out of tourist accommodation facilities and the rehabilitation of areas around Ayers Rock as Yulara Village is completed.

In seeking to ensure the protection of the natural resources, the plan of management includes provision for such things as the control of introduced plants and animals, the adoption of a fire regime which takes account of the special requirements of park ecosystems, and the rehabilitation of damaged or degraded areas in the park. Special provision is also made for the protection of the interesting plant and animal communities around Ayers Rock and the Olgas. The plan envisages the provision of a range of visitor facilities and amenities. These include a visitor interpretative centre, an entrance station, picnic facilities and walking tracks. In addition, a program will be developed to interpret the places, objects and stories which best express the natural and cultural attributes of the park. Until now the interpretative programs in the park have largely focused upon Ayers Rock and, to a lesser extent, the Olgas. However, these will now be expanded to encompass the Aboriginal significance of the area and the desert ecosystem as a whole.

The plan provides for the establishment of living areas for Aboriginals, the development of Aboriginal training programs, and the secure storage of Aboriginal sacred objects. The plan also prescribes the establishment of an Uluru Aboriginal Advisory Committee on park management. Responsibility for the preparation of the plan of management for Uluru-Ayers Rock-Mount Olga-National Park rests with the Director of National Parks and Wildlife. The Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory has been consulted and involved in all stages of its preparation. During the preparation of the plan the Central Land Council was kept informed of its progressive development in order to seek Aboriginal views.

Honourable members will be aware of discussions which may lead to the granting of title to the park to the Aboriginal people. This would require revocation of the proclamation of the park under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. If approved by Parliament, this plan of management would cease to have any legal effect once the proclamation was revoked. However, the plan would still provide a sound basis for a new management plan in the light of the changed circumstances.

I wish to emphasise that the plan of management for Uluru-Ayers Rock-Mount Olga -National Park has been prepared in accordance with the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 and has taken into account all public representations received in response to the plan released on 20 April 1982 for public comment. I am confident that the plan provides a sound basis for the future management of the Park. I commend this plan of management to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 24 May 1978 Uluru or Ayers Rock-Mount Olga National Park was proclaimed under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Some 4 1/2 years later the Opposition welcomes the tabling of the management plan for the park and looks forward to its implementation when it passes through all administrative stages. The management plan has many long and short term objectives. Basically, they can be summarised in three major areas. First, development in the park will be phased out-that is, developments within the park, such as motels and so on, will be moved outside the boundaries to the new Yulara village. This will reduce the pressures on the park considerably. I understand that necessary tourist facilities such as those involved with interpretation, education and access will be established in the park to promote appreciation by the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the plan provides that increased Aboriginal involvement in the park management and the maintenance of values of Aboriginal association within the park should be facilitated. At present virtually no Aboriginal people are employed in park management at Uluru in ranger, interpretative or management capacities. This should be changed. Thirdly, the plan also provides for management regimes to be established to protect the park's conservation values, for example, with programs of rehabilitation of degraded areas, control of feral animals and maintenance of fire regimes.

Having been to the park recently I particularly welcome the moves to withdraw all of the obsolete facilities from within the park as Yulara village is completed. I think that is an extremely good move. The new tourist village, I am told, will eventually provide accommodation for some 5,000 people, at any given time, and jobs for some 500 people. If the village is run within the limits of this sound management plan I expect that will be acceptable. The existing administration of Uluru National Park is under the control of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Day-to-day management is carried out by the Northern Territory Conservation Commission. The capital and recurrent expenditure for the administrative services carried out in this fashion is funded through the National Parks and Wildlife Service appropriation in the Federal Budget.

I put it on record that a Labor government will maintain Commonwealth control over Uluru-Ayers Rock-Mount Olga-National Park. However, it will continue these current management arrangements that I have outlined. I understand that at present the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory employs about 17 people, nine of whom are rangers, in the administration and surveillance of the park. As tourism expands these figures will increase to 50 and 25 respectively. I make it clear that the Commonwealth should retain the overall control and let the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory do the work on the ground. There should be no alterations to those overall arrangements. In that respect I am concerned at the omission from the speech of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) of the important point regarding the state of play of current discussions with the Northern Territory Government. The Minister said :

Honourable members will be aware of discussions which may lead to the granting of title to the park to the Aboriginal people. This would require revocation of the proclamation of the Park under the . . . Act.
The Minister continued:
If approved by Parliament, this plan of management would cease to have any legal effect once the proclamation was revoked.

However, the Minister hoped it would be a sound basis for future management, et cetera. So do I. I draw the Minister's attention to a memo from the National Parks and Wildlife Service concerning the current state of negotiations in regard to the handing over of control to the Northern Territory. The memo states :

Over the years considerable discussion has taken place with regard to the future of the Park. The N.T. has strongly urged that ownership and full responsibility for it should be returned to the N.T. The Commonwealth's position has been that, in changing the status of arrangements for the Park, Aboriginal aspirations (i.e. ownership and involvement) must be met. Both the Prime Minister and Minister for Aboriginal Affairs have given commitments to the Aboriginal people that no changes will be made without their concurrence.
This is the rub:

Recently the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs announced that the Commonwealth would transfer the Park to the N.T. with the N.T. legislating to provide title to the Park to the Aboriginal people. Management of the Park would then be a joint arrangement between the N.T. and the Aboriginals. The CLC and Pitjantjatjara Council, representing the Aboriginals, have rejected the proposal . They are seeking title under the provisions of the Commonwealth Aboriginal Land Rights Act. They are proposing that once they get title they would prefer to make an arrangement with ANPWS, similar to that at Kakadu, for the future management of the Park. At this stage the matter is unresolved.

It had better be resolved. We support the transfer of title to the Aboriginal people. I know that the present Land Rights Act does not permit claims to alienated Crown land. So there is a problem using that avenue. The Minister has said that transfer of title is being considered by some other means. We support the transfer of that title to the Aboriginal people, but we do not support the transfer of full management control to the Northern Territory. There is no reason why the legislative model covering Kakadu should not apply to Uluru. That is, of course, an Aboriginal lands trust with registered traditional owners set up to assume title to the land should lease that area, necessary for the continuance of the Park, to the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Then instead of using the Kakadu management model, whereby of course officers of the National Parks and Wildlife Service do most of the work, we could then revert to the Uluru model that currently exists. That would involve Aboriginal title and Commonwealth control with the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory with an expanded ranger service doing the management work on the ground, as indeed it does now.

The last point I want to make-I thank the House for the courtesy in allowing me to speak-is that we want to see more Aboriginals employed in park management service at Uluru. That is our national policy. We will seek to implement training programs to enable a much larger percentage of local Aboriginal people to be employed on their own land as park rangers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This issue is of vital importance to my electorate because Ayers Rock, as well as being very significant to Australia , is of particular interest to people who live in the Northern Territory, especially the Aboriginal people of the area. This plan of management now provides them with the opportunity to engage in park management and full park involvement. The plan has been developed with their co-operation, with their interest and with their consultation at all times. It now formally recognises that there will be an Aboriginal consultative group to do the day-to-day management with the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory, the group that has been doing the on-the-ground work, and doing it very satisfactorily and very well. Probably the most overriding economic importance of this area is the tourist industry. Work has begun on the $100m Yulara tourist village. It is due for completion in 1984. Yulara will accommodate up to 6,000 people in facilities ranging from camping grounds to first class hotels. We will see a phasing out of the inadequate tourist facilities at the Rock, and this will mean a significant improvement and will allow areas within the Park to be rehabilitated and returned to their natural state.

SPEECH.PARA: However, my big reservation with regard to the plan of management puts me in total opposition to the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West). I cannot agree that the issue should remain under Commonwealth control. It should properly be under Northern Territory control. The Northern Territory is still in the anomalous position that, unlike other States, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service controls its national parks. In the early 1970s, when the ANPWS was established, the Northern Territory Reserves Board was stripped of its major parks and left with only a few reserve areas. Self government happened in the interim. This brought about a major change. We should recognise the importance of how the events fit together-that the Northern Territory is self- governing and is carrying out all the State-like functions responsibly and well. This park area is one of the areas that are still to be passed across to the Northern Territory. Last year the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions recommended that the Commonwealth hand over control of national parks to the Conservation Commission. The honourable member for Cunningham referred to the Kakadu model. I turn his attention to the Cobourg model which shows that State bodies can run it, can run it well, and can accommodate the interests of Aboriginals and local residents. I certainly do not accept the centralist view of the Australian Labor Party as to how it should be run.
