DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House:

INTERJECT.PARA: Report relating to proposed work in the Parliamentary zone: Construction of extensions to Commonwealth Avenue, Kings Avenue and Melbourne Avenue, land axis bridges, intersection improvements and other works.
Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, I present the reports of the Committee entitled 'Lack of co-operation by the Queensland Government' and 'Strategies to help overcome the problems of Aboriginal town camps', incorporating three dissenting reports, together with the transcripts of evidence and extracts from the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The first report brings to the attention of the Parliament the Committee's extreme concern at the lack of co-operation it has received from the Queensland Government in relation to its inquiries into fringe-dwelling Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal education. The Committee sought the opinion of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in relation to its powers to summon State witnesses to appear before it, and the Attorney-General advised that, under its resolution of appointment, the Committee was not able to summon witnesses from State governments. The Attorney-General's opinion is included as an appendix to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee considered that the co-operation of the Queensland Government is of particular importance to its inquiries. There are over 46,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people resident in Queensland. This represents over one- quarter of the total Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population. There are many initiatives being undertaken in Queensland in relation to Aboriginal affairs and the Committee would have benefited from being able to discuss these initiatives with the officers involved. Unfortunately, this was not possible. The co-operation of State governments is, I understand, a problem for other committees as well as the Aboriginal Affairs Committee, though perhaps it is more acute in this case.

The second report concerns the economic and social problems of Aboriginal communities and groups living on the fringes of cities, country towns and other communities. The Committee was asked by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) to undertake this reference, which required it first to identify the problems and then to develop strategies to overcome these problems. It was a most challenging exercise.

The Committee was appalled at the deplorable conditions in which Aboriginal fringe-dwellers, or town campers as they are referred to in this report, live. There are up to 20,000 town campers located in about 200 communities throughout mainland Australia. The report highlights inadequate housing, ill health, lack of essential services, unemployment and, in a number of cases, lack of land tenure as the most distressing of the problems facing town campers. The Committee identified three types of town campers: Namely, the permanents, transients and homeless drifters. The broad range of strategies devised will assist all town campers. However the problems of the homeless drifter and transient required separate attention, and I will refer to them later in this statement.

There are no easy solutions to the problems of town campers. The Committee was concerned to address the questions of whether town camping situations ought to survive, and under what circumstances they should continue to exist, or whether there are alternative approaches which Aboriginals should be given the opportunity to pursue. In considering the reasons which have caused some Aboriginals to adopt the lifestyle of the town camper, the Committee concluded that there is no doubt that many town campers find attractions in living in a town camp environment and wish to continue to live as town campers. However, the Committee is also conscious of the long term factors which have forced some Aboriginal people to move from situations in which they lived traditionally into town camps.

Strategies to overcome the problems of town camps must then have two strands: Firstly, to overcome the existing problems of the town campers and, secondly, to take steps to reduce the drift of people into town camps. The provision of appropriate housing is the first step in an integrated approach to overcome the existing problems of the town campers. The Committee has recommended that there must be increased funding to enable all town campers to be housed by 1988. This could be in important bi-centennial initiative for the benefit of our indigenous people. This will first require a survey of the needs of the town campers, but on a very preliminary estimate, on today's costs, about $200m will be required to ensure that that need is met.

The success of strategies devised in other areas such as health, education and employment is strongly dependent on the provision of adequate shelter being provided for Aboriginal town campers. The implementation of the strategies to overcome existing problems will involve a substantial degree of Aboriginal self- management, both at the national level through the Aboriginal Development Commission and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, and at the local level through relevant Aboriginal organisations and the town campers themselves. In the areas of health and alcohol, on which previous Committee reports have been given to the Parliament, the Committee recommended greater Aboriginal involvement in all stages of the delivery of services. Much still remains to be achieved in terms of Aboriginal involvement.

Many of the problems experienced by town campers can be overcome through effective co-operation at the local level, and the Committee believes that local government authorities have a significant role to play in the implementation of the strategies in consultation with the local Aboriginal community. The Committee believes that the promotion of a better understanding of town campers in the non-Aboriginal community is of tremendous importance and has recommended that a public awareness program should be developed to help overcome the unsympathetic attitude of the general community towards town campers. These strategies to improve conditions in town camps could increase the attractiveness of the town to Aboriginals in remote communities. However, the attractiveness of towns can be counter-balanced by improving the conditions in home communities and outstations and the Committee has made recommendations for this. These communities would then provide an attractive alternative to town camps for many Aboriginal people.

Steps can be taken to reverse some of the long term factors which have forced some Aboriginals to leave their traditional homes and move in to town camp situations. The wider application of the community development employment projects program would mean that Aboriginal people would not have to leave remote communities to seek employment in town. The Committee was concerned at the dramatic reduction in the number of Aboriginals living on pastoral properties, particularly in the Northern Territory. The granting of excisions to Aboriginal people on pastoral properties could reduce the drift to town. However , the Committee is also concerned at the number of Aboriginal people who are not at present resident on pastoral properties but who might return to properties if excisions were granted. We therefore recommend that procedures be developed to allow former residents of pastoral properties now living in town camps to apply to have areas excised from pastoral properties.

Finally, I turn to the transients and homeless drifters. Many of the strategies described will be of benefit to them. To provide for homeless drifters, the Committee recommends that the Department of Social Security, as the department responsible for the Homeless Persons Assistance Act, provide funding for night shelters for homeless Aboriginals where local government authorities, in consultation with relevant Aboriginal organisations apply for such shelters. In catering for transients, the Committee believes that alternative camp style accommodation, appropriate to the needs of town campers, should be established. Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and local government authorities would be appropriate funding agencies for the provision of these facilities, local Aboriginal organisations should be given responsibility for operating the facilities wherever possible and the local campers should be consulted about the design of the facilities. Given the importance of maintaining kin relationship to Aboriginal people, provision should also be made for visitors in the accommodation provided in permanent camps.

Included in this report are several dissenting reports on particular matters of detail. I regret, on this occasion, that unanimity was not possible on all aspects. However, I thank fellow members of my Committee for their interest in the complex issues which have been considered in the course of the inquiry and their ready and willing co-operation to complete what I regard as a very difficult task.

I think we are all a little wiser as a result of this inquiry and our concern for the Aboriginal people remains. However, in this inquiry we have had to look not only at short term palliatives but also at the underlying causes of the problems. We have made an attempt to devise strategies to overcome these problems. Only time will tell whether or not we have been successful. In addition to my fellow Committee members I thank the staff who assisted us in this inquiry-Phil Bergin, the Clerk; Molly Cranswick, who has been with the Committee over very many years and is probably the longest-serving member; David Elder; Max Kiermaier; Penny Duff-Jones; Carol Lam; and the Hansard reporters who accompanied the Committee on its inspections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome the opportunity to speak briefly on the report of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs on strategies to help overcome the problems of Aboriginal town camps. Firstly, I commend the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), for his excellent chairmanship of the Committee and the genuine interest and concern he has always shown for Aboriginal people throughout Australia. As he did, I also thank Phil Bergin, David Elder, Max Kiermaier and the other members of the secretariat of the Committee for their assiduous support. As the first Tasmanian to have been on this Committee, my experience on it has given me a new insight into both the growing confidence among Aboriginal communities as they continue to adjust to the immense cultural shock inflicted on them by a dominant white community and the immense problems they also continue to suffer. The living conditions suffered by many town camp communities, which was the subject we concentrated on in this report, are disgraceful. I hope the general Australian community will accept the challenge and provide proper living facilities for these people by 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel we should concentrate on two particular issues. First, we should provide proper housing and, second, we should do all we can to help overcome two tragic health problems suffered by Aboriginal people in Australia-infant mortality and alcoholism. I feel very strongly that we should home in on those problems and direct all the resources we can reasonably provide to help overcome them.

The other brief point I make is that in my view the town camps should not be long term things. I believe that they should be temporary. Ultimately, I am sure that the Aboriginal communities will become part of the general Australian community but, of course, retaining the opportunity and the right to practise their own heritage, as they want to, and their own unique traditions. I have certainly welcomed the chance to be on this Committee. As I said, as the first Tasmanian on the Committee, I have learnt a great deal from our deliberations and visits to the various communities. Again, I commend the Chairman for his work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Reports dealing with Aborigines are always contentious and can generate considerable debate. The report of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs on strategies to help overcome the problems of Aboriginal town camps will be no exception. But I believe it is an ideal discussion paper that goes further than usual and comes to grips with some very practical solutions to the problems of Aboriginal people living in town camps. Approximately one-third of the town camps in Australia exist in my electorate in the Northern Territory. The submissions that were put to us, naturally, had a very heavy emphasis and concentration on the Northern Territory . A very wide range of views was put by all sectors of the community and various government agencies. Many people in the Northern Territory contributed to the inquiry in very significant ways. They spoke for and on behalf of Aboriginal people or Aboriginal organisations dealing with major social problems. One thing we should acknowledge is that the problems in town camps are very varied. They can include anything from basic needs such as the supply of water to social problems such as alcohol abuse, violence and personal hygiene. I challenge many government agencies to consider the issues and the recommendations of this report very carefully-particularly the Aboriginal Development Commission and all the Commonwealth departments with functional responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I make no apology for exerting some influence on other members of the Committee with regard to the involvement of local government in future in areas relating to Aboriginals. The one area where I have recorded my dissent in this report covers the issues of Aboriginal health. The standard and delivery of health services always constitute a most contentious issue. I have suggested in my dissenting report a number of alternative recommendations, particularly in respect of treating the independent Aboriginal health organisations as though they were filling the role of the general practitioner in any community. Similarly, I would like to see the funding of those organisations changed from direct grants to fee for service. This report goes a long way in providing a blueprint for many agencies and I strongly commend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I endorse the remarks made by the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs-the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)-and other members of the Committee who have spoken of the service provided to the Committee by a dedicated staff. On the occasions when a report is tabled, it is not my practice to refer to the basic conclusions of the report . It is there and it speaks for itself. On this occasion the Committee makes some very important recommendations which I commend not merely to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs but to the relevant State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to a matter which I believe ought to be a matter of comment, as it has been by the Chairman. I believe it ought to be a matter of comment and rebuke by the Minister. This Committee received a wide range of support not merely from citizens but from most State governments and the Government of the Northern Territory. The exception was the Government of Queensland. There is a significant Aboriginal population in Queensland. It reflects and has the same problems as Aboriginal communities living in difficult circumstances in other parts of Australia. There are fringe dwellers or camp dwellers in Queensland as there are everywhere else. When any State government, irrespective of its party politics, says that it will not even make the most menial officer in any of its departments available or any knowledge or information available to a parliamentary committee which was urged into this inquiry by the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the present Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) , who believed that it was a critical exercise for the development and pursuance of a strategy for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs then I believe that that has to be viewed seriously by this House and by the Minister. It ought to be an occasion for a rebuke. I think it is an attitude which has no place in Australia on an issue like this where a co-operative approach between Federal and State authorities is necessary if we are to confront these problems and fund solutions to them. I believe that it was in marked contrast to the attitude of every other government. I am pleased that the new State Government for my State of Victoria responded by sending along Dr Coghill, who represents the Premier on Aboriginal Affairs, to assist the Committee in whatever way he could and to provide whatever information he possibly could on behalf of the Victorian Government. I think it is true to say that this report would not have been possible if we did not have that degree of co-operation for and on behalf of those governments that have significant Aboriginal populations. For that reason I believe that the Government of Queensland unfortunately has to be condemned by the approach that was taken on this occasion. I hope that, on future inquiries, we will not be confronted with this problem.

The report again endorses what has been the general approach of this Committee on issues concerning Aboriginal affairs. It reaffirms what essentially has been a government policy and has tried to apply the philosophy of Aboriginal involvement and self-determination in what is a very difficult area. I believe that in so doing the majority of the members of the Committee were conscious of trying to provide a report which, while it dealt with particular problems, approached those problems in accordance with what has been the stated political philosphy, approach and policy of the Federal Government. I thank the House for its courtesy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Street)-by leave-agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the order of the day for a National Industry Development Strategy being called on forthwith and the honourable member for Adelaide speaking for a period not exceeding five minutes.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My speech terminated at 12.15 p.m. under sessional orders because of a misunderstanding. I was talking about the need for a national industry development strategy and the fact that scale economies are not always as important as conventional wisdom has suggested. As I said earlier, because the producer-goods manufacturing sector, so vital to the whole economy, is so underdeveloped in Australia, we are losing our ability to innovate. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to remind you of the words of Professor Endersbee, Professor of Engineering at Monash University, who said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether we like it or not we live in a world of technological imperialism, where the economic strength of nations is measured by their technological sophistication.

According to Professor Endersbee the clearest evidence of our declining involvement in technology is the decline in the work force engaged in manufacturing over the last two decades from 28 per cent to 19 per cent. Japan has far fewer lawyers per capita than we do but it has considerably more scientists, engineers and technologists. Moreover, whilst our expenditure on research and development is about average for the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries the private sector component is abysmally low. To cap this the Fraser Government has recently slashed the industrial research and development budget by 10 per cent in real terms. Equally the free trade, free market ideology blinds the Government to the role which the public sector can play in the process of industrial development.

Japan has a Ministry of International Trade and Industry-MITI-a ubiquitous instrument of Japanese industrial planning and one which has shepherded the Japanese economy through probably the most rapid and successful process of continuous restructuring and response to changing world trends. That is what we want in Australia. It is my personal hope that the Australian Labor Party, in government, will be seeking to build a MITI counterpart in Australia. We are not blind to the multitude of opportunities for industrial growth and development within the Australian economy.

Finally I point out that the Government's prevailing ideology creates yet another serious blind spot-which is not to the benefit of us all-that of the excessive control of Australian industry by foreign interests. Frankly, I do not subscribe to the international conspiracy theory in this area of concern but in many ways this high level of control by overseas interests impedes Australian development. To illustrate this point I refer to a recent article in the Australian Financial Review which reported attempts by the Association of Consulting Engineers to require the Foreign Investment Review Board to set an amount of local engineering input into major resource projects. The Association' s response to the negative treatment it has received from the Government was as follows:

Due to the Government's seemingly religious belief that nothing must be done to offend overseas investors, the Association's representations were consistently and arbitrarily rejected, until, in September 1981 the FIRB sought the Association's comments on the proposition that the Australian consulting industry was in danger of being dominated by overseas engineering organisations.
It is significant to note from that quote that the Foreign Investment Review Board asked only for comments on the proposition.

I return now to my original proposition: This Government has failed to devise a national industry development strategy capable of leading to full employment in the next decade. I believe I have demonstrated this view amply and have given an indication of some aspects of a Labor alternative. The Government's message is one of no hope. Some people are interpreting the statements of one Labor spokesperson as being ones of no hope. I ask for any such interpretation to be ignored. Labor is developing a policy of hope in macro-economic strategy and industry policies. I would have liked to introduce many other factors had the time allowed. My only hope is that before too long Labor will have the opportunity to give Australia a national industry development strategy which is capable of leading to full employment in the next decade.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allowed under the suspension of Standing Orders for this debate has now expired. Resumption of the debate will be set down on the Notice Paper under 'General Business' for the next sitting.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.58 to 2 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation I present the report of the Committee entitled 'Australia's participation in international environmental organisations', together with the transcript of evidence and extracts from the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report I have just tabled is the twenty-second report of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation since its establishment in 1973, and is the fourth report of the present Committee during this Parliament. The Committee resolved to undertake this inquiry on 14 May 1981 but because of other commitments it was not able to commence hearings until early this year, when it was decided that it would be best for the inquiry to be undertaken by a sub-committee. In the early stages of the inquiry the Chairman of the sub-committee was the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) who, as the House would be aware, is now the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs . Upon his elevation to the Ministry he resigned from the Committee as Chairman and his position on the sub-committee was very ably taken over by the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins), who held the position of Chairman of the sub- committee throughout the remainder of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was elected Chairman of the Committee, the sub-committee had completed its public hearings and was in the first stages of considering the Chairman's draft report. It was decided, therefore, that the honourable member for Scullin would maintain his position as Chairman of the sub-committee. In view of these circumstances, it is not my intention to refer in detail to the substance of this report. I wish only to indicate to the House that both the sub-committee and the full Committee were unanimous in their support for the report.

The report represents a balanced assessment of Australia's participation in some of the major international environmental organisations and also looks at Australia's peformance in negotiating and implementing international treaties of an environmental nature. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At the outset I would like to thank the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), for permitting me to inform the House of the details of the report he has just tabled. As the honourable member for Warringah mentioned, this inquiry was conducted by a sub-committee of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation consisting of myself as Chairman, the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) and, following the resignation of the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) upon his appointment as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond). This report has the unanimous support of the members of that sub-committee and, indeed, of the full Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this inquiry has been to investigate, in the first instance, the role and effectiveness of Australia's participation in international environmental organisations, with the emphasis being placed on the three recognised major bodies in the world-the United Nations Environment Program, the Environment Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Passing reference is made in the report to Australia's involvement in various other international bodies that have environmental application. As mentioned in the introduction to the report, it became evident to the sub-committee during the inquiry-that principally applies to the service departments themselves-that outside of government circles knowledge of the role and purpose of some of these international bodies was fragmented and ill- informed. Accordingly, we have decided that the report should be informative as well as investigatory in nature. In this way it is felt that the findings will be more fully appreciated and assessed by outside observers as well as by members of this House.

The introduction to the report gives an account of the growing incidence of international co-operation in environmental matters. We indicate that world environmental problems must be looked at on a global scale in order to estabish the most effective means of dealing with what has been recognised as the declining state of the global environment.

In looking at the three major bodies referred to earlier, the Committee has acknowledged the useful role which each is playing within its own area of concern. The recommendations generally support the continuation of a high level of Australian involvement in each of these organisations and in others like them . Notwithstanding my previous comments, we did receive criticisms concerning the effectiveness of some organisations. The United Nations Environment Program, for instance, was described by one organisation as a brilliant failure and by another as badly administered and politically motivated. We have recommended that the Government review its commitment to UNEP and closely monitor its involvement in the other international organisations.

An issue which came to the forefront during this inquiry was the fragmentation of responsibility among government departments in relation to Australia's international involvement. This fragmentation has contributed to what could be said to be an inefficient and wasteful approach to involvement at the Government level. The Committee has made a recommendation calling on the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) to seek ways to overcome this problem. Another extremely important issue that was raised is the lack of information available to this House and its members and to interested voluntary conservation organisations concerning Australia's international commitments. The Committee sees no justification for withholding this sort of information and has made recommendations calling for a greater degree of openness with respect to Australia's international activities.

A large proportion of this inquiry was devoted to the role Australia has taken in negotiating and implementing treaties of an environmental nature. Within this aspect of the inquiry the role and input of the Australian States became a major issue. For their part, the States want to be fully consulted prior to any negotiations in the formulation of international treaties being commenced. Presently, a draft set of guidelines stipulating principles and procedures for Commonwealth-State consultation on treaties has been formulated. The Committee was told that, to all intents and purposes, these guidelines adequately represent the current practice. We have recommended that the draft guidelines be discussed and finalised at the earliest available Premiers Conference. Many of the States made submissions calling for the insertion of Federal clauses in international treaties. The report addresses itself to this practice in some detail and comes to the conclusion that the matter needs to be resolved between the States and the Commonwealth Government as soon as possible. The Committee believes that there is nothing to be gained by delaying the signing of international treaties which have environmental implications simply because of disagreements between the States and the Commonwealth relating to the issue of Federal clauses.

Another matter of concern which came to the Committee's attention in relation to the treaty aspect of international co-operation was that treaties, once ratified, are not necessarily implemented. The Committee has recommended that formal machinery be established at the Commonwealth-State ministerial level to monitor the implementation of international treaties within Australia. In passing, one could refer to the fact that the present controversy over South West Tasmania, the question of its inclusion in the World Heritage List and what might happen flowing from that illustrates something of the Commonwealth-State conflict in the implementation of some of these agreements.

The role of voluntary conservation organisations in the international scene was an important aspect of this inquiry. Voluntary conservation organisations have been formed in an attempt to achieve better protection of the environment at the community or citizen group level. They are primarily self-funding although several of the major ones receive financial assistance from the Commonwealth through the grants-in-aid scheme. These groups believe that the Government should provide funds to enable at least one non-government representative to attend international conferences as part of the official Australian delegation. The Committee acknowledges the significant role which these groups play and has advised that greater effort should be made at looking at ways by which the non- government organisations can be accommodated. The Committee has recommended that a greater and more formalised system of consultation with these non-government groups be adopted by government departments. It has reiterated proposals made in a previous report of the Committee over the funding of non-government organisations.

The report acknowledges the development of the World Conservation Strategy and, within that strategy, the efforts being made by the Government to develop a national conservation strategy for Australia. This project is still in the formative stages and the Committee has simply recommended that when a draft strategy has been developed it be tabled in this House so that it may be fully debated by the elected representatives of the Australian people.

Finally, the report acknowledges Australia's role in Antarctica as a unique area of international involvement. The Antarctic treaty which has been formulated to regulate activity in the area may be subject to review in 1991. The Committee applauds the significant increase in funds being provided to the Antarctic Division of the Department of Science and Technology in the 1982-83 Budget and recommends that this support be maintained at least until 1991.

I thank the staff of the Environment and Conservation Committee who have worked so well for us over the years. On this inquiry Mr Alan Hume was attached to the Committee. He had the carriage of the sub-committee's work. I convey in the House the thanks of the sub-committee to Mr Alan Hume for his assistance in the inquiry and the devotion he showed in preparing what was a rather difficult report because it had to be both informative and investigatory.

In conclusion, I indicate that this report is significant and will be of interest to many members of the House. I urge the Government to consider the recommendations seriously and look forward to a response from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) in due course. Once again as Chairman of the sub-committee which conducted this inquiry I would like to extend my thanks to the input made by the honourable members for Calare and Forrest towards achieving an harmonious and balanced approach to this issue-one that we could put forward as a unanimous report of the Committee. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee on accommodation and home care for the aged, together with the minutes of proceedings and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Two years ago the Expenditure Committee set out to identify the reasons for the continued dominance of expenditure on institutional care for the aged and to establish a framework for the provision of services which allow governments to make cost-effective decisions. The Committee estimates that in 1982-83 the Commonwealth will spend approximately $960m on accommodation and home care for the aged. Of this vast sum $890m will be spent on residential accommodation and care and just under $80m on home care and domiciliary services of which the aged are the major users.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was concerned at the continuing high level of expenditure on institutional care. Despite some degree of frailty, many aged people are physically and emotionally capable of living at home. This is, of course, by no means a new revelation. Yet expenditure on institutional care has grown from $ 285m in 1976-77 to an estimated $850m in 1982-83. This is an increase in the order of $565m. By contrast, expenditure on home care and domiciliary-type services has increased by only $45m over the same period. Expenditure on institutional care was nine times greater than expenditure on home care in 1976- 77. By 1982-83 expenditure on institutional care was 11 times greater than expenditure on home care. These comparisons exclude the Commonwealth's outlay on pensioner housing and independent living units. Many previous inquiries on the same subject have all concluded that there was an imbalance in the Commonwealth funding between institutional and home care. Despite those recommendations made by these inquiries to redress the imbalance, little has ever been achieved.

After reviewing the reports that had previously been published and in the light of submissions to my inquiry, the Committee identified the basic reason for the predominance of institutional care as the relatively generous provisions for the construction and operation of nursing homes compared to the resources available for alternative forms of community-based care. The machinery for determining and allocating public financial support to the various sectors of accommodation and home care for the aged is dispersed among Commonwealth, State and local government agencies, together with religious and charitable organisations, individuals and private commercial enterprises. There is, moreover, a lack of coincidence between the responsibility for paying benefits and subsidies on the one hand and responsibility for the supervision, regulation and control of facilities and services on the other.

Despite the evidence that most elderly people wish to remain in their own homes , a number of factors prevent many aged people from being adequately cared for and housed in their own environments. These factors work towards the drift of aged people towards high cost institutional care. These matters are explored in some detail in the body of the report just tabled. The Committee concluded that improvement in the delivery of accommodation and home care services for the aged will not be forthcoming without resolving the fundamental problem that some programs are fully funded by the Commonwealth, some are cost shared and some are not funded at all. This problem is aggravated by the fact that the Commonwealth does not have equal control over all areas of expenditure in which it is involved.

The divided responsibilities between Commonwealth and States is a major shortcoming which gives rise to the inadequate machinery for planning, policy formulation and advice, as well as a lack of accountability in terms of implementation, performance and effectiveness review. The result of these deficiencies has been the dominance and relevant opulence of institutional health-based facilities and the uneven and mostly inadequate supply of community -based domiciliary services. Not all of the blame for these deficiences should be attributed to the problem of divided financial and functional responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States. The procedures for determining Commonwealth budget allocations for accommodation and home care for the aged tend to reinforce the expansion of nursing home care whilst placing further pressure on the domiciliary sector.

The Committee was advised that the annual Budget processes are designed to result in each program competing for funds with every other program within a limited aggregate expenditure that the Government considers appropriate. But the Committee was also advised that the Budget processes do not automatically result in the examination of efficiency objectives involving several different programs . This focus of the Budget process on individual programs and the neglect of broad efficiency criteria has inevitably led to distortions in the allocation of public expenditure in the area of accommodation and home care for the aged. This is because some programs can be subjected more readily to detailed financial control than others which provide for alternative or complementary forms of care and assistance.

Decisions on the level of funds to be allocated for home care services are taken in the annual Budget context. Limits are generally set on the number of organisations to be funded which in turn sets limits on the amount to be provided in the annual Appropriation Acts. Similar considerations apply to home nursing subsidies and the rate of subsidy under the delivered meals subsidy scheme. By way of contrast, nursing home benefits-we have heard a lot about the increased cost of nursing home benefits from the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton ) in the last few days-and deficit finance subsidies are provided as ongoing authorities under special legislation. The amount provided in the Budget in a year is an estimate based on the number of beneficiaries in receipt of nursing home benefits which, in turn, is largely determined by the number of beds available.

Decisions giving rise to an increase in the number of beds are taken by the Director-General of Health under the National Health Act. In making those decisions there has been no requirement for formal evaluation of the budgetary implications even though the approval of new nursing homes beds gives rise to significant ongoing increases in Commonwealth expenditure in the form of nursing home benefits. The $750m made available in the Budget this year to fund nursing home benefits was allocated largely without any consideration in the budgetary context. The domiciliary services had to fight for every dollar of the amount of just under $80m that they got from the Budget.

Furthermore, decisions relating to the level of nursing home benefits are made by the Minister for Health on the basis of a fees survey, the methodology of which has never been explained. These decisions, which might involve significant public expenditure, are subsequently endorsed by the Government in October of each year. This procedure is in marked contrast to setting expenditure levels for delivered meals, personal care and domiciliary care benefits where decisions tend to be taken by Ministers in accordance with the Budget processes.

In these circumstances, therefore, it is difficult to envisage how the balance between institutional and community care could ever change. Even with the expansion of domiciliary services the balance need not change particularly if outlays on institutional care continue to grow at an even faster rate. We have seen this year an increase in outlays for institutional care of around 30 per cent. This situation represents a serious deficiency in budgetary management and control. In effect expenditure decisions are taken outside the Budget context and without regard to priority. It follows that there is a serious shortcoming in accountability to the Parliament. I note that concern is again being expressed by the Minister about the increase in nursing home benefits this financial year. Similar concern was expressed last year and in previous years. Nothing has been done.

The essential problem in this area is that the States determine the standards of nursing care, which in turn sets the level of costs which are reflected in the level of fees, and which are, in turn, reflected in the level of benefits. Unfortunately, those who are concerned with setting the standards-the States- have no responsibility for paying the benefits; that is, there is a breakdown in the accountability between those who are responsible for providing the money-the Commonwealth-and those who are responsible for regulating the services provided- that is, the States. Indeed the Auditor-General, when commenting on the nursing home program in a previous report brought down by the Expenditure Committee, went into the subject of standards of care in a quite lengthy way. In that report the Expenditure Committee recommended that the Commonwealth should adopt a policy of paying to Health and Allied Services Advisory Council standards alone-a recommendation the Minister has not commented upon yet.

The Committee has made a number of recommendations which are addressed towards changing the balance between the provision of institutional and home care services. Broadly the Committee's recommendations fall into two categories. The first category concerns changes to programs on the premise that financial arrangements and functional responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States will not alter, at least in the short term. These recommendations are directed towards removing major problems and anomalies in the administration and delivery of programs, shifting the balance between institutional and home care and directing Commonwealth Government assistance for health and welfare to those in greatest need, in accordance with the Government's own stated policies. These recommendations are contained in chapters 4 to 9 of the report.

The second category of recommendations deals with the Committee's medium to long term strategy for the transfer of responsibility for the administration, delivery and financing of accommodation and home care programs to the States. The Committee's major recommendation is that present arrangements be changed in order to achieve a reduction in the number of programs, responsibility for programs be brought under one Minister, modifications to the financial arrangements to remove disincentives for the expansion of home care services and similar forms of control over all categories of program expenditure and reallocation of resources between institutional and home care. The Committee then recommends that the restructured accommodation and home care programs be transferred to the States, initially through grants, moving towards eventual absorption in the tax sharing arrangements.

More specifically, the Committee has recommended that the number of programs should be reduced to an extended care program and a nursing home care program. The Committee envisages that subsidised housing would continue to be provided under the Housing Assistance Act and come within the purview of the Minister for Social Security. The Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth cease subsidising the construction of nursing home beds. The extended care program would be provided as a grant to the States, for domiciliary and home care services. As well as replacing current programs in this area, restrictions currently applied in the separate programs would be removed to allow flexibility in the development of a wider range of services, including an attendant care allowance and funding for assessment teams.

The nursing home care program would replace current nursing home benefits under the National Health Act and Nursing Homes Assistance Act. Payment would be made to State health authorities in order that they might subsidise nursing home care provided by private, religious and charitable organisations. It is envisaged that the nursing home care grant, while still being calculated primarily on a per capita basis, would be paid formally and directly to organisations and institutions as a subsidy by State health authorities. The minimum patient contribution would still be retained. I believe that the change from individual payments to payments to institutions is a most important recommendation of this Committee.

Subsidised accommodation would be provided wholly through the Housing Assistance Act. This change would ensure that subsidised accommodation is directed to those in need rather than rehousing those who have sufficient resources, as occurs at present under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. The Committee has recommended that no more approvals be granted under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954. However the Committee recommends that existing commitments under this legislation be honoured.

The Committee proposes that strict control be exercised over the growth in nursing home accommodation to bring about a further shift in resource allocation between institution and community care. Decisions concerning the provision of additional nursing accommodation would be made by State authorities in the light of their own priorities and in relation to their respective State hospital service systems. It is proposed that where decisions are made on further nursing home accommodation in areas of demonstrated scarcity, generating consequent ongoing expenditure under nursing home care programs, consideration should be given to alternative development of home care services under the extended care program. With both programs funded through grants the relative allocation to each will be a matter for annual decision. The opportunity for Commonwealth to consider both programs at the same time should encourage a more rational approach to planning and resource allocation. It would be an opportunity for considering alternative use of resources so that a nursing home forgone does not necessarily mean funds lost to the State.

The Committee has considered that the prime responsibility for the administration and control of aged care programs must rest finally with State governments. The Committee notes, however, that whichever level of government ultimately takes prime responsibility the other must be involved. For example, there is a strong relationship between provision of services for the aged and the payment of income maintenance through the income security system. On the basis of evidence which was presented, the Committee gained the impression that most States would not be unhappy to undertake the administration of all programs concerned with the care and accommodation of the aged. Officers of numerous State health, welfare and housing authorities stated in evidence to the Committee that they were generally in support of the States taking more direct responsibility for expenditure decisions.

The Committee has recommended that an office of care for the aged be established to advise on policy in respect of the aged among all Commonwealth agencies involved in providing assistance for the aged. At present it is not clear how policy decisions regarding this area ultimately get to Cabinet. Responsibilities are spread through a plethora of departments and agencies. The major purpose of the office would be to develop a national policy on how best to provide assistance to meet the accommodation and home care needs of the aged. The office would assist in advising on and monitoring implementation of this inquiry's recommendations. It could also commission research into areas of concern possibly through the health service research and development grants. Once programs have been transferred to the States the office would have continuing responsibility in representing the Commonwealth in negotiations with the States on the size and distribution of grants proposed in the preceding section, monitoring the effectiveness of the expenditure by States and ensuring consistency in approach between the provision of direct services and the income security system.

The Committee also recommended setting up a nursing homes tribunal. People who wished to make a complaint against a particular nursing home, domiciliary service or State about the manner in which it conducted its services could safely and securely lodge a complaint with the tribunal. It became quite clear to the Committee members, during our discussions with various organisations in the States, that confidentiality was not being observed by many State health organisations in handling complaints made against nursing home proprietors. We believe that the tribunal would provide a very necessary vehicle by which people could confidentially make those complaints. It would also allow for an advocacy role to develop in the community so that a wider range of people could take an interest in what happens to the programs for the care of the aged which are put up.

In conclusion I thank my fellow Committee members-the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford), the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean), the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher). The Committee's staff-John Howard, the Committee's secretary towards the end of the inquiry, and Bob Harlow , the Committee secretary in the initial stages of the inquiry-did an excellent job in seeing that the Committee got acces to a wide range of people. They were of great assistance in compiling the final report. Ms Anna Howe and Dr Bruce Ford, the Committee's specialist advisers, brought to the Committee a breadth of knowledge that was not possessed by the medical profession alone. I think that the assistance that the Committee received from Dr Ford and Ms Howe went a long way towards ensuring that the report was as comprehensive as it is. Finally, I thank my electorate secretary, Mrs Williamson, whose interest in the care of the aged-her honours thesis was written on the care of the aged-sparked my interest in this area. Her advice and guidance throughout the inquiry have been invaluable to me. I also thank the other members of the Committee and the specialist advisers. I thank the House for its time and once again thank my fellow Committee members. I particularly thank the honourable member for Moore for the time that he put into the final drafting of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The tabling of these two reports means that the Committee has now been able to report on all references referred to it this year, with three exceptions. The Committee has been unable to report on the Garden Island Dockyard surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant proposal as it is still awaiting replies from the Department of Defence and the Department of Transport and Construction following a public hearing on 4 August 1982. The Committee is also awaiting information from the Department of Aviation on proposed domestic terminal facilities related to the redevelopment of Brisbane International Airport. The third outstanding reference is the redevelopment of Fort Queenscliff, which has only recently been referred to the Committee and will be examined next week. I thank all members of the Committee for their co-operation, loyalty and hard work throughout the year. This year has been a busy one involving some 16 references. I would like particularly to thank the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Les McMahon) who has been Vice-Chairman since August 1981 and who has chaired several meetings in my absence. Finally, I extend the thanks of the Committee members to the staff of the Committee for their dedication throughout the year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 13th report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the 199th report on the form and standard of financial statements for Commonwealth undertakings and the 202nd report on the selection and development of senior management in the Commonwealth Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 199th report is a most significant report. It reflects upon the whole financial administration and brings to the fore the question of the proper standards that should be applied in government accounting. I commend the work done by my colleague on the Public Accounts Committee Senator John Watson, and other members of the Sub-committee who were involved in this most important review. In June 1980 a joint working party consisting of officials from the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General's Office published an exposure draft and abridged report on proposed guidlines for the form and standard of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings. The joint working party asked my Committee to comment on the guidelines. This report provides a substantive response to that request.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee considered that the joint working party's request was timely because it had been apparent for many years that financial statements of many statutory authorities do not reflect the full scope of management accountability which devolves from government. While acknowledging that reserve powers are usually granted to Ministers under enabling legislation for the creation of authorities, the Committee considers that it is management which shapes the destiny of undertakings in every day affairs and operations. In such circumstances we cannot support propositions that statements of receipts and payments indicating legal and financial compliance with statutes and appropriations properly convey adequate disclosure of operations in financial terms.

Managers of undertakings should be accountable for the use of all resources over which they exercise control. Acquisitions and depletion of resources must be integrated with operating transactions so that informed decisions about potential solvency and the capacity to undertake objectives of the authority can be made. This theme is central to the formation of the guidelines and modern concepts of effective public sector management.

As a result of its deliberations, which have extended over nearly two years, the Committee has formulated several recommendations designed to improve the standard of financial reporting at all levels of government throughout Australia . Our major recommendations are:

A genuine research effort should be mounted employing resources from both within the accounting profession and outside of it, to construct systematically a relevant theoretical framework for financial reporting by public sector authorities.
Any adoption of private sector accounting standards should be seen as a short term solution.
Cash-based accounting should be eliminated as the primary focus for financial reporting by authorities except for extremely small agency situations and that accrual accounting should be adopted.
Funds statements of Commonwealth authorities are to adopt a total resources rather than working capital or cash basis of funds and are to be published as part of the formal financial statements.

The joint working party should join with accounting and other interested groups to further evaluate the nature of financial reporting by public sector bodies. Government financial support at Commonwealth and State levels should be sought by a suitably organised proposal from the accounting profession.
Program statements should be prepared by all government undertakings except where such a statement would disclose necessarily confidential information.
The audited financial statements of all government organisations should be presented to Parliament within six months of the close of the financial year to which they relate.

An Accounting Standards Review Committee should be established to examine government accounting and reporting standards, and to make recommendations for improvement. This Committee should consist of representatives from the Parliament, the Public Service and the accounting profession.

Discussions should be held between relevant Commonwealth and State government Ministers and officials on the desirability of introducing a uniform set of accounting standards and procedures for public sector authorities at all levels of government throughout Australia. An appropriate mechanism for this issue to be considered would be for a working party to be established by the Premiers Conference.

The members of my Committee fully support efforts to increase relevance, uniformity in methods and consistent application of sound accountancy so that financial reporting in the public sector will better serve the community. We believe that parliamentary support for this undertaking will enhance the commitment of statutory bodies to the proposed guidelines and strengthen the co- operation needed for their successful adoption and implementation. The Committee is heartened to learn that the general response to the exposure draft has been favourable and encouraging. In considering the question of accounting standards for government the Committee, by necessity, has had to examine the adequacy of many private sector methods. In its examination of the private sector standard- setting process the Committee is concerned only with its relevance to the public sector. No judgments are made as to the adequacy of the process or standards for the private sector. In the longer term it may be possible to draw a closer link between the two sectors in terms of reporting. In the meantime the Committee observes that differences, including the noticeable tendency of the community to identify the operations of statutory bodies with the appropriate Minister rather than with management, are becoming more pronounced. If the control of these bodies is seen as a function of the Westminister system of government, control may need modification. A distinct and rigorous philosophy of accounting in the public sector may also need to be formulated.

At an early stage in the preparation of this paper the Committee decided that it was essential for government accountants throughout Australia to have the opportunity to discuss and to evaluate the issues addressed by the joint working party's report. To fulfil this requirement the Committee, in association with the government accountants group of the Australian Society of Accountants, conducted seminars in all State capital cities which were attended by over 1,000 accountants. This indicates that there is a high level of professional concern in regard to these issues. The degree of enthusiasm shown by all sections of the accounting profession to participate in these discussions undoubtedly impressed the Committee. It is conscious that a strong effort from all professional accounting interests is required if substantial progress is to be made to improve financial reporting in the public sector. In common with its other discussion papers, the Committee recognises that many of the views expressed are contentious and would therefore welcome further contributions or comments from interested individuals or organisations on any aspect of this discussion paper.

The Committee wishes to express its appreciation to its senior adviser on accounting, Dr Max Aiken, and also to thank Mr David Shand, Dr Ian Ball and the many others for their considerable assistance and advice in the preparation of this document. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the 201st report of the Committee, 'Efficiency Audit-Administration of Bilateral Overseas Aid'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I regret that there is limited time in which to debate this report, but the Committee believes, however, that it is more important to make the report available now for the information both of honourable members and other interested persons so that informed public discussion might ensue outside this place. Unfortunately also, copies of this report are limited at the moment due to printing constraints, but there will be copies for perusal in the Table Office and the Parliamentary Library. It is expected that there will be more copies for distribution to honourable members shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly pleased to table this report as I was privileged to lead the sub-committee which conducted this very useful and interesting investigation. The sub-committee comprised Senator Georges, Senator Watson, Senator Lajovic and also the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee.

The report has particular significance to the community and to the Parliament on three accounts. Firstly, bilateral overseas aid is a major item in the Commonwealth Budget. Bilateral aid forms the major part of Australia's official development assistance budget, one which totalled $727,207,000 for 1982-83. This is nearly half of one per cent of Australia's gross national product, or over 1. 5 per cent of total Commonwealth Government outlays-that is, 1.5 per cent of all the moneys expended by the Commonwealth on Commonwealth programs and of moneys provided to the States, local government and other agencies to support the programs they administer. Secondly, the report is significant because it provides a rare opportunity for the Parliament to examine the way in which this enormous sum of money is expended. Such opportunities are, unfortunately, infrequent. A substantial part of the Committee's report is devoted to a description of the bilateral aid program, suggestions as to how the aid program could be more efficiently examined by the Parliament and, perhaps most importantly, how public and community awareness of the principles which guide the aid program and the resources devoted to it can be increased. Thirdly, the report has a significance in that it is the first report of the Public Accounts Committee on an efficiency audit. It treads new ground for the Committee. The Committee devoted the final chapter of its report to the examination of some of the issues and problems raised by this form of auditing and to suggestions as to how efficiency auditing could be made more effective and useful to administrators and the Parliament.

The Committee divided its conclusions in respect of the bilateral program into four. After a brief summary of the Auditor-General's recommendations and the resources devoted to the overseas aid program and its administration, the Committee focused on four areas in which it believes changes to current administrative practices and arrangements will have the greatest beneficial impact on the aid program. These areas are: The impartiality of the aid program; the public profile of the overseas aid program; the resources available to the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to administer the program; and, finally , arrangements for the management of the program.

Whilst the report's recommendations form an integrated package designed to improve Australian and overseas perceptions of the quality of Australian bilateral overseas aid, I should like to highlight a few of the most significant recommendations and conclusions. The Committee believes that overall the Australian aid program is adequately managed within the resources available to it, that it has a high reputation overseas, and that it has provided an important input into the development of Third World countries. The Committee also believes, though, that there is significant scope for improvement in the quality of Australian aid in terms of the management of the bilateral aid program. The Committee considers that the audit report provides a blueprint for efficient and effective aid program administration and that, with only limited exceptions, the Auditor-General's recommendations should be pursued.

The Committee does, however, have reservations about the demands that the Auditor-General's suggestions will make on the staffing and physical resources of ADAB and believes that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) will require special assistance at the parliamentary level to continue to fulfil his parliamentary and ministerial responsibilities. Therefore, the Committee recommended that the Department of Foreign Affairs urgently examine, in consultation with the Public Service Board, the staffing and physical resources available to ADAB. It also recommended that the Government should consider the appointment of a parliamentary secretary for overseas aid to assist the Minister for Foreign Affairs on overseas aid matters. The Committee believes that this latter recommendation and the recommendation that the Minister for Foreign Affairs at regular intervals issue a policy statement to the Parliament, to his department and to the public are essential prerequisites to the development of parliamentary and community debate on the nature and direction of Australia's overseas aid.

In respect of efficiency audits generally, the Committee recommended that the Auditor-General prepare guidelines specifying in broad terms the scope of efficiency audits to assist the proposed Government review of efficiency auditing, and that the report of the Government review be referred to a parliamentary committee for further examination when completed. The Committee believes that overseas aid plays such a signfiicant role in Australian relations with developing countries and is such a significant proportion of Commonwealth outlays that it is essential that development aid issues should be widely understood and debated in Australia.

Finally, I should like to thank all those Government departments, independent aid agencies and individuals who made submissions to and appeared before the Committee. Their input has been invaluable to the inquiry. I should also like to thank the Public Accounts secretariat for their work, especially Mr Alec Nicholson who was the secretary to the inquiry while on placement with the PAC as part of the Public Service Executive Development Scheme. I commend the report to honourable members.
