DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to respond urgently to the long-term effects of structural change in Australia's ten over-specialised industrial regions severely hit by unemployment and its failure to provide alternative employment possibilities and a broader economic base.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has utterly failed to grasp the significance of structural change in the Australian economy and has done nothing to ease the transition of Australia's traditional manufacturing base to new, diversified and more highly skilled forms of employment. I want to talk about the problem of over-specialisation. Employment in manufacturing, like employment in agriculture and mining but unlike employment in services, tends to be heavily concentrated in particular regions. As a result significant rises or falls in aggregate employment in manufacturing are not evenly spread throughout the nation but affect only the already high figures for manufacturing employment in particular cities, suburbs or regions. This compounds the already serious problems that exist in all cities dominated by over-specialisation and dependence on a narrow employment base. This is a universal phenomenon. Manchester, with its dependence on textiles, Detroit with its dependence on motor manufacturing, Seattle with its dependence on aircraft manufacturing, Boston with its dependence on footwear and textiles, or Liege with its dependence on coal are all in the same category. In Australia Sunshine depends on heavy engineering and chemicals, Wollongong on coal and steel, Whyalla on steel, Newcastle on coal and steel and Geelong on motor vehicles.

SPEECH.PARA: The current unemployment figure of 7.8 per cent, is not evenly spread throughout Australia. There tends to be a bunching effect in traditional industrial areas, where unemployment figures are sometimes two or three times as great. I think the community does not recognise that. This Government does not permit the Australian community to understand and recognise this, because since March 1981 it has been impossible to get local Commonwealth Employment Service figures. The scandalous reason for that decision was to prevent members of Parliament from being able to identify with a high degree of precision just how serious things were in their own areas. When the aggregate figure for unemployment spreads across the community, it disguises local impact.

Without exception the Federal electorates with the highest unemployment rates are those with the heaviest proportion of workers in manufacturing. In New South Wales in the seat of Cunningham the proportion in 1976 was 41.8 per cent, in Reid it was 35 per cent, in Prospect it was 33.6 per cent and in Blaxland it was 32 per cent. In Victoria in Gellibrand the figure in 1976 was 41 per cent, in Lalor 37.5 per cent, Corio 36.2 per cent and in Wills 35.8 per cent. In South Australia the highest figure was 32.7 per cent in Port Adelaide. The States with the largest traditional manufacturing base-that is Victoria, where according to 1976 figures 23.5 per cent of workers were in manufacturing, New South Wales, where the figure was 20.8 per cent; and South Australia, where the figure was 20 .7 per cent-are in more serious employment difficulties than are Queensland and Western Australia, in which States the proportion of workers in manufacturing was less than 14 per cent. Tasmania, which tried for heavy industrialisation and failed, now faces economic disaster.

The appalling rapidity of the employment collapse in our major industrial areas in 1982 suggest that we are entering a new era which will pose enormous challenges to social stability and our capacity to provide political leadership. Technological change must not be isolated as a unique cause of unemployment; nor should its role be minimised. Current unemployment results from a synergistic interaction of a number of factors. The first is the emergence of a global economy with its interlocking mechanisms. We see the paradoxical situation of our textile industry being dependent on cheap imported yarns, without which it cannot survive, while at the same time wanting protection against imported finished goods, which it must have to survive. The second factor is the development of excessive specialisation in particular regions; that is to say, one-crop economies such as Ghana or Tasmania. The third factor is the changing direction of demand away, for example, from durable commodities such as cars to services such as travel, from aluminium to plastics, from tinned fruit to fresh fruit. These are very dramatic changes in demand. The fourth factor is a combination of a contraction of venture capital, and impact of high interest rates and inflation as a result of which investors play safe and consumers cannot afford to buy. The fifth factor is the phenomenon of technological change that fewer people can produce far more goods.

Between 1965 and 1982, 2,060,000 new jobs were created in Australia in a time of generally rising labour participation rates. What was the net contribution of manufacturing to those new jobs? The answer, to the surprise of many, is none- not one. There was a net loss of 150,000 jobs, that is minus 7.3 per cent of new jobs, in that period. Of course, some new enterprises were begun in the industrial sector but these were more than offset by the manufacturing enterprises which expired or transferred off-shore. This is a phenomenon occuring in the United States of America as well. Much traditional industry in the north of the United States is moving off-shore to either the Caribbean or some of the low cost countries in Asia or Europe. You have probably heard, Mr Deputy Speaker, that people in the United States ask: 'How can you tell the Titanic and Detroit apart?' The answer is: 'Detroit has got a better orchestra'.

We can identify 10 problem areas in Australia. I will put them in order. No. 1 is Wollongong-Port Kembla. No. 2 is South Australia generally. No. 3 is Tasmania generally. No. 4 is the western suburbs of Sydney. No. 5 is the western suburbs of Melbourne. No. 6 comprises the Victorian provincial cities of which Ballarat is an outstanding example-it is outstandingly represented here too-as is the city of Dandenong, which is also outstandingly represented here. No. 7 is the Newcastle-Hunter River Valley area-I have to say the same thing again for my colleague, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown). No. 8 is North Queensland, perhaps not quite so well represented. No. 9 is the Rockingham- Kwinana-O'Connor basin in Western Australia. No. 10 is the seat of Geelong represented by my colleague, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes).

I want to say something about South Australia because the election there has focused people's attentions remarkably over the last few weeks. Under David Tonkin's disastrous Liberal Government, South Australia is slowly chugging backwards like the African Queen. Under the Premier's soporific rule South Australia has had the highest unemployment of any mainland State for 32 consecutive months. In August 1982 unemployment was 1.7 per cent above the national average-that is, 8.4 per cent-and it has deteriorated markedly since then. The figures are made even more serious when it is realised that South Australia's population has been falling under Mr Tonkin and is now behind the population of Western Australia making it the least populous mainland State. About 16,000 people have voted with their feet by migrating to other States. There is no evidence whatsoever of the 7,000 new jobs promised by Mr Tonkin in his 1979 election policy. The Premier has been so carried away by the prospect of a resources boom that he has put all the State's eggs in the one basket. He talks of nothing else. Even if all the mineral projects come on stream they will make a very modest contribution to employment growth. This may do positive harm if it leads to an excessive reliance on minerals as a wealth generator especially in a State as heavily urbanised as South Australia.

South Australia has been particularly hard hit by changes in patterns of demand especially in motor manufacturing and the white goods industries. Between 1966 and 1980 the proportion of average household weekly earnings devoted to the purchase of motor vehicles fell from 4 per cent to 2.7 per cent-a decline of 48 per cent-hardly an indication of bouyant future employment prospects in that area. People are keeping their cars for longer periods and spending their money on other things. Expenditure on household appliances, such as washing machines, refrigerators and electronic goods has been absolutely stable in that period-2.5 per cent in 1966 and 2.3 per cent in 1980. South Australian firms such as Horwood Bagshaw Ltd, General Motors-Holden's Ltd, Dulux Australia Ltd, Titan Manufacturing Co. Pty Ltd, Actil Marketing Ltd, Scott Bonnar Ltd, Tubemakers of Australia Pty Ltd and Northern Engineering Industries have laid off large numbers of workers in recent months. Timely action by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) has persuaded the Government to attempt to prevent a collapse of Kelvinator Australia Ltd.

In his excellent policy speech last Monday John Bannon, the Leader of the Opposition and, after 6 November South Australia's new Premier, recognised the need to diversify the traditional employment base by creating 'sunrise' industries to supplement the 'sunset' industries in long term decline. He promised to set up a South Australian enterprise fund to assist the expansion of industry by providing venture capital. This fund would pump investment into high technology and export-based industries. He will set up also a special technology task force and provide real incentives to attract high technology industries to South Australia. He recognises the need to raise skill levels in this post- industrial era. I know that, like me, John Bannon is an enthusiast for biotechnology and South Australia is well placed to develop this as a major industry and as a wealth generator.

Tasmania, like Ghana, illustrates all too clearly the dangers of relying on an economic strategy based on natural resources and resource enhancement to the virtual exclusion of all other factors. The result is that Tasmania has hawked itself around purely as a supplier of cheap electricity and nothing else. Tasmania already generates more electricity per capita than any other place on earth, with Labrador a close second. Neither could be regarded as an industrial El Dorado. At the moment 60 per cent of Tasmania's electricity sustains three huge companies-Comalco Ltd, Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Australasia Ltd and Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd which between them account for less than 2 per cent of Tasmania's jobs. All three commodities produced by hyper- hyroindustrialisation in Tasmania have dubious futures. What was originally regarded as a sure formula for success now looks like a recipe for disaster.

Unemployment in Wollongong and Port Kembla has been discussed very eloquently here this week on a number of occasions. I want to point to the changing nature of the labour force. I think this can be illustrated by comparing the electorate of Cunningham which includes Wollongong with the electorate of Bradfield-the safest Liberal seat in New South Wales. In Bradfield only 10 per cent of people were employed in manufacturing in 1976, many of them, no doubt, in management and other white collar occupations; less than one-quarter of the Cunningham figure. In Bradfield just on 65 per cent were employed in 'Information' the ' show and tell' sector of the economy-exactly 2 1/2 times as many people than in Cunningham. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table comparing employment in Bradfield and Cunningham.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The development of more sophisticated skills for our labour force has never been more vital. People employed in the ten problem areas have never been given adequate opportunities to upgrade and diversify their skills. They are working in a 1950s-type industrial environment while the rest of Australia and our industrial contemporaries are in the 1980s. Honourable members opposite, including the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Mr Peacock) who is at the table, are to blame for that. Education will be increasingly important in Australia's future as an employment area in its own right, to provide the base for future economic development and for a more complex and intellectually challenging society. To those people who doubt the capacity of nations to absorb increasing numbers of graduates in the economy I point to the example of Japan and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from Scientific American for October 1982 setting out the education level of new entrants to the labour force in the period 1950 to 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. To summarise the table I should explain that in 1950 the highest education of Japanese labour force entrants was as follows: 86 per cent from middle school; 14 per cent from higher school; and less than one per cent from college and university. By 1980 only 6 per cent of Japan's new work force entrants had only middle school education; 55 per cent had completed higher school; and 39 per cent had come from colleges or universities-a 3,900 per cent increase in a 30-year period. The table that I have incorporated should give Australians something to ponder about.

SPEECH.PARA: Much can be done also by decentralising government facilities; for example, the plan of the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Charles Jones) to have a regional taxation office in Newcastle, to set up transport testing facilities and pilot training at Albury-Wodonga and so on. It can be done. Much could be done for Ballarat and Dandenong. Much can be done for the area represented by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott). This Government will not do it. But the Australian Labor Party, in its science and technology policy, sets out 16 new areas of likely development which will be very important as wealth generators. It is essential that we elect a Labor government not only in South Australia but also, at the earliest possible moment, to take power in Canberra so that we can transform the face of the nation by allowing us to create new ' sunrise' industries which will enable us to be in the forefront of the industrial and technological developments in the Western world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) is an intelligent and respected member of this Parliament. But when he speaks on issues such as the matter of public importance before us today he gives the impression of being farsighted in a narrow minded way. Nevertheless, in reality he is bound by the dogma of the outmoded philosophy which is the fount of the party that sits opposite; a philosophy which was out of date when it was first written into the platform of the Australian Labor Party. During his attack on the South Australian Government- indeed in a way on the Tasmanian Government but more particularly on the South Australian Government-he sought to indicate the thrust of development that would occur in South Australia were the Tonkin Government to be defeated on Saturday, 6 November. The reality is that when Labor was in office in that State it was rapidly turning the area into an industrial museum. That is why the Tonkin Government was elected. It has turned that situation around.

SPEECH.PARA: After all the advocacy of the honourable member let us focus very briefly on what Labor did when it was in office. I do not want to spend too much time on it . Honourable members will recall that when Labor was in government it brought the Australian manufacturing industry close to total collapse. Tariffs were slashed by 25 per cent across the board without warning and without consultation with industry. The investment allowance was abolished and export incentive schemes were drastically curtailed. The reality is that the Opposition appears to have a fundamental confusion about the nature of the problems currently facing certain regions. A number of them were identified by the honourable member for Lalor. It is not only a problem of structural change, it is also one which is more directly the result of the current economic recession facing countries world wide. The adverse impact is not isolated to industries facing long term structural difficulties, nor to regions specialising in particular activities. Equally hard hit are the growth industries and, indeed, the more diversified regions. Few sectors of the economy have been spared the effects of the current recession.

The Government is acutely aware that structural change is inextricably linked with growth and development. Our economic and industry policies therefore do not attempt to halt structural change but to facilitate it, to ensure that the necessary restructuring is permitted to occur at a manageable pace and, importantly, without undue social and economic disruption. They are doing this by attacking inflation and providing an economic environment conducive to investment, growth and the creation of sustainable job opportunities and also by encouraging the development of a stronger, more competitive manufacturing sector through the provision of incentives for development-for example, investment, industrial research and export development and the like-and by the gradual reduction of assistance to the highly protected sectors.

This is a long term process and the policies in place are working, but they would have been more effective if honourable members opposite had sought to get an effective cohesion between any person in government and the trade union movement. Instead, they have associated with a number of the trade unions which have hindered attempts at improving the productivity of industry by disrupting our exports and our position as a reliable supplier, by demanding cost- increasing shorter working hours, adding enormously to unit labour costs, and by claiming excessive wage increases which, more than anything else, have contributed to our high inflation rate. Short term interventionist palliatives simply will not provide the basis for a sustainable recovery. Economic recovery firmly based on growing world trade and positive measures to improve industry's efficiency and competitiveness rather than relying on defensive measures are the only long term solutions. This is why the Government has continued to pursue its anti-inflationary strategy of fiscal restraint and tight monetary control. This is also why the Government has significantly improved depreciation provisions to provide investment and enable industry to take full advantage of the economic recovery. To shift from this approach would be a sell-out to those people the Opposition is claiming need help. We have heard from the honourable member for Lalor this afternoon that he wants to move people as well as industry. Of course , interestingly enough--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. I think it might happen.

—Implicit within the honourable member's argument, and implicit within the very dogma upon which his party is based, is the compulsory control and direction of labour. The honourable member cannot implement his schedule of nationalisation or his blueprint of socialism without control and direction of labour. That is what lies behind it all. It is not in his books-love his books- but his speeches give him away. All he is doing is putting forward a transparent case of the old argument of moving people as if they were digits in a computer. They are not units, they are people. Furthermore, we have the honourable member coming in on a day on which the one national daily editorialises on the speech by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) as to how he would bring about change in the economy, not by dint of the methods proffered by the honourable member but by the schedule he produced in this Parliament and outside it yesterday. What did the Australian editorialise on the official Labor program? After setting it out the editorial said, and I believe accurately:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hayden has picked all the soft options and flung them together in a package that would have disastrous implications for unemployment.

His package would be inflationary, when the inflation rates of our trading competitors are falling. He would be neither helping those already unemployed, or securing the prospects of those in jobs now. Recovery depends on reducing our inflation rate which requires belt-tightening, not a spending fling.

The editorial is headed: 'Raising false hope for the out-of-work'. The honourable member should not seek to mislead us with any other resolutions introduced into this Parliament today. That is his plan in the short term, that is what one newspaper thinks of it, and I endorse the remarks whole-heartedly. I wish there could be an approach to wage fixation that was sensible rather than the divisive and disruptive activities that are being displayed within the community. We have had brought home to us very forcibly over the past few months those sorts of divisions. If we could get together on issues rather than being apart all the time, we might be serving the country's interests by a collective effort to restore the economy more quickly to its long run growth path. We do not see that from the Opposition. Regrettably, I become divisive myself by drawing attention to what the Australian Labor Party is doing.

What has the Labor Party got to offer over and above what the Leader of the Opposition brought down yesterday? If we peruse the policy documents that have been issued, it is difficult to know. The Opposition has an industry policy, allegedly, but what is it? A package of statements. The policy has not yet been issued. As I said the other day in relation to the Opposition's housing policy, which it is allegedly rethinking, we have had decades in which to illustrate that when the Labor Party is allegedly rethinking a program it is merely rearranging its prejudices. We know that in regard to industry it will probably have some special policies for certain industries. What is new in that? This Government's sectoral policies are in place and working well. We are told that the Opposition will set up special task forces on 'key industries', on 'new industries', on 'regional industry problems'. In other words, a Labor Government will look at the problems. What sort of excuse for a policy is that?

We can also expect a Labor Government to seek to direct industries to certain regional areas. Again, we have the old compulsory control and direction of labour, that essential element of socialism. This looks very like a re-run of its old growth centre policies. What an abysmal failure they were, despite a threefold increase in urban and regional development expenditure under Labor. We all recall the total ineffectiveness of the Regional Employment Development scheme and the National Employment and Training scheme, which were originally designed to overcome the regional unemployment problem. These artificial programs simply did not work, despite the money that was lavished on them by Labor, and they will not work in the future. The Labor Party persisently refuses to recognise that in order to achieve a healthy industrial sector, Australian industry has to retain its competitive edge. Only in this way can it achieve ascendancy over cost pressures and the uncertainties of the international environment. The Labor Party refuses to recognise that there is a world wide recession and it persists in hoodwinking the Australian people that its so- called social contract with the unions will bring about industrial harmony. It is no more than a sell-out to certain vested interests in the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know I did not say that.

—I know it is endemic in the Labor Party program. That is what is important. Regrettably, the honourable member is not the sole determinant of policies for his party. Indeed, even if he has a voice on it he cannot express it if the party disagrees with him in the Caucus room. We can express a different view in this chamber. He cannot do it in there. This is the old shackle and control again. He should not ask me to accept what he has put forward today as official Labor policy. Let him look at the platform, look at the policy and, moreover, look at the record. What about the prices and incomes policy proposed by the Labor Party? Did we hear about that today in regard to the manufacturing industry? Frankly, that spells doom for the Australian industry. In no way can we expect to remain internationally competitive when elements of the trade union movement continue to state publicly that excessive demands for entering into this so-called social contract have their support.

SPEECH.PARA: The trade union movement is already insisting on the following in the Labor Party's compact: Full automatic wage indexation, annual wage increases in line with productivity improvements, an 'effective' capital gains tax, significant increases in social welfare spending, a prices justification tribunal, regulation of profit levels, regulation of non-wage incomes-dividends, rents, interest payments, directors' fees, incomes of lawyers, doctors, shopkeepers, et cetera-and trade union involvement, of course, in economic advice and planning. In other words, a Labor government would have to abdicate its responsibility for government in favour of the trade union movement to the detriment of our manufacturing industry and, therefore, to regional development.

There is no doubt that in practice Labor's proposals would mean support for higher wage rises than the economy can afford together with government provided benefits which would increase government spending massively and fuel inflation as a result. The Labor Party holds up its prices and incomes policy as 'the cornerstone of the nation's economic management under a Labor government'. It is a sort of magic wand to cure all ills or, as one respected commentator in this country described it, 'Labor's own special brand of snake oil'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—Maximilian Walsh. The fact is that prices and incomes policies of the sort envisaged simply will not work in the absence of sound economic management. They have not worked in other countries-the much vaunted social compact in Britain was admitted to be an abject failure and accommodated a 27 per cent increase in earnings in one year alone. One can easily predict the same fate in Australia. The real problem is the economic recession. The only lasting solution is to restore the level of economic activity. Whilst we cannot do very much to affect the international situation we can do something on the domestic front. This is being done. We will continue to look at ways of complementing this overall strategy. An essential ingredient which would help the recovery, and particularly the predicament, of those unemployed and which has up until now proved quite elusive is a more realistic approach to wages, to hours of work and to conditions. That is the approach the Government would take; not that in the material put forward by the honourable member for Lalor which does not represent the total complement of Labor's approach to industry, to regional development or to job creation-quite the contrary.
—The discussion is concluded.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Vietnam Veterans
To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth;
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will (a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and (b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell,Mrs Child,Mr Cross,Mr Duffy,Mr Hawke,Mr Holding,Dr Jenkins,Mrs Kelly and Mr Mildren.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHILD; DUFFY; JENKINS; JONES; MILDREN; MILTON
PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
1. That Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communication.
2. That the Australian postal service meets the needs of all Australians.

3. That any reduction in Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward will destroy the concept of the national postal service and result in: Inceased rates for mail carried outside the capital cities; a reduction in mail delivery and collection frequencies in non-profitable areas; the closure of post offices.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the powers of the Postal Commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Duffy,Dr Jenkins,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Mildren and Mr Milton.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the parliament will resolve to ask the Australia Council to reverse its decision in respect to the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, 1975 take into consideration the protection of the island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sandmining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal byproducts, including the Harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal byproducts and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the number of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Sir James Killen) agreed to:

(1) That if the House is not sitting when the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation has completed its inquiry into the management of chemicals potentially hazardous to health and the environment, the Committee may send its report to Mr Speaker or, in the absence of Mr Speaker, to the Chairman of Committees, who is authorised to give directions for its printing circulation.
(2) That the foregoing provision of this resolution, so far as it is inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
Bill presented by Sir James Killen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALKER.NAME: Sir JAMES KILLEN
TALKER.ROLE: Vice President of the Executive Council and Acting Minister for Trade and Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the new River Murray Waters Agreement between and among the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the control and management of certain water resources of the River Murray system. The new agreement is set out in the Schedule to this Bill.

From the earliest days of Federation, the Commonwealth has demonstrated a strong interest in River Murray matters, initially reflecting its concern for interstate trade implications of river traffic but more importantly in latter times reflecting a recognition of the national importance of water conservation and associated land development based on the River Murray. In fact, River Murray problems, which were already claiming a good deal of attention from 1880 onwards , probably accelerated the advent of Federation.

Linked with the history of River Murray development, we have such great names as Alfred Deakin, recognised as the father of irrigation in Australia, and the Chaffey brothers, brought out by Deakin from California to start the first irrigation development at Mildura. Isaacs, Barton, Reid, Symon and Glynn-amongst others-alluded constantly to multi-State aspects of the River Murray waters during the great convention debates which preceded Federation. They identified the highly controversial and contested issues relating to River Murray management.

The first River Murray Waters Agreement, to resolve developing conflicts in the use of River Murray waters, was signed in 1914, legislation came into effect in 1915 and the River Murray Commission was established in 1917. The new agreement now before this Parliament is the result of the first major review of this important inter-governmental agreement since those early days. River water quality, particularly in respect of salinity, has now become a key factor in the long term utilisation of what is regarded by many as the nation's most important water resource. Under the new agreement, the responsibilities of the River Murray Commission have been extended to include water quality matters, in addition to the responsibilities it has had in the past for water quantity in the main stem of the river and associated storages.

The new agreement charges the River Murray Commission with the responsibility for monitoring the quality of water in the river, in tributary inflows and in the Commission's storages. To this end, a monitoring network is already well established. The Agreement also authorises the River Murray Commission to formulate water quality objectives or standards for key locations along the river. It is against these objectives or standards that the Commission will have to develop its water management strategies.

State authorities are required to inform the Commission of proposals under their consideration which could have a significant effect on water quality or quantity in the river, and to provide the information necessary to enable their likely impact to be assessed. Obviously, the agreed water quality objectives will provide important bench-marks in this regard, and the Commission will then make representations, as necessary, to the appropriate State authority on such proposals. There is already clear evidence of the States' co-operation in implementing this provision of the new Agreement.

Also worth noting is that the water distribution provisions have been completely recast to ensure not only an equitable distribution of water between the States but also to allow each State maximum flexibility in meeting its own particular water demands. Even more importantly, the provision will enable account to be taken of the quality of tributary inflows and drainage returns to the river from each State in assessing their respective shares of the water resources under the Commission's control. This procedure should provide a strong incentive to each State to improve the quality of flows in its tributaries and from outfalls to the river.

In keeping with modern water management principles, the new Agreement now comprehends important river water management objectives for the Commission, additional to its traditional role of supplying water for irrigation. These could include flood mitigation, environmental protection, recreational uses et cetera. For over 65 years, the Commission has operated effectively within the powers defined for it by the four Governments. With the enlargement of these powers to encompass water quality, inter-governmental co-operation in the management of the river systems now enters a more difficult phase.

As in every river system, water quality is the end product of practically all major activities in the vast catchment of the River Murray-in dryland agriculture, irrigation, forestry and urban/industrial development. These are all areas of State responsibility, and the realities of the Australian Constitution require that many of the Commission's water quality responsibilities will have to be pursued in consultation and co-operation with the States. While in these areas the Commission will have mainly an advisory role, its powers of persuasion should not be underestimated, particularly if its representations are based on well researched data and are consistent with the overall thrust of the new Agreement.

The Commission retains its autonomy under the new Agreement. This is essential if it is to continue as an effective custodian in the national interest of this most important water resource, and to provide the stimulus for co-operative action by the States in the maintenance and, eventually, improvement of water quality in the River Murray. The Government believes that the new Agreement provides a realistic framework for inter-governmental co-operation in the development of long term plans for safeguarding the enormous public and private investment in irrigation settlements and urban water supply systems based on the River Murray in the three States. This Agreement, as was the case with its predecessor, depends on the goodwill of the contracting parties for its success. There is every indication that this will be forthcoming. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Sir James Killen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALKER.NAME: Sir JAMES KILLEN
TALKER.ROLE: Vice-President of the Executive Council and Acting Minister for Trade and Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to give effect to the Area to be Avoided in Bass Strait, in the vicinity of the off-shore petroleum production facilities, to which entry is prohibited to unauthorised Australian vessels over 200 tons gross tonnage. The Area to be Avoided replaces the existing restricted area first established in 1976 and enlarged in 1980. The existing restricted area is advisory only. However, with the increasing number of platforms in the area, and their economic importance to Australia, the Government considers it appropriate that additional steps should be taken to increase the effectiveness of the restrictions, enhancing the protection of the off-shore platforms and the safe movement of shipping in the region.

Under the present provisions of the Act, and in accordance with the 1958 Convention on the Continental Shelf, safety zones of 500 metres have been declared around each platform, prohibiting entry by any unauthorised vessel. The Area to be Avoided established under this Bill will extend approximately 50 nautical miles from the coast to envelop the offshore platforms and submarine pipelines. Its outer boundary will lie about five nautical miles beyond the platforms while its inner boundary will follow the outer limit of the three mile territorial sea. Complementary legislation will be introduced by Victoria extending the Area to be Avoided from the outer limit of the territorial sea to the coast of Victoria.

The areas to be avoided established by the Commonwealth and the State legislation will have the same boundaries as the present advisory restricted area. The restrictions established under the Bill will be binding on Australian vessels over 200 tons gross tonnage. For foreign vessels, the restrictions have been promulgated as an Area to be Avoided in accordance with arrangements approved by the International Maritime Organisation. The restrictions will become mandatory for foreign vessels as their governments pass appropriate legislation. The International Maritime Organisation has also approved a traffic separation scheme to the south of the Area to be Avoided to assist ship navigation. Arrangements are in place involving sea, air and radar surveillance of Bass Strait to ensure that restrictions are complied with by shipping.

Turning to the details of the Bill, clause 3 inserts a new Division 6A into the 1967 Act and clause 4 adds a new Schedule 6 to the Act defining the boundaries of the Area to be Avoided. The new section 140C provides for a penalty of a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment up to five years for unathorised entry into the Area to be Avoided or both. The penalty may be imposed on the owner, the master and any officer in charge of the vessel. In order to ensure that the new provisions can be carried out effectively, authorised persons are given powers of enforcement set out in the new section 140D. These include the power to board a vessel, to order the removal of a vessel from the Area to be Avoided and to order a disabled vessel to accept assistance. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW AIR TRAFFIC SERVICES CENTRE AND CONTROL TOWER, PERTH AIRPORT, WESTERN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: New air traffic services centre and control tower, Perth Airport, Western Australia.

The work consists of the following elements: An air traffic services operations building and associated services building; a technical maintenance centre, a radio equipment and plant and equipment building, and a control tower. The elements of the work excepting the control tower were reported on favourably by the Committee in its twelfth report of 1981. On 17 November 1981 the House resolved that it was expedient to proceed with those elements at an estimated cost of $2.7m.

The control tower element, then estimated to cost a further $0.9m, was to be the subject of a further report by the Committee in the light of master planning strategies for the overall development of Perth Airport. The Committee has now tabled its report on the control tower component. In recommending construction of the tower the Committee concluded that further development of the airport should not rule out the early construction of a wide-spaced parallel runway. It has recommended the adoption of strategy 4 of the master planning studies for development of the airport which provides for a wide-spaced parallel runway when aircraft movement demands it or earlier if recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Commmittee on Environment and Conservation.

Taking into account the recommendations of the Committee and the concern held by the local community regarding the future development of the airport, the Government has decided to proceed basically in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee, and is developing a detailed planning concept for the airport and its facilities in accordance with stragety 4. The final details are, of course, still subject to the approval of the environmental impact statement on the master plan which should be available by the end of this year. It is now practicable to proceed with the control tower. The Committee has recommended that the height of the control tower be 60 to 65 metres and that it be located in accordance with the strategy 4 option. The actual height of the tower will be the subject of further studies during the design phase, taking into account operational requirements.

The estimated cost of the tower option recommended by the Committee is approximately $2.4m based on indicative planning only. The final estimated cost will depend on further development of planning and design and the optimum height decided for the tower. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning can proceed along the lines recommended by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion of expediency in respect of the construction of a new air traffic services centre and control tower at Perth Airport. We have noted, from the comments of the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt), that it is intentioned to develop the international terminal on a modified strategy 4 basis as was outlined in the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on these works tabled in this House last week. The selected site will provide some advantage in relation to noise in surrounding residential areas. I think it is useful, in terms of what we are discussing, to refer to the strategy 4 option that was recommended to the Public Works Committee in respect of Perth Airport. Those recommendations were:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The further development of Perth Airport to the year 2000 should not rule out the early construction of a wide-spaced parallel runway on 02/20 alignment;
2. The Committee recommends the adoption of a strategy 4 for development of Perth Airport with the provision of a wide-spaced parallel runway-
(a) when aircraft movements demand it; or
(b) earlier if recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.
3. The proposed control tower at Perth Airport should be located at the site required under strategy 4 as shown in the provisional master plan and its height should be 60-65 metres.
4. The Committee recommends the construction of the control tower recommended in paragraph 82.

That paragraph of the report referred to a control tower of between 60 to 65 metres in height, which contrasted with the provisional master plan of the Department of Aviation for a tower height of 90 metres. Strategy 4 referred to by the Committee involved the construction of a parallel runway on a 02/20 alignment and a taxiway system similar to that referred to in strategy 3 but with taxiway connections to an international terminal area to the east of the present 02/20 runway.

I have indicated that the Opposition supports the motion before the Chair at the moment. But I would like to contrast the manner in which this report of the Public Works Committee has been treated with the treatment of the report last session on the international terminal at Adelaide Airport. Earlier in the afternoon we had some degree of disagreement in the chamber from Government members. Honourable members on both sides of the House were denied an opportunity to participate in discussion of a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure relating to care of the aged. Similarly, in the autumn session, the Chairman of the Public Works Committee was gagged by the Government and prevented from speaking on the recommendations of the Committee on the siting of an international terminal at Adelaide Airport. A major recommendation of the Committee in that case was overturned.

That is the bad news. The good news is that on this occasion the Committee's recommendations have been heeded by government. In the main they have been adopted. I support the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Swan ( Mr Beazley), who is not able to be here today, but who has made some contribution to this matter because it affects his electorate. On an earlier occasion he pointed out to the House the very fair manner in which members of the public were treated when they appeared before the Committee to make submissions and participate in the activities of the Committee. He indicated on behalf of his constituents and on behalf of the Opposition that it was thought that the recommendations of the Committee were appropriate and sensible. Committees of the Parliament provide very great value in creating a forum in which differing points of view within the community can be put at public hearings. People give evidence on oath. Public hearings provide an opportunity for understanding another point of view and developing the consensus that we so desperately need today to improve opportunities for people and to try to get this country out of the mess in which the Government has put it.

The point to be made about the adoption of strategy 4 as recommended by the Committee is that here we see a standing committee of the Parliament, a very important committee, in effect overruling the proposal of the responsible department, on this occasion the Department of Aviation. In a number of ways it confirms considerations of that Committee in respect of Brisbane Airport in, I think, 1979 and Adelaide Airport earlier this year. There was conflict between deliberations and recommendations of the Committee and the submissions made by the responsible department, the Department of Aviation.

I interpret this as a result, firstly, of ad hockery of the Government's policy in respect of airport development and the provision of aviation services generally. Time and time again we see that this Government does not have any clear, planned policy in respect of the provision of aviation services. It does not have any national airport program. It does not have any national airport plan. It responds generally on the basis of how far off the next State election is and when the next Federal election is rather than doing as other Western democracies do and analysing airport and aviation needs of the nation, looking at settlement and movement patterns, looking at the costs involved and looking at the investment required to provide an adequate system of air services that people can afford. Today more and more people cannot afford to travel by air in this country. Having done that the Government should lay down, for instance, as the United States has done, two five-year programs-a program from year one to year five listing the works that need to be carried out at each airport and the expected costs to revenue of each development and then a program from year six to year 10 looking at the developments and works that will be required in those years. So at any one stage there is a reference for the next 10 years of airport development works that need to be done, the priority that ought to be accorded them and the cost benefits that can be gained in respect of those developments. This is where the problem arises between the Department of Aviation- the former Department of Transport-and the Public Works Committee.

When we see this conflict and the overruling of departmental submissions by the Public Works Committee it is not simply a matter of the Parliament wanting to exercise its muscle for the sake of exercising muscle but rather it is looking at the situation in a more rational way. It shows up the weaknesses of ad hockery, the lack of a national airport program and the other weakness I want to come to. That weakness is within the present Department of Aviation, and was deeply imbedded within the former Department of Transport. There is an understaffing of key personnel, an understaffing of planning people, an inadequate provision of resources, a lack of co-ordination and overall a lack of leadership. In 1977 the report of a three-year inquiry conducted into the then Department of Transport made 300 recommendations about alterations and changes that needed to be made urgently to the airport engineering and airport planning branches of the Department-now the Department of Aviation. Never has this Government reported to the Parliament on what it did with those recommendations. We have seen continual confusion and deterioration in the provision of airport developments by the present Government. Another example is Brisbane Airport which is dragging a year behind the chain for those reasons I have just mentioned-lack of planning, lack of people with expertise, lack of co-ordination and lack of appropriate resources. The program for the provision of airport facilities for wide-bodied aircraft is also a long way behind for those very same reasons.

The Opposition supports this motion of expediency. We believe that the total project, which includes the items mentioned in the Minister's motion and the construction of a new international terminal at Perth expected to be completed in 1986, will give Perth the most modern and best airport services on our continent. They will initially provide Perth with slightly more capacity than it needs, but will provide sufficient room for growth for the next two decades. Perth is fortunate to that extent in that it will gain benefits from having those services. I have referred to the cost to the community of not having a proper plan for airport development. The Australian Labor Party, when it comes to government-I do not expect that to be very long-will establish a national airports authority so that we can put the planning and provision of airport services on a proper, organised, co-ordinated and, most of all, responsible basis. That authority will be given the responsibility for planning, developing and operating airports and for the first time will bring proper accountability for revenue and expenditure in respect of airport operations. The Opposition supports the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW TACTICAL FIGHTER PROJECT, FISHERMENS BEND, VICTORIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Stage 1 construction of new works and upgrading of existing facilities for the new tactical fighter project at Fishermens Bend, Victoria.

This proposal is for the construction of facilities at the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation and the Government Aircraft Factories to facilitate Australian industry participation in the new tactical fighter project. It involves the construction of a jet engine test cell and a co-production staff office at CAC and improvements to the canopy shop at GAF. In endorsing the need for the work the Committee concluded that for the jet engine test cell, which has yet to be designed, the commission for its design criteria, including that for the acoustic and aero-dynamic components, should not automatically be given to the supplier of specialised equipment. The Committee recommended that suitably qualified Australians should be given the opportunity to perform this task.

The Committee is rightly concerned that Australian involvement in the project be maximised and full opportunity be taken to develop Australian expertise. In the development of this proposal for the Committee's consideration, it is the intention of the Department of Transport and Construction to maximise the Australian content in both design and construction phases. The most critical elements of the test cell are the aero-dynamic and acoustic aspects and it is the assessment of the Department of Transport and Construction that the best expertise on these aspects rests with the firms which produce the special equipment and instrumentation.

Rather than arranging for an overseas firm to prepare totally the detailed design and tender documentation, the Department intends to obtain information on the acoustic and aero-dynamic aspects from the supplier of the specialised equipment. This information will be incorporated in the briefing to Australian consultants who will be commissioned to carry out the detailed design and tender documentation of the cell-hence Australian consultants will be commissed to translate the highly complex and critical design criteria into a working solution for Australian conditions. The estimated cost of the work is $5.4m at May 1982 prices. The Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion, the project can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is in agreement with the motion moved by the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt). I am particularly glad to see that encouragement is to be given to Australian expertise in high technology areas. We add our blessing to the view taken by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Mr Fife:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1982, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the intention of the Government to move certain amendments to these Bills in the Committee stage. It is the Opposition's intention to move amendments to the motions for the second reading of these Bills, dealing with matters which I will raise in a moment. I wish firstly in this cognate debate to draw attention to the determination of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to inflame the state aid debate in Australia. The Government is determined to promote policies which treat government schools and non-government schools quite differently. The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill really highlights the approach the Government is now taking. It has been the practice of governments, starting with the last Australian Labor Party Government, to provide grants to all schools on the basis that at the end of the year when the schools have experienced cost increases those grants will be adjusted through a method called the cost supplementation process to take account of the increases in prices which have been faced by the schools. That was the procedure which existed up until this year.

SPEECH.PARA: This year the Government decided to abandon the process of cost supplementation and instead to make a prediction about what costs were going to be during the year and try to incorporate within the grants a prospective allowance for those increases. What happened in the event was that the Government's prospective allowance in relation to those cost increases turned out to be pathetically inadequate. The Government realised this defect half way through this year and decided to make amends. Regrettably, however, the Government went only half the way. What it said to the non-government school sector was that it would fully compensate non-government schools for cost increases which had been experienced during the period in which the grants were intended to operate. However, in relation to government schools the Goverment was going to compensate State governments only partially for cost increases which they had experienced during the period.

What this really means is that there was a sleight of hand operating; the Government was not determined to maintain the real value of the grants which it had provided for government schools whereas it was prepared to maintain the real value of grants made to the non-government school sector. We think that is entirely wrong. We objected to the abandonment of cost supplementation in the first place. We told the Government that its prospective allowance would not work. In the event, it did not work. The point we were making at the time was that all schools, regardless of whether they were government or non-government, should be fully compensated for the cost increases which inevitably and unavoidably they were going to face during the period. What the Government said was that it expected State governments to absorb something like a third of the cost increases during the period.

Half way through this year when the Government announced with immense flourish that it was going to increase grants to the government school system by $6.3m it failed to mentioned that at the same time the government school system was losing $5m as a result of the Government's failure to compensate government schools fully for the increases they had experienced. There is no way in which government schools can absorb those increases, just as there is no way the non- government schools can absorb them. Most of the increases in costs, which all schools experience relate to increases in salaries. These account for about 80 per cent of total outgoings. Other matters such as increased maintenance and electricity charges and the like relate to increased costs. There is no way that any school can avoid the consequences of those increases. The only way schools can absorb-to use the euphemistic expression of the Government-the effects of those cost increases is for those schools in fact to reduce the quality of their operation. We think that is highly discriminatory. We believe that there should be a common approach to schools, regardless of whether they are government or non-government schools.

As I said in the beginning that was indicative of the approach which this Government has taken and which has contributed to a shattering of the consensus which was established in 1973 in relation to the funding of all schools. That was an historic consensus which put the bitterness and division of the State aid debate behind us with the creation of the Schools Commission and the adoption of the needs approach to the Commonwealth funding of all schools in Australia. It allowed the Commonwealth-the last Labor Government-to accept as its primary obligation its commitment to the maintenance of a high quality government school system. At the same time it provided a basis for that Government and succeeding governments to provide assistance to all schools on the basis of their needs, in order that parents could be sure that whether they sent their children to government shools or non-government schools they could be guaranteed that their children would receive an acceptable standard of education.

What has happened during the period of this Government is that that consensus has been gravely distorted. In the first place the Government has quite deliberately interfered with the balanced composition of the Schools Commission. I am not saying that that is a major effect, but it was one of the actions which the Government took which meant that it was all the more difficult for the members of the Schools Commission to approach the question of a compromise between the competing demands of the two school systems. Secondly the Government has been providing the Schools Commission with increasingly restrictive guidelines relating to the School Commission's funding policies. Again this has seriously compromised the Schools Commission's ability to reach a consensus on and an accommodation in relation to the needs of the two sectors.

Thirdly, and most importantly, the Government has introduced a two-part subsidy for non-government schools throughout Australia. The first part of the subsidy goes to all schools regardless of their circumstances and needs. The subsidy goes to all schools on a per capita basis as a right. The first component of the subsidy is a 20 per cent component. The second part is a 10 per cent or 20 per cent component. What that means is that under this Government no more than 50 per cent of the subsidy is needs based. Of course, that has been hugely exacerbated by the actual adjustments to the subsidy level which the Government has introduced during its period in office. I will refer to that again in a moment.

I mention now the fourth distortion which the Government has introduced. This relates to the campaign which the Minister for Education has now launched attacking those people who represent the government school system-the parents and the teachers-saying that what this Government does in respect of non- government schools has nothing to do with them. What the Minister is trying to argue is that there are two quite separate and distinct systems of education in this country, that the interests of the two never coincide and that the approaches of this Government in relation to those two sectors are not going to interfere one with the other. Of course, that is clearly nonsense. Of course, what happens to one sector will impact on the other. Take for instance the fact that there has been an increase in the enrolments in the non-government school sector. That is something which I accept with equanimity. But it cannot be said that that increase in enrolments does not have an impact on the government school sector. Of course, increasing enrolments in one sector leads to declining enrolments in the other. Of course, declining enrolments will have an effect on the government school system.

In reading what the Schools Commission has been saying in relation to increasing non-government school enrolments we find it has identified the increased level of support for non-government schools as the primary cause of increased enrolments in the non-government school sector. It is quite idiotic for the Minister to argue that we can treat the sectors separately, that they have nothing to do with each other and that the interested parties of one sector should not be concerned about what is happening in the other sector. I think the Minister is doing Australia and Australia's school children an enormous disservice by trying to re-establish, recreate and magnify the differences between the two sectors.

On the other hand our approach is entirely different. We take the view that all schools and all school children in Australia deserve to be treated fairly by the Government. That brings me to the matter I mentioned in passing a moment ago in relation to the increases in subsidies for the different levels of non- government schools in Australia.
