TALK.START.PARA: —The debate today has been greatly truncated. I do not know why; I dare say it is due to the Government's mismanagement of the Parliament. Opposition members were told that we were to confine our remarks on these two Bills-these two desperately important Bills-to 30 minutes, so I will move quickly to indicate that we will move an amendment to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill in the terms that have been circulated in my name. We will also move an amendment to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, again in the terms circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: In the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill the Government intends that certain institutions should receive no financial support for next year and the year after unless they agree to the Government's requirements in relation to amalgamations. The Armidale College of Advanced Education and the University of New England in Armidale will not receive any funds as of right, as do all other colleges and universities, unless they agree with the Government's requirements in relation to the amalgamation proposals. Serious problems exist in Armidale, and those two institutions should not be forced to amalgamate in advance of them reaching agreement about the conditions of that amalgamation. Any amalgamation in the tertiary sector ought to be designed to advance the educational objectives of the institutions, not some airy-fairy, nebulous, dubious economic objectives which the Government may believe are possible but which the Tertiary Education Commission believes, at least in the short term, are unlikely to be achieved.

Armidale is not the only place in which this problem exists. A similar situation exists in Newcastle where the University of Newcastle and the Newcastle College of Advanced Education are again being forced to amalgamate. The Milperra College of Advanced Education is being forced to amalgamate and the Hawthorn Institute of Education in Melbourne again is allocated no funds for next year or for the year after because the Government is insisting that all those institutions, as mentioned in Schedule 18 of the Bill, should amalgamate. Only when the Minister believes they have achieved a satisfactory amalgamation- satisfactory to him, not to anyone else-then and only then, will he be prepared to allocate funds. What we are saying on this occasion is that the Bill ought to be withdrawn and redrafted to ensure that, in the event that those institutions cannot reach agreement about the educational advantages which will flow from those amalgamations, the Bill ought to provide that they receive funds for next year and the year after in the normal way.

One cannot expect to rationalise the education system by holding guns at the heads of universities and colleges throughout Australia. They have been distracted from their important tasks by these amalgamations which have never been justified and the aims of which have never been spelt out. The effect on morale has been cataclysmic. I suspect that if the institutions involved are forced to some unsatisfactory amalgamation it will take them years and years to recover from the effects.

The last matter I refer to in this context is the decision of the Government to require the Orange Agricultural College in the electorate of Calare to amalgamate with the Mitchell College of Advanced Education. Again there is no real justification for it; no educational objectives need to be met. All that is said in this Bill is that the Orange Agricultural College, which has a nation- wide reputation in farm management education, is to be forced, against its will, into an amalgamation with the Mitchell College. We think that is highly unsatisfactory. We believe therefore that the Bill ought to be withdrawn and redrafted to provide that until such times as those institutions are mutually satisfied with the amalgamation arrangements-that may take another year; it may take another two years; who knows-they should not be forced into it against their wills. They should not be deprived of the financial support to which they are entitled just because they cannot comply readily with the unreasonable demands of this Government. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that grants to all schools should be fully adjusted to take account of cost of increases experienced by those schools'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. On the radio program AM this morning the Treasurer (Mr Howard) explained that yesterday's tax Bills were so important that he was happy to have as long a debate as necessary and to have as many members as possible take part in it. We can gauge the Government's interest in education by the fact that the Opposition has been given 30 minutes in which to debate these two important Bills. I thank my colleague the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) for being generous enough to give some time to me in which to speak.

SPEECH.PARA: When Labor set up the Schools Commission in 1974 its responsibility was to report to the Federal Government on the overall standards and needs of all schools. In addition, it was to make recommendations on government spending in both the public and private sector. The emphasis was on the independence of the Commission. It was then, and should always be, the responsibility of government to accept or reject all or part of the Commission's report. However, with the advent of the Liberal-Country Party Government in 1975, the independence of the Schools Commission was slowly whittled away.

In 1978, following a spate of extravagant promises in the 1977 campaign speech, the Liberals advised the Commission to allocate extra funds to the non- government sector. The Schools Commission's acquiesence gave a shabby respectability to the Government's intentions. The Commission, to its credit, at that time showed its independence and severely criticised the Government. However, in 1979 the Commission was again advised how the money was to be spent. The then Chairman, Dr Ken McKinnon, said:
Our role is to advise the Government-we assess the needs of schools and the Government makes its decisions in the light of that assessment.

These words were evidently Dr McKinnon's swan song because on 4 December 1981 he lost his position. Dr McKinnon, a highly respected Chairman, expected to be reappointed. Heads of statutory authorities are usually offered a second term. This Government has, however, shown all too often that convention and courtesy have gone by the board. Dr McKinnon's honest, independent and forthright stand on a number of controversial issues upset the Federal Cabinet. Dr McKinnon was treated with little personal regard. He stated in 1980 that the Commission's independence was vital. He also said that the Commission acted as a buffer between government and competing interests for educational funding but he said that the Government wanted it both ways-it wanted the buffer without the awkwardness of getting straightforward advice.

When Ken McKinnon went so too did the last vestiges of independence from the Schools Commission. In April 1982 I urged the Schools Commission to adhere to its charter and let the Government of the day reject or alter its recommendations. The Schools Commission should have the guts to exercise its powers and fulfil its charter under the Schools Commission Act. It is a sorry state of affairs now with the Government issuing guidelines and directions to the Schools Commission and the Commission meekly accepting them. The latest comments in the Schools Commission report for 1983 are a pathetic gasp from a shadow organisation. It is now impossible to separate the views of the Commission from the views of the Government. Their policies make them siamese twins.

Under the Fraser Government and the emasculated Schools Commission the gap between the richest and the poorest schools in Australia has widened as the Government, with the silent assent of the Schools Commission, has promoted privilege and rejected the goal of equality. The Schools Commission correctly says that this grossly unfair approach has provoked a revival of the thoroughly divisive and fruitless state aid debate which my colleague the honourable member for Fremantle has so ably illustrated. For that state of affairs the Government and the Schools Commission are to share the blame, the latter because it does not fulfil the independence of its charter and the former because it treats the Schools Commission and the people with total contempt. The cost of the Government's election promises determines education policy for this Government. That is its yardstick. I do not know any more what yardstick the so-called independent Schools Commission uses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that not only is the Opposition to be restricted to 30 minutes on these two important Bills-the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill-but also there will be no speakers from the Government side.

SPEECH.PARA: Before dealing with some specific matters contained in these Bills I will comment briefly on the relationship between the Government and the Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. As the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife), who represents the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) in this chamber-he is himself a former Minister for Education-said in his second reading speeches on 23 September, all the financial recommendations of the commissions have been accepted. This is hardly surprising. There is no real reason for self-congratulation on that point because the whole process of triennial reports, followed by tight proscriptive guidelines, followed by a report in response to those guidelines, followed by these Bills, guarantees docile commissions and made-to-measure reports. As sources of independent advice , the commissions now are mere shadows of their former selves. They ought to be sources of independent advice but quite clearly now they are not. Whilst the final decisions on funding must obviously be the responsibility of the government of the day, a process involving less proscriptive guidelines and giving the commissions the opportunity to offer at least a range of options annually could produce great benefits. At the very least, it would force the Government to justify its decisions in education more thoroughly and publicly than it now does.

I turn now briefly to the measures contained in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. I point out, first of all, that the Bill does nothing to address the problem of falling levels of participation in tertiary education, nothing to address the problem of massive youth unemployment and nothing to correct a basic lack of educational opportunity in this country. The Bill continues the Government's war of attrition against universities and colleges across the land. Funding for universities and colleges of advanced education will remain at starvation levels-starvation to a point where many of their activities will have to be restricted. As the Schedule to the Bill reveals , the Government is hell-bent on continuing its policy of forced amalgamation. There are nil grant figures for the University of New England, the University of Newcastle, the Newcastle CAE, the Armidale CAE, the Milperra CAE and a number of others. The explanation for this which the Minister gave on 23 September was that recurrent funds for those institutions concerned in amalgamation would be put into a national unallocated grant and that money would be released from that national unallocated fund only in the event that acceptable proposals for amalgamations were received by the end of this year. The implication is that if those amalgamation proposals are not received there will be no money. It is a kind of 'or else' proposition. It is clear evidence that the Government is determined to pursue these amalgamations, these shotgun weddings, with a single- mindedness which it should apply to national problems that are far more pressing than the amalgamations of these institutions.

I note that in the technical and further education sector there is a cut in overall funding, capital funding is down by $4m and there is no increase in equipment funding. These are disgraceful decisions, especially in view of the need for refurbishing and re-equipment in the TAFE sector. There is no doubt that as long as this Government remains in office technical and further education will remain the poor relation.

The Opposition for some time has been drawing attention to the problems flowing from falling tertiary participation rates and pointing to the fact that the percentage of final year secondary students proceeding directly to tertiary education has fallen quite dramatically in recent years. Of the 15 to 19-year- old age group, which covers those at school and those in their first year of tertiary studies, Australia-wide, 38.5 per cent is engaged in full time education. This means that the remaining 61.5 per cent is on the labour market. By international comparison this is a very high figure indeed. In Australia 61.5 per cent of that age group is on the labour market. In Japan the figure is only 24 per cent, in the United States of America it is 28 per cent, in Canada it is 33 per cent and in Sweden it is 34 per cent. Yet in Australia the figure is 61.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like New Zealand and the United Kingdom.

—Exactly. The contribution of falling tertiary participation rates and low secondary retention rates to the current record levels of youth unemployment is quite obvious. In Japan 88.1 per cent of 17-year-olds are still full time school students. In Australia the figure is 34.8 per cent. I point out to the House that this is a national average. Clearly, schools with low retention rates are not evenly spread. Obviously, they are found in regions with the highest rates of youth unemployment. Where in the Bill is there any provision to raise retention and participation rates? The question of recurrent funding for non- government schools has been covered in detail by my colleagues the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) and the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child ) but I point out that if this Government had any commitment to raising resource levels in under-resourced non-government schools it would take the obvious step. It has had seven years in office. The reason that the position has not improved in the needier schools is the policy of this Government to make a present to over-resourced schools, those which are operating at 180 per cent of government school levels. Those schools do not need funding. At the same time the Government is prepared to tolerate a situation in which the neediest non- government schools are still as badly off as they were seven years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The approach of the Opposition this afternoon has been negative to say the least. The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free) exemplified that attitude. His attitude, particularly in relation to non-government schools, is the attitude of a large number of members of the Opposition. They fail to tell the truth in relation to this matter. I said that the Opposition's approach this afternoon was negative. It was negative because Opposition members failed to point out and acknowledge that support for the recurrent resource standards in government and non-government schools throughout Australia has never been higher in the history of this country. The Opposition has failed to acknowledge that very important fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity also to indicate on behalf of all those people who serve on the Schools Commission the fact that they are dedicated educationalists who come from a variety of fields within the education sector-the teachers federations, the various parent groups, both government and non-government, people who serve in the State education systems throughout the Commonwealth and others who are in the employ of the Commonwealth. I deplore the suggestion that has been made that those people are not acting independently. On their behalf I call on the Opposition to apologise, in particular the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) and the honourable member for Macquarie who reflected not only on the corporate body of the Australian Schools Commission but also on each member of that Commission. The honourable member for Macquarie and the honourable member for Henty both made reference to the fact that this Government provides the Schools Commission with prescriptive guidelines. Those were the words used in particular by the honourable member for Macquarie. I inform him- apparently he is not aware of it-that the first government to provide such guidelines to the Schools Commission was a government of his political colour; the Whitlam Government.

The main purpose of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill is to provide funds for primary and secondary schools in the States and the Northern Territory next year. The detailed distribution of these funds for 1983 is in accordance with the recommendations of the report of the Schools Commission on the 1983 guidelines all of which-I emphasise the words 'all of which'-have been accepted by the Government. The Bill also provides additional funds for 1982 programs to help meet unanticipated cost increases arising from recent teacher salary determinations. In providing an estimated total of $1,241m for schools programs in 1983 the Government confirms the high priority accorded to education and to the schools in particular. In difficult budgetary conditions the total allocation for schools has been increased by nearly 4 per cent in real terms over 1982 to a level higher than in any previous year. It represents a continuation of the Commonwealth's support in providing the best possible education for all Australian school children.

There has demonstrably been no reduction in Commonwealth support for government schools. The $567m allocated for these schools in 1983 includes a 2 per cent increase in real terms in general recurrent funding to help meet running costs and maintenance of capital programs in real terms. These additional allocations for government schools were consistent with the advice given to the Government by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. As I said earlier, support for recurrent resource standards in government schools has never been higher in our history. The Government's policies and programs are also intended to help in supporting the provision of an adequate education for those chidren whose parents choose to send them to non-government schools. The Commission has reported that the great majority of non-government schools are operating at resource standards significantly below those of the government school system. The Government has given special attention to these low resource schools in its funding programs.

Since 1976 the subsidy rate for schools classified by the Commission as most needy has been increased from 31 per cent to 33 per cent in secondary and primary schools to 38 per cent of average government school standard costs. In 1983 the rate for these schools will be increased further to 40 per cent. Indeed some 95 per cent of the total increase in general recurrent grants to non- government schools in 1983 will be directed to the low resource schools in greatest need.

It should not be forgotten that resource standards in non-government schools have risen markedly due to the combined efforts of State and Commonwealth governments and private contributions. Government systems would now have total recurrent resource levels on average equivalent to those of non-government schools classified by the Commonwealth Schools Commission as being in Group 1- that is, with the highest resource standards. It seems hardly necessary to point out yet again that it is misleading to look at Commonwealth funding patterns for schools in isolation of the funds provided from the States and other sources. The Government's decisions are made on the basis of a complimentary, Commonwealth-State funding relationship which has been very productive in leading to improved standards in schools overall. When total resources of State and Commonwealth governments are considered on an average per pupil basis total government funding of pupils at government schools is now more than double that for children in non-government schools.

I outlined clearly in my second reading speech the greatly improved facilities and resources that are being provided by this Government to Australian schools, both government and non-government. I outlined also the very real increase in expenditure for technical and further education. One of the Opposition members earlier described TAFE as being the poor relation of the education system. Indeed, technical and further education was the poor relation of the education system until this Government took office. That has since been corrected.

The first four amendments establish the legal position regarding the interest of the Commonwealth where its grants have been used for the purchase, wholly or in part, of major assets by non-government school authorities and the requirements regarding recovery of grants in the event of disposal or changes in the purpose of such assets. In cases such as a non-government school ceasing operation, there has been no formal legal capacity to initiate recovery action on behalf of the Commonwealth, although there have been administrative arrangements for this purpose. It is not possible constitutionally for the Commonwealth to take direct recovery action in its own right as this would need to be done under the conditions of the States grants legislation and with the co -operation of the States.

Although there have been no past instances which would have necessitated the Commonwealth requiring a State to take recovery action, such instances could occur if conditions in agreements between a State and a school authority concerning the Commonwealth's conditions for grants are not fulfilled, for example, because of the closure of a school. Non-government school authorities have been consulted on this matter and have not objected to the principle of recovery of grants. The Government is therefore seeking to amend the legislation , firstly, to specify that the conditions of grants for major assets apply for a maximum of 20 years, with any repayments based on a 5 per cent per annum reduction in the value of the grant for each remaining year; secondly, to specify that major assets include purchases of land, buildings and equipment costing more that $30,000 in 1983; and thirdly, to require States to enter into contracts with recipients so that the Commonwealth conditions of grants are met and, in the event that they are not, to initiate recovery action if requested to do so by the Commonwealth Minister.

These provisions largely reflect current administrative arrangements and therefore do not constitute any significant departure from existing policy. While it is not intended that there be any retrospective changes to the conditions of existing grants, it is the Commonwealth's intention that the broad principles which are to be established in the legislation will apply in respect of the administration of past grants. Under these arrangements, the Commonwealth does not require any proprietary interest or trust in property purchased, constructed or brought into being as a result of expenditure by a non-government school authority of payments it has accepted from a State pursuant to Commonwealth grants. The Commonwealth is consulting with the States to seek their full co-operation in administering these arrangements. The Government has also decided that these arrangements will be applied to corresponding grants for non-government schools in the Australian Capital Territory from 1983.

The new clauses I have moved to be inserted after clause 67 of this Bill change the funding for 1982 of the new arrivals element of the English as a Second Language Program from a fixed allocation to a per capita basis, consistent with the 1983 funding arrangements in the Bill. The purpose of this amendment is to overcome the problem of uncertainty about the level of funding required for the final number of eligible students enrolled in courses in 1982. This means that the final cost of this element of the program would be determined by the actual number of students. Current enrolment trends indicate that enrolments could reach about 14,000 in 1982, an increase of 2,000 students on the original estimate, which would cost an additional $1.6m at the 1982 rate of $795 per student. This additional commitment indicates the importance which the Government attaches to the provision of intensive English language programs for non-English speaking students who are newly arrived in Australia and will ensure that all eligible newly arrived students who enrol in government and non- government schools in 1982 can receive special English as a second language course. The total financial commitment for 1982 is now estimated at some $11.1m, in 1982 outturn prices. I commend these amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose these amendments, and I rise simply to make a couple of points. It was very slick of the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) to conclude from my colleagues' criticisms of the Commonwealth Schools Commission that in fact they were attacking the character of the individual members of the Commission. Of course they were not doing that. What they were referring to was that the Schools Commission has, regrettably, become a somewhat compliant organisation over the last few years. That has been largely influenced by the kinds of instructions the Government has sent the Commission in the form of its prescriptive guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has nothing but respect for the members of the Commission, although we do say that they should have protested more loudly and more frequently about the effects of the Government's guidelines on schools throughout Australia. Members of the Commission have not stood up to the Government. Of course, the Government is happy with that situation, but the Opposition is not. The Minister says that this Government was not the first to send guidelines to the Commission. Of course it was not, and of course it is a legitimate role for governments to tell the Commission how much money it has to spend, how much money the Government is prepared to allocate for the Schools Commission's programs. It is an entirely different matter for the Government then to tell the Commission how, in precise terms, it should spend that money. That is the difference between the guidelines which were provided for the Schools Commission under the Labor Government and those provided under this Government.

I want to refer to one other matter because the Minister for Aviation is getting more enthusiastic about using statistics deceptively. He said that he used certain statistics to indicate that the Government's commitment to the government school sector had never been higher, or words to that effect. Regrettably, the Minister apparently did not read the table I showed him earlier in the debate, which indicates that in real per capita terms the decline over the last six years has been 12 per cent in the recurrent programs going to government schools, whilst at the same time there has been a very substantial increase to non-government schools. The Minister certainly did not address what was the central burden of my remarks. It is fine for the Government to provide assistance to the non-government school sector. That was something which the past Labor Government embraced. What we cannot understand and what the Government did not answer was why it is that it has given such substantial and unjustified increases to the schools that are already doing very well and operating, in some cases, at twice the level of the government schools whilst the gap continues to exist between the poorest schools in Australia and the government school standard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The gap is narrowing.

—It has narrowed in the sense that a few years ago the schools were operating at 60 per cent; they are now operating at 75 per cent. The Minister has to acknowledge that the gap that existed in 1972 still exists. There is still a 25 per cent gap between the government school standard and the poorest schools in Australia.
—Both have higher standards.

—I am not denying that for a moment. I have accepted that government school standards have improved and that non-government schools standards have improved, on average, but there is a large number of very needy non-government schools in this country and, on average the gap remains where it was 10 years ago, despite the increases in expenditure. The Government has to focus on that problem and abandon this idiocy of having as of right grants which completely ignore the individual needs, the urgent needs of students in non-government schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

In indicating the Government's assent to these amendments I make it absolutely clear that the Government agrees to them only because there are other parts of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) which must come into effect to provide essential benefits to deserving people. It does not agree with what the Senate has decided in relation to these amendments. I give notice that the Government will be reintroducing these provisions as a separate Bill in due course.

The amendments made by the Senate relate to the tax put on the private health insurance funds in Victoria by the Victorian Government. The clauses in the original Bill were intended to prevent State governments levying such taxes on private health insurance funds. It is the intention of the Government to proceed with separate legislation to give effect to those provisions at a later stage but, in the interests of the special provisions for disadvantaged persons which have to come into effect very soon, for the moment the Government accepts the Senate's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion of the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton). We have indicated throughout the debate, both in this Chamber and in the other place, that we would accept all parts of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and would facilitate its rapid passage except for the two clauses relating to the cost-efficient Victorian health levy. We argued in this place and in the other place that those clauses were a complete tack; the clauses disallowing the levy had nothing to do with the rest of the Bill and had nothing to do with the substance of the Bill. They had nothing to do with the Budget and were therefore in no sense Budget legislation. They were not even mentioned in the Budget Speech. Had the Government had any sense of parliamentary propriety it would have introduced these disallowance provisions in a separate Bill. I am glad it is now going to do that. It was a pity that that was not recognised beforehand. The Government simply has tried to blackmail and bluff the Opposition in the other place but that blackmail and that bluff has failed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) in congratulating the Government for accepting the amendments. It played 'chicken' with the Opposition in the Senate and lost. One of the most important aspects of this situation is that it quite clearly demonstrates that the Government has finally realised that if it went to an election now it would be decimated. It has realised that it cannot just keep on saying to the Senate that it has to pass every bit of legislation otherwise an election will be called. Surely it is clear to any political observer in this country that, the way things are at present, any government would be defeated if it went to an election at this time. I congratulate the Government for finally realising that and accepting the amendments.
—The Government knew about it. It has not told the Prime Minister yet .
—I hope the Government pulls on an election this year because I am quite sure we would win very easily.
—Is that a challenge?
—Yes. I am quite happy to challenge the Government. I am prepared to suffer the respective increases and decreases in votes in the electorates of Prospect and Dundas.
—What clause is this?

—This is the clause on which the Government has caved in on the question of allowing the Victorian Government to impose an across-the-board charge against registered health insurance organisations rather than, as far as hospital attendances at casualty out-patient departments are concerned, charging for individual hospital attendances. It is extremely difficult for the public hospitals of all the States to chase the money owing to them. When people come into casualty they are distraught. They come in following an accident or because of acute problems. Obviously they do not carry their medical insurance books around with them. Many of them do not even know for sure what fund they belong to. It is then left to the hospitals to chase that money. Funds are behaving in a rather cavalier fashion, all over Australia not just in Victoria. I hope that the New South Wales Government will follow the example of the Victorian Government and introduce similar legislation. The Victorian Government has taken the right step in imposing that charge, which averages the costs attributable for hospital out-patients attendances, casualty departments and so on, rather than the hospitals going to the trouble of carrying out the clerical work involved and losing a large percentage of fees payable by the private organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst in theory one should congratulate the Government on accepting the amendments, it is important to remember that they were originally Australian Labor Party amendments in this Chamber. The amendments were supported by enough honourable senators in the Senate to enable them to be passed. I urge the Government to accept amendments which will be moved on other legislation which comes before the Chamber today to show that it has an understanding that the Opposition is not trying to stop the Government from functioning but is trying to improve quite significantly the way in which it functions. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I should make some response to the points made by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman). If there had been any machinery that I could use to reinstate these clauses and put them back through the Senate before it rises tonight I would have done so. However it was not possible mechanically to do that without jeopardising some very important benefits for disadvantaged persons which have to be introduced next week. That is the reason why the Bill has not had its clauses reinstated. I think I also ought to make quite clear to the Committee the basis on which the Government is going to insist on putting these clauses back into a separate Bill and to insist that State governments do not levy taxes on private health insurance funds. Basically, if a State wishes to run its hospital system in any particular way that is a matter for the State.

SPEECH.PARA: In September of last year the Government introduced new arrangements for funding State hospitals. It abandoned in all States but two 50-50 cost sharing agreements which I would call buck passing agreements. Under these schemes the Federal Government provided 50 per cent of the funds for running hospitals systems in the States. As a result the States were very reluctant to accept the basic managerial and planning decisions of their hospital systems. Those changes made it absolutely clear that the financial as well as the managerial responsibility for running the hospital systems lay with the States. The States have always had the constitutional responsibility for running hospital systems. But while there was no clear-cut financial responsibility to go with that managerial responsibility they did not, in general, bother to manage their hospitals properly. Whenever there were further demands for additional services in various areas, instead of looking at the overall scheme for planning in those hospital systems, they said that the Commonwealth should provide more money.

I believe that the changes of last year were very satisfactory ones. Since I became Minister for Health I have been determined not to interfere in the managerial responsibilities of the State Ministers. I realise that they have had very difficult problems during the transitional phase of accepting this full responsibility. There have been arguments over funding amounts at the end of the financial year. These were very difficult problems to resolve. There were arguments on both sides and I am certainly not one to claim that all wisdom lies here in Canberra. There were difficulties in resolving these financial arrangements and, of course, they became linked with the general financial provisions between the Commonwealth and the States which were hammered out at the Premiers Conference. Some States believe that they were unfairly done by; other States believe that they did better. Inevitably there is some form of conflict in an allocation of resources of this kind. But whatever those arrangements are-they are argued out at successive Premiers Conferences-the principle of the States having a financial as well as a managerial responsibility for their hospital systems, I think, is a very good one.

In Victoria the State Government decided-I must say without giving any notice to me; the announcements were made before I had had any opportunity to examine them-to levy a tax on private insurance funds. The State Government can do what it likes with regard to the operation of its out-patient services and its charges for them, provided that it does so with its own funds. For example, the Queensland Government-this matter has been raised a number of times-chooses to allow people into public hospitals without applying any means test. That is a choice for the Queensland Government. If I were making the choice I would not follow that path, but we have made a clear-cut decision that the States can spend their money as they wish. If Queensland, unlike all the other States, does not wish to means test public hospital patients it can do so but it does make up the extra cost of doing that out of its State taxation revenues.

If Mr Roper, the Victorian Minister of Health-I fully understand the difficulties he has in funding his hospital systems and making up for wrong planning decisions that have perhaps been made in the past-wants additional money he should make it up out of State taxation revenues, which he can do. He can argue for more money at the various conferences with the Commonwealth. What we objected to was a levy on the contributors to the private health insurance funds in lieu of making charges at out-patient departments. Again I make it quite clear that if he had decided to stop levying the individual charges at the out-patient departments and paid for it out of Victorian tax revenues we would have had no quarrel with him. There would have been no problem about that at all .

We do have a constitutional and legislative responsibility for health insurance under the Health Insurance Act. I have to be concerned about the reserves in the private insurance funds. It is not acceptable to have State governments levying taxes on those contributors' funds which do not relate specifically to the services rendered. In this case Mr Roper levied the private funds in Victoria to an amount in addition to that required to provide these free services in the out -patient departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is an amount which you decided on.

—No, it is more than that; it is in excess of that amount. There is some argument as to how much more it is over what the private funds think it is. They think it is a lesser amount but the amount levied by the State Government is even more than that which the Commonwealth believed it might get under that program. That is the basis of our concern about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have a concern for those pensioners who, although entitled to free hospital care, have decided to insure themselves under hospital tables in order to have choice of doctor. Those people who are already paying an additional burden for that privilege-it is their right to do so-find themselves having to pay the additional levy imposed by the Victorian Government. That is another unfortunate by-product of the Victorian proposals.

All these things taken into account, we believe that we cannot let this matter rest. We would not have let it rest tonight had the machanics been available to us to send the legislation back to the Senate with the amendments reinstated. We will be arguing once again with a separate Bill to ask the Senate to re-examine this matter. I shall certainly be arguing my case and the Government's case on this matter. I also hope to make it clear that it is not my intention to make Mr Roper's job any more difficult than it is. State Ministers have massive responsibilities for delivery systems. The managerial problems in those systems- because of some years of neglect and I think partly because of the old financing arrangements-are immense. I have spent a lot of time, since I have been in this job, coming to understand those problems as well as our own. Of course I do have a responsibility for delivery services within the Australian Capital Territory and therefore a very direct interest. I am not without sympathy for Mr Roper's overall plight but we are attempting to preserve the integrity of contributors' funds and to assert our control over the health insurance arrangements. That is why for the moment we are accepting these amendments but we will be asking the Senate once again to consider them within a fresh Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) so blithely passes off responsibility to the Victorian Government and other State governments. I well remember the Commonwealth insisting on a four beds per thousand public hospital funding system and the Victorian Minister of Health writing to members from Victoria-where that system did not apply-who were insisting on the four beds per thousand. They included the then Prime Minister of Australia. The Prime Minister at the time publicly condemned the Victorian Government because that system might have affected his electorate. When the Minister talks about people taking responsibility he must look at both sides of the coin. If the Minister wants to apply rules, sanctions and restrictions I suggest he should have the guts to stand up for what he does and support it in his own areas.

TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT BILL 1982 [No. 2]
Consideration resumed from 27 October.
Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, pages 6 and 7, omit sub-clause (12).

This amendment is to delete sub-clause (12) of clause 3 of the Bill. That sub- clause provides that no liability to recoupment tax arises where, after sale to the promoter, the company was unsuccessfully entered into a tax avoidance scheme which, objectively viewed, could reasonably have been expected to succeed in eliminating the company tax liability. Provided the tax arrangement was not part of a subsequent stripping operation which rendered the company unable to pay its tax, this legislation will not operate to recoup unpaid company tax in such circumstances. This proposal was not part of the earlier Bill introduced a month ago but has been included in the revised Bill as a concession to the tax dodgers . The rationale for it is apparently that in such cases there was supposedly no element of fraud because the company was stripped on the assumption that the tax avoidance scheme had legally wiped out the company's tax liability. When that scheme subsequently fails so that a tax liability does apply to the company which has no funds to meet it because it has been stripped, the Government now argues that the vendors and promoters should be exempt from recoupment tax because when the company was stripped it was supposedly reasonable for those involved to assume that the action was legal.

The Opposition opposes this on two grounds. They are conceptual and practical grounds. On conceptual grounds we find the supposed logic that lies behind this sub-clause absolutely extraordinary. It is basic to realise that the whole of this legislation will not apply where a company entered a successful tax avoidance scheme after sale; that is, there will be no recoupment tax process in such cases because in those cases there is no company tax liability which remains unpaid. So, in all cases where profits were stripped under the guise of a successful tax avoidance scheme, the vendors and promoters are laughing all the way to the bank and the Government is making no attempt to wipe the smile from their faces.

In addition, this sub-clause says that if the Commissioner of Taxation challenges the tax avoidance scheme that was used, fights it through the courts and eventually wins his argument that the tax avoidance scheme purported to apply was not legitimate, he still will not be able to collect the tax. Where tax is owed by the company but it has no funds, this sub-clause will act to prevent any assessment being made on the vendors, shareholders or promoters who benefited from the pre-tax stripping operation to pay that tax. What an absolutely extraordinary situation this is. Not only is there no application of this legislation where a tax avoidance scheme was successful, which demonstrates that accusations of retrospectivity are rather wide of the mark, but in addition there is to be no application of it when they are unsuccessful. Such legislation makes an absolute mockery of the work of the Australian Taxation Office. Having worked to strike down a supposed tax avoidance scheme by proving that it was not within the law at that time, the Government is now going to step in and say ' Even though this was part of a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme and the vendors, shareholders and promoters all profited substantially from this arrangement at the expense of other taxpayers, no attempt is to be made to collect tax from them because they could reasonably have been expected to believe that the tax avoidance scheme would work'. What a sell-out that is.

The Government is saying that if the Taxation Office strikes down a supposed Curran scheme, for instance, as recently happened in the New South Wales Supreme Court, and the company was not stripped under a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme, then the tax obligation will apply. However, if the company was involved in a pre-tax stripping operation, a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme, and so has no assets because of the stripping operation, the Government says that it will not bother to collect tax from the vendors, shareholders and promoters who benefited from it. This is an extraordinarily anomalous situation in which the Government is seeking to protect one particular category of intending tax dodgers-that is, those who were involved in a straw company scheme which included a purported tax avoidance arrangement. Those who entered into exactly the same kind of arrangement without the straw company element remain liable. This is a quite ridiculous situation which must be enormously damaging to the morale of the Taxation Office. The Office is trying to strike down tax avoidance schemes under existing law and when it is successful the Government says that it cannot collect the tax consequently owing in the case of a company involved in a straw company scheme. What a great incentive that is to the diligent pursuit of tax dodgers!

We can see no valid conceptual reason for this sub-clause. The argument that it is appropriate because technically fraud was not involved in the situation in which it applies ignores the fact that in the same situation applying to a non- stripped company where again it could be strictly argued that no fraud applied, the tax liability would remain and be collectable. Therefore, it is impossible to escape the conclusion that this sub-clause acts to discriminate in favour of participants in the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme as against non-participants in that scheme.

As regards practical considerations, we are appalled at the potential loophole that this sub-clause will create. As I understand it, the Taxation Office has so far identified 4,600 companies as being involved in pre-tax profits stripping and having unpaid company tax liability. Of those 4,600, about 700 have engaged in a purported tax avoidance scheme. Some of these schemes may eventually prove to be valid. The Taxation Office in challenging them may find that some are upheld, but most of them are expected to be struck down. However, the effect of sub-clause (12) will be to ensure that even though the Taxation Office and the courts strike them down the promoters and the vendor shareholders involved in these companies will not have to pay tax. Thus, no tax will be collected from up to 15 per cent of the companies so far involved.

The proportion of tax that will be lost because of this incredible exemption may well be substantially in excess of 15 per cent. This is because, as we understand it, the tax avoidance scheme purportedly employed by many of these 700 companies is a Curran scheme, which scheme enables vast amounts of tax to be dodged through artificial losses on share trading. If many of these supposed Curran schemes were now to be struck down under existing law, a lot more than 15 per cent of the tax that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was expecting to recoup may not now be collected.

The Treasurer's most recent estimate of tax involved in this recoupment operation is $580m, as I recall it. If this sub-clause is passed the amount gathered is likely to be far less than that. This will make a massive hole in the amount of money which is supposedly to be recouped under this legislation. A 15 per cent loss would reduce it by $87m, but for the reason I have mentioned the loss of potential revenue could be far in excess of 15 per cent and probably will be well over $100m. Thus this sub-clause is utterly without merit. It is thoroughly unjustified in conceptual terms because it involves discrimination as tax dodgers in favour of those involved in the bottom-of-the harbour schemes and it will lead to massive losses of potential revenue from the recoupment tax exercise. This legislation was already weak in that it ignored a substantial amount of revenue lost through bottom-of-the harbour schemes, but this sub- clause ensures that it will be much weaker. It makes a mockery of the Government 's supposed determination to get back the funds which have been stolen from public revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say in answer to what has been put to the Committee that the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) gave the game away when he said that technically fraud was not involved. That is so. The conceptual problem that he referred to is no conceptual problem at all if we look to the consideration that fraud was not involved and was not intended to be involved. That is the distinction between that kind of situation and other kinds of situations, and that is why those who did not intend, and who can on objective evidence be determined not to have intended, to commit a fraud on the revenue should be exempted. If the honourable member cannot understand that, he does not understand the essential difference between avoidance and evasion, between legality and illegality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about the matter raised by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I think one of the problems we have is that the whole question of tax avoidance has become blurred by the sort of view he put. It is as if there were something quite good, quite respectable, about tax avoidance as opposed to tax evasion. In relation to this part of the Bill, we now find that where companies enter into a tax avoidance scheme-it is in the explanatory memorandum-after sale to a promoter, with a reasonable expectation that the scheme would be successful but which scheme subsequently fails, the companies, the vendors and the promoters associated with that scheme are exempt from the legislation. As was outlined by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), that is an extraordinary situation having regard to what we have heard about this legislation. It has taken long enough for this Bill to get in here, with the Government making concessions to people on its side of the chamber who were disturbed about it for all sorts of strange reasons. The attitude of those people came out very clearly in the speech of the honourable member for North Sydney. It may not be a bad idea for the honourable member for North Sydney to understand that the sort of mentality he is displaying tonight is quite extraordinary and is certainly not good for the community. I referred yesterday to a seminar that was held in Melbourne, following the Government's insertion of Part IVA into the Income Tax Assessment Act.
—You said that last night.
—Yes, but the honourable member did not understand it.
—I heard it; I understand it.

—In view of what the honourable member said tonight, it is quite plain that he may have heard it yesterday but he just does not understand it. He was saying tonight the same sort of thing that was said at that seminar where there was criticism of his Government on the grounds that the penalties under Part IV were too high. It would not be a bad idea if the honourable member were to listen very carefully. The reasons the penalities were too high were stated in the seminar papers as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I myself think that that maximum penalty is too high. It equates artifical but honest arrangements with fraudulent and dishonest steps taken by taxpayers. It blurs the distinction completely between what is clever and tricky on the one hand and what is dishonest and cheating on the other. Not everybody might agree that there should be a distinction but to me there is a distinction between saying 'That is what I've done, I say it works, I think it's clever, it may not be playing fair by the community but that's a different matter' and saying alternatively 'I'm just going to put this money into my pocket'.

That is the sort of view that the honourable member for North Sydney put tonight in answer to what the honourable member for Gellibrand said in relation to this clause. It is another indication of the appalling inability of this Government really to take on this issue and to say: 'If the system is being ripped off in this way it is no different from where we have decided that there will be recoupment'. To exempt that sort of situation outlined by the honourable member for Gellibrand tonight is utterly without excuse and can be explained only by the appalling attitude which was indicated by the honourable member for North Sydney, which is the sort of stuff we get from the tax avoidance industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fail to understand the Opposition's concern about this matter. It is simply criticising the Bill for something which it is not and which it was never intended it should be in the first place. This legislation is concerned with the recoupment of outstanding company tax lost through fraudulent and illegal evasion by way of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. In simple terms, it employs a technique of identifying a company which has found itself at the bottom of the harbour, tracing backwards and working upwards. All that this legislation and particularly clause 3 (12) do is to specify the terms that this legislation is all about. It is simply saying that if these hitherto legal tax avoidance schemes are struck down, certainly they will not be caught up in this legislation but they will be caught up under the Income Tax Assessment Act. There are plenty of other mechanisms that the Commissioner of Taxation can use, has used and will continue to use in regard to tax avoidance schemes that are struck down. We are not talking in this legislation about tax avoidance schemes; we are talking about fraudulent, illegal evasion. Honourable members opposite are criticising the Bill for not doing something which it was never intended to do in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly in connection with this matter. One of the points I want to make in connection with clause 3 (12) is essentially one of the points that I made when this legislation was being discussed yesterday. I emphasise the claim has been made that this legislation is concerned with the recoupment of tax which was avoided under various types--
—Evaded.

—Evaded; exactly. It is the recoupment of tax which was evaded. I am indebted to the honourable member for North Sydney for emphasising that word-'evaded'. The point is that if the tax was evaded at the time it was evaded there must have then been laws which made that evasion of the tax illegal. There must have been laws at the time which indicated that the operators of the schemes were commiting an illegal act. If that is so, it means that this legislation we are considering now is not necessary. If this legislation is necessary it means we are not dealing with tax that could not be collected under various evasion practices but we are in fact dealing with tax which was not paid as a result of various types of avoidance practices. There is no other explanation.
—No, no!

—Members of the Government can try to twist themselves around this matter whichever way they like. It was the honourable member for North Sydney who drew attention to the distinction between evasion and avoidance. I emphasise again that evasion is an illegal scheme; avoidance is a legal scheme. If the legislation now before us is concerned with evasion practices those schemes were illegal then. If they were illegal at the time there were laws at the time which made them illegal. I do not know how thick in the skull people have to be before that point sinks in. If the point I have just made is correct and it cannot be refuted, let us put this particular clause and sub-clause into that context. The point about this particular sub-clause is that it exempts from paying recoupment tax those scheme operators who entered into a tax avoidance scheme, believing that it would be successful-of course the main type of tax avoidance scheme they entered into was the Curran scheme-and who stripped the assets of the company which, under the provisions of this legislation and the way in which these schemes have been recognised, would have been an act of evasion because the tax which they had evaded paying could not have been paid since there were no assets left in the company to pay it. The Government cannot have it both ways. If the avoidance scheme was unsuccessful the company was left with no assets to pay the tax. Such people will then be exempt from recoupment action under this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not matter very much whether the process of stripping the company of assets was supported by an unsuccessful tax avoidance scheme because in both cases there must have been evasion practices involved. If there were evasion practices involved as members on the Government side including the Treasurer (Mr Howard) claim-there must have been a law at that time which made those practices illegal. If that is so why were those laws not applied? Why is it necessary then --

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell you.

—I hope we get an answer. Why is it necessary for the Treasurer and the Government to belatedly bring in this legislation against evasion practices? I emphasise again in conclusion that if they were evasion practices, then they were against the law. If they were against the law there were laws which made them illegal. So let us have no more of this nonsense. The point I made yesterday and the point which I repeat now is that the Government has retreated from the absurd position it adopted before. The Government has tried to claim that this is not really retrospective legislation because we are collecting tax which was illegally evaded. If it was illegally evaded there were laws then which should have been applied. This Government did not apply them. The Treasurer and other representatives of the Government knew as early as 1978 about these practices, these evasion practices against which there must have been legal sanctions, and no action was taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I should rise on two counts. The first is that the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) has obviously learnt a lot in the last 24 hours from a number of speakers on this side who have been at pains to point out that this legislation ought not to have been necessary. It is very helpful to know that a member of the Labor Party is beginning to understand.
—I support the legislation; I do not support lies being told about it.
—If the honourable member supports the legislation then he does not support what he has just said.
—He would not know the difference.

—That is right. The other point I want to make is that clause 3 sub -clause (12) is a matter of faith by the Government on the basis that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his 25 July statement made it quite clear that this legislation was meant to catch cases of the nature of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. It was well known when the first draft of the Bill came out and we examined it that there were many other cases that would be caught, cases which would extend well outside the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. That was never the intention of the Government. If that had been the intention of the Government then I should think we would want to be debating that quite separately under a separate Bill. This has brought the Bill into line with the original intention.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that I want to flag a reservation which I still have and which I think one or two honourable members might still have in relation to this clause. I hope the Treasurer might comment on this matter in his summing up. There is a fear among some people, as I understand it, that clause 3 (12) (c) may possibly have the effect of defeating the whole clause through its own wording. It refers to the relevant scheme being part of a stripping arrangement and if that stripping arrangement was a bona fide tax minimisation scheme outside the scope of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, it is just possible, I am advised, that the intent covered in 3 (12) (a), (b) and (d) of excluding cases where there was no purpose for being in the position of not being able to pay tax, might be defeated by 3 (12) (c).

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that again?
—The honourable member wants me to start again?
—Yes.

—All right. If we read clause 3 (12), paragraphs (a) (b) and (d) it clearly follows the line that if there were a purpose for a person entering into a scheme of the nature covered in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act then that person would be caught; but, if that person did not enter into a scheme for that purpose that person would not be caught. Clause 3 (12) (c) would appear to make it possible that if a person entered into a scheme which was a bona fide tax minimisation scheme that person could still be caught under this provision. It looks to me to be self-cancelling. I think it is something that needs to be re- examined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not accept the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). I make it clear to the Committee that clause 3 has not been inserted as a concession to the tax dodgers-the great, flamboyant catch-cry of the Opposition in this debate . As the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) pointed out, this clause has been inserted to make sure that the intention of the Government is given effect to in this legislation. It is as simple as that. Throughout all of the public debate on this legislation the Government has sought to draw a distinction between using legislation of this kind to recoup unpaid tax, which was the produce of an arrangement that had a fraudulent element from all other kinds of avoidance arrangements. The Government has drawn a very clear distinction. I know the Opposition does not believe we should make any distinction. The Opposition would use this type of legislation in respect of anything it could lay its hands on.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members are saying yes. I know they would do that. They have made that perfectly clear. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) has made it clearer than anybody else, and I am indebted to him for his interjection. It reminds me of his contribution last night. All along we have said that in effect a trigger of fraud had to be involved in order that this Bill should come into operation. Our policy objective has been to get a situation in which that trigger of fraud existed. The legislation reaches out to collect that evaded tax from those who enjoyed the financial benefit of the tax evasion. That is why this amendment is necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing I wish to say is that one would imagine, from listening to the honourable member for Gellibrand, that the effect of this clause is to frustrate all the attempts of the Commissioner of Taxation to strike at tax avoidance arrangements. All this clause does is to make it certain that the provisions of this Bill do not apply to those arrangements. It does not in any way hobble the Commissioner of Taxation from fighting pre-August 1977 Curran schemes under the provisions of the law that existed prior to August 1977, which he is very successfully doing, to the benefit of the revenue. I reject the suggestion of the Australian Labor Party that this in some way is a concession to the tax dodging industry. It is a concession to the original policy intention of the Government. If this provision had not been put in we would not be giving effect to the original policy intention of the Government. I want to make that perfectly clear.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro expressed some concern about the operation of this clause. Let me endeavour, in a very complex area, at the end of a long week, to try to respond to the technical question that the honourable member raised. As best as I can explain it to the honourable gentleman, the position is this: This sub-clause operates to take out of the provision of this Bill a situation in which, after the sale of shares, a company was put into an arrangement that might reasonably then have been regarded as an effective tax avoidance arrangement, provided that the arrangement was not part of a stripping arrangement entered into for the purpose of rendering the company unable to pay its liabilities. That is the intent. Provided all those tests are met the arrangement goes outside the purview of this legislation.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro drew attention to the provisions of sub- clauses (c) and (d) of this clause. I point out to him that the Bill does not contain an overriding purpose test, whereas the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act states that an arrangement entered into for the purpose or including the purpose of rendering a company unable to meet its tax liabilities is struck at by that legislation. So far as liability is concerned, under this Bill an objective test , not containing a subjective element of a purpose, is sufficient to attract liability under the Bill. Without the provision of sub-clauses (c) and (d) we could well have a situation in which although a dealing of the company, in association with or shortly after the company had been put into a legal tax avoidance arrangement, had the effect of leaving the company unable to pay its debts, it would not have been entered into for the purpose of leaving the company unable to pay its debts.

Let me instance this. The company may have been put into a legal tax avoidance arrangement, a loan may have been made by the company out of the then calculated remaining assets of the company, and that loan may have become, in the normal commercial course, irrecoverable. If the objective test were applied the company would have been rendered unable to pay its debts. Therefore we found it necessary to put in the purpose test. By doing that we effectively meet the original policy intention of the Government. I think it is important-the Government has not made any secret of the fact-that we sought to distinguish these taxation arrangements and therefore to support the use of legislation that we would not normally use, and we will not normally use in future, because of the particular nature of this practice.

The distinguishing feature on this occasion, as one of my colleagues called it, has been the trigger fraud. If this provision had not been put in, the legislation would have gone beyond the original policy announcement that I made on 25 July and beyond the repeated public justifications that have been made by the Government in respect of the legislation. Therefore this amendment is necessary. I emphasise again that in no way does this amendment affect the capacity of the Commissioner of Taxation to challenge tax avoidance arrangements under the law that operates in respect of those arrangements. The amendment is purely concerned with ensuring that this legislation recoups the produce of evaded taxation in arrangements where, clearly, there has at some stage been an element of fraud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found the explanation given by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to be totally unsatisfactory.
—It was a very good explanation.

—Let us see how he explains this: On the one hand he said that this clause will not limit the capacity of the Commissioner of Taxation to collect all the tax involved in the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and yet on the other hand he said quite clearly that a purposive clause was being introduced here-he then used this term-to establish the trigger of fraud. The fact is that under this clause a situation may arise in which a company, before it actually strips assets, may have been involved in a scheme which it believed to be a tax minimisation scheme but which was later not accepted as a valid tax minimisation scheme. Under that sort of arrangement such a company would be excluded from having to repay the tax involved in a bottom-of-the-harbour operation. I cannot see why, if someone had the intent or purpose of being involved in a tax minimisation scheme which was later rejected by the Commissioner and then there was a stripping of the company's assets, this should be sufficient to exclude that company from having to pay the recoupment tax. In fact, this clause, I put it to the Treasurer, is a back door way of introducing what many members opposite have wanted him to introduce-namely, an innocence provision.

SPEECH.PARA: With this clause many companies can plead that they were involved in the first instance in a tax minimisation process before they were actually stripped of their assets. I cannot understand why this clause is necessary if the aim of the legislation is to collect the maximum amount from all those schemes that went to the bottom of the harbour. If in fact we start to make substantial exceptions of this kind-the shadow Treasurer has mentioned this-up to 25 per cent of the total number of companies involved could be exempted under this provision. I do not see why this is necessary, especially in view of the fact that it may be possible for this provision to be interpreted by the courts in such a way that perhaps more than 25 per cent of those involved in these schemes may be able to claim under it. The Treasurer referred to the objective criterion and then talked about introducing a purposive criterion. There is absolutely no need for this clause or for a purposive criterion. If a company was stripped of its assets and went to the bottom of the harbour it should be required to pay, and that is it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) to clause 3 of the Bill on pages 6 and 7. He proposes to omit sub-clause (12). I reject the amendment. I think that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) have adequately described to the Committee this evening the purpose of sub-clause (12), which is to limit the intent of the legislation to cases where tax is evaded fraudulently and illegally. That is where I differ with the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous). The sub-clause has that purpose. I share the reservations that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro expressed concerning sub-clause (12) (c) when it is read in conjunction with clause 5 (1) (h) on page 11 of the Bill. I was reassured by the Treasurer's response to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. He said that in his view the sub-clause operates to take out of the legislation the situation when, after the sale, what is regarded as a legal scheme is left, provided it is not part of a stripping scheme which makes the company unable to pay its liabilities. The Treasurer said -I was reassured to hear this-that this meets the effective policy intent of the Government. As I see it, the Treasurer has confirmed that the sub-clause applies where there is an intention to strip, an illegality, a fraudulent purpose and fraudulent evasion. It may well be-I assume that the Treasurer takes this into account-that there are strips which are legal and commercial and are carried out for a purpose which perhaps is unrelated to tax or which could be part of a legal minimisation scheme. There may be a situation in which a strip is not avoidance or evasion.
—What is it then?

—It could well be a normal commercial transaction. As I also understand the Treasurer's explanation, where a company is able still to pay its liabilities, where there has been a strip which may well have been a minimisation scheme that is regarded as legal by the Commissioner of Taxation or the courts and where there is no illegal fraudulent purpose of a bottom-of-the- harbour nature-which is the target of the general intent of this legislation-the legislation will not apply. I take that explanation to mean that the combination of sub-clause (12) (c) and clause 5 (1) (h) means that there has to be an illegality of the nature described by the Treasurer. I have the reservation that was expressed by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro about the result that a combination of sub-clause (12) (c) and clause 5 (1) (h) could produce if there were no illegality or illegal purpose, but not a legitimate arrangement that could be said to have achieved the result referred to in clause 5 (1) (h). I am pleased that the Treasurer has stated the Government's policy of intent in relation to these clauses.

—Before I call the honourable member for Lowe I want to say that the Committee is proceeding in a rational and good fashion. This will continue, no doubt, as honourable members adopt a meeting of minds. I think this is very important in a technical Bill of this nature. Repetition is unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the nation is waiting and watching the national Parliament for action against bottom-of-the-harbour tax evaders, avoiders or rip -off merchants. The nation is looking for honesty and fairness but in this emasculated legislation there is no honesty and no fairness.
—I remind the honourable member that the Committee is debating clause 3. I ask him to keep his remarks close to that clause. This is not a second reading debate.

—I am indebted to you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Chairman. The Government has brought forward legislation which has the largest loophole I have ever seen in any legislation. An appalling number of tax evaders and avoiders will avoid their complete tax liabilities. We are told that the Government is serious in trying to recoup $580m of revenue misplaced or stolen from the public purse. The Opposition is pressing for the deletion of part of clause 3 which completely excludes from the ambit of this legislation those promoters who failed, the ones who were a little unlucky, and the companies on which tax is actually owing. The vendor-shareholders of these companies will not be included in the legislation, nor will the promoters. This is most unacceptable to the Opposition. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has moved an amendment which I completely support. I believe that if this legislation is to be seen by the public as necessary and workable it must include the people who are generally known as the bottom-of-the-harbour tax avoiders.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members are full of rhetoric and legal advice. I noted a comment by Mr I. C. F. Spry, Q.C., editor of the Australian Tax Review. He talked about the 1978 legislation which dealt with the Slutzkin schemes. That legislation brought in sections 50A to 50N of the Income Tax Assessment Act. He described these sections as 'complex to such an extent that they are hardly intelligible even to experts'. We have heard many Government members explain to us the Slutzkin schemes and what was done in this place to outlaw them. Mr Spry said that the Slutzkin schemes continue. Tonight we are debating legislation that the Liberal- National Party Government has put before the Parliament. Regrettably, it is being debated, even in Committee, in a rather emotive way. We have had near- hysteria as to whether tax has been lost through avoidance or through evasion. Nevertheless, the revenue is missing and it must be recovered. If the Committee had before it examples of which taxpayer took what amount of money out of the public revenue we and the nation would have a clearer appreciation of what was going on. If we even knew whether assessments were issued by the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to all these schemes we would have a clearer indication as to what is happening. It appears that the assessments have not been issued. It appears from other clauses of the Bill which will be debated later that these are to come. I am pleased to have an opportunity to make a short comment tonight . I fully support the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Gellibrand because I believe that without it there is an appalling loophole in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The points that have been made by Government speakers in the debate on this clause and the amendment proposed to it boil down to two things.
