They say, firstly, that sub-clause (12) as it stands, the sub- clause which we seek to delete, gives effect to the Government's intention in respect of this legislation and, secondly, that it does not hobble the Commissioner of Taxation in fighting Curran schemes. I wish to make some remarks in regard to those two very bare points that have been made by Government members in the debate. The first point I make relates to the policy intention of the Government. It is the contention of Opposition members that the Government's policy intention in respect of this legislation has been woefully inadequate; that the Government all along has not sought to get back hundreds of millions of dollars which have been lost under this scheme. That is our undeniable assertion . It is one which the Government has not sought to refute at any stage. Rather, it has knowledge that that is the situation; that it is not seeking to get back hundreds of millions of dollars. It has acknowledged this situation on the basis of trying to make a distinction between tax evasion and avoidance. It is doing so despite the fact that, in the one transaction in the bottom-of-the-harour scheme, a lot of revenue was lost which the Government carves up between what is fraudulent and termed evasion and what is not fraudulent and is termed avoidance . It seeks to get back only that part of the company tax which has been lost because it says that that was an evasion activity. But it does not seek to get back any tax which was lost, for instance, by way of personal income tax which it says was avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: By making that distinction, the Government gets itself into some awful messes. It has not addressed itself in any way to one of the basic anomalies which it has now created and which I mentioned earlier in the remarks I made about this sub-clause. That is the discrimination between participants in tax avoidance schemes which is now being built into the legislation. Of course, this discrimination between the two elements is a basic point that we are making in respect of this sub-clause.

Before I get to that point I wish to make one other point concerning the distinction between tax evasion and tax avoidance. Last year the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of this country told the nation that there was no difference between tax evasion and tax avoidance. I quoted what he said in my speech in the second reading debate. In May 1981 he said that, in effect, there was no moral difference between avoidance and evasion; that they were both equally culpable. We now have legislation brought in supposedly making that very clear distinction to ensure that a lot of the money that has been lost under this scheme does not have to be paid back. As I have said, in doing so the Government builds in this massive discrimination. This discrimination can be seen in a situation involving participation in a Curran scheme, where the participants in that scheme were not involved in a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme and where that Curran scheme is struck down. In that situation, a tax liability applies to that company. There is a liability to pay tax and the Commissioner of Taxation will proceed to get back that money. But if the participants have been involved in a bottom-of-the- harbour scheme, under this sub-clause the Commissioner of Taxation will not be able to pursue them for those funds. The Treasurer is shaking his head but that is the situation. He does not understand his own legislation.

In the situation where a tax avoidance scheme is struck down, a tax liability attaches to the company. There are no funds in the company because under the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme the funds have been stripped from it. Therefore, the company cannot pay the tax this legislation states that the taxation Commissioner cannot levy the shareholders or the promoters for that tax. So this Government is discriminating in favour of participants in the bottom-of-the- harbour scheme. That is an indefinible-

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable member for Higgins says that that is rubbish. He would not know about one aspect of this legislation. The reality is that the Government is building into this legislation undeniable discrimination with the intention of saying that if a comapny was involved in a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme and that company was participating in a tax avoidance scheme which failed then clearly a tax obligation applies to the company. But there are no funds to pay that tax because the company has been stripped of its assets. The Taxation Commissioner cannot now get that money back from the shareholders and the promoters. That is clear discrimination in favour of participants in the bottom- of-the-harbour schemes. What an absurd and ridiculous situation that is.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is building discrimination into this legislation which makes a mockery of its supposed intention to ensure that bottom-of-the-harbour participants do not get away with stolen funds-to use the term of the Prime Minister. This sub-clause is ensuring that some of those stolen funds remain very securely in the pockets of the beneficiaries of that process. That is what this legislation does. Nothing the Government has said overcomes the basic point which we are making in this regard-that is, that the Government has built in discrimination which is ridiculous in the extreme. In so doing, it has opened up a loophole which will mean that a substantial amount of money which should have been gathered from this legislation will not be so gathered. As I have said, something like 15 per cent of the companies involved have purported tax avoidance schemes associated with them, many of which it is hoped will be struck down. We sincerely hope that that is the case. But it will not matter a damn if they are struck down under this legislation. Still no money will be able to be recouped because there are no assets in the companies to which the tax liability can apply.

This sub-clause prevents the Taxation Commissioner from going after those people who stripped that money out of the company and who were the beneficiaries of the scheme. It is a ridiculous provision and one which presumably will cost the revenue well over $100m. The Treasurer's talk of $580m is nonsense. He will get back much less than that. The Treasurer is totally wrong in regard to a point he made earlier in reply to a question I asked concerning Curran schemes. We hope that the Curran schemes can be struck down under existing law. We certainly applaud Mr Justice Rogers's decision in this regard. We hope that there will be many more decisions of that kind. Decisions made in respect of participants in the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes will be useless if this sub- clause goes through. There will be no way in which that money will be recouped from the beneficiaries of the schemes. This sub-clause is a complete cop out, as we asserted earlier. It will ensure that the Government makes a very large concession to the tax dodgers. We deplore the Government's refusal to accept this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) completely misunderstands the purport of this clause. If he does understand it, he is exaggerating its application for narrow political purposes. It does not have the effect which he says it has. It has the effect that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has stated to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Very briefly, I want to put a simple proposition to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) involving two sets of circumstances. The first one concerns promoters who strip the assets of a company by way of a wet Slutzkin scheme without trying to support it with some type of avoidance scheme. In that case they will be caught by this legislation and they will be required to pay the tax that they otherwise would have avoided.

SPEECH.PARA: The second case concerns people who are involved in a wet Slutzkin scheme in an endeavour to have two strings to their bow or two bob each way. Another avoidance scheme precedes that Slutzkin scheme. I am referring to the smarter operators who try to cover their tracks. In the first place they have an avoidance scheme which proves to be unsuccessful. These are the real smarties. They are precisely the scheme operators that the inclusion of this clause in the Bill will allow to get away with the tax that should have been paid. The people who try only the wet Slutzkin schemes will be caught. Those who have two bob each way and try an avoidance scheme followed by the wet Slutzkin scheme will be able to escape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) and the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) I wish to read the words contained in clause 3 (12) (d). It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the stripping arrangement was not entered into for the purpose, or purposes that included the purpose, of achieving or securing the result referred to in sub-paragraph 5 (1) (h).

As I understand it, honourable members opposite are talking about the case where a person is deliberately trying to put himself in a position where he cannot pay . This saves the case for the revenue so that it is only--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it doesn't.
—It does. If a person entered into a scheme for the purpose of making himself unable to pay the tax then he will be caught.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Willis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 4 (Application of Assessment Act).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 4, page 8, after sub-clause (3) insert the following sub-clause:
''(3A) A report of the Commissioner under section 14 of the Assessment Act may-
(a) draw attention to the failure of a person to pay recoupment tax or late payment tax due and payable by the person; and
(b) disclose the identity of the person.''.

This amendment is designed to reinsert a provision which was in the original recoupment legislation which was brought before this House a month before the Bills now before us were brought to the House. The original legislation had a provision which read exactly as the amendment now before the House. The purpose of that provision was to authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to set out in his annual report the names of persons who participated in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, were assessed for recoupment tax, but had not paid the recoupment tax. It seems to us that there is no real reason for the Government to withdraw that provision, which was in the original legislation. Certainly, with its withdrawal section 14 of the Income Tax Assessment Act still applies, but that does not specifically provide for the naming of persons. We believe that it is thoroughly reasonable that in this situation we have direct authorisation to the Commissioner of Taxation to publish the names of persons who fail to pay the recoupment tax for which they are properly assessed. The Government has given no reasons for eliminating this provision. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his second reading speech simply said the Government had changed its mind on that issue and gave no reasons for so doing. We assume that the reason for making that change is that the Government is concerned about the possible naming of persons who have association with the Liberal Party and who may be required to be named in the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation if this provision is included in the legislation.

We believe that there is no good reason for not having this provision. These people, after all, are persons who have been involved in a tax evasion scheme, who have had the use of this money for several years and who have now been finally caught up with; who have been required to pay and who have not paid. In that situation it seems to us that there is every right for the Taxation Commissioner to be able to name those persons in his annual report. The fact that he has that right, of course, will be added inducement to ensure that people, in fact, do pay the tax. If this provision is there and people are going to be named for not paying the tax then people may think twice about not paying the tax. Certainly they may have other more direct financial reasons for not making that payment. But the fact that publicity can attach to their non-payment can be a powerful deterrent, particularly for persons in important positions in this country. We believe, therefore, that it is very important that this provision in fact be included in the legislation. The Government has given us no reasons for its action. We look forward with interest to the Treasurer now telling us why the Government has seen fit to delete a provision which he originally saw fit to include and which we believe is absolutely essential if this measure is to have the proper weight attaching to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is absent for a few moments so may I answer what has been put by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis)? In the first place, we have, of course, the usual smear tactics. What are we told? We are told that the reason this provision has been taken out is that this Government is seeking to cover up for members of the Liberal Party. This is reminiscent of the unsubstantiated but constantly repeated smear which has been put about this chamber by members of the Opposition in the course of the public trial of people who never have the opportunity to come here to answer what has been said about them. Individuals like the honourable member for Gellibrand and other members of the Opposition have time and time again directly, by implication or by innuendo, brought into controversy and attacked and damaged the reputations of people who do not have the opportunity, as they do to exercise and to minimise the absolute privilege which we have. All one can say about that is that it is most contemptible. But one might also say that it is a most understandable exercise given the kind of political leadership that we have experienced in the Australian Labor Party. Honourable members would see-if honourable members opposite would be good enough to listen so that they could learn something, because God alone knows they know little enough about the tax law from what has been said so far-if they bothered to look at section 14 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, that that section which has been there for some time provides:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commissioner shall draw attention to any breaches or evasions of this Act . . .

Clause 4 (4) as it was in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill allowed the Commissioner to publish details of any person who, for whatever reason, including a lack of funds, has not paid recoupment tax. We are dealing with two entirely different situations. One is concerned with breaches or evasions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The second is simply concerned with those who, for whatever reason, fail to pay recoupment tax. I point out to the Committee that the clause places all persons subject to recoupment tax in the same position irrespective of the circumstances under which they sold their shares or under which their shares were sold. For example, an infant beneficiary who is assessed to pay recoupment tax and who is unable to pay that tax would fall within the provision proposed by the honourable member for Gellibrand. Why does he propose it? He does it simply for the purpose, so it would seem, of bringing pressure on people to pay. People should not pay because of public pressure, because of fear of trial in Parliament, because of fear of trial by the media. They should pay or not pay depending on their own individual decisions, their capacity and their legal requirements. When this Parliament substitutes public pressure for that other kind of judgment then what we are doing is capitulating to the kind of leadership that has been put forward on the part of the Opposition.

For those reasons we say that this motion should be rejected. Moreover, in putting it forward the honourable member demonstrated that he does not understand the difference between what was involved on the part of the vendor, shareholders and what was involved on the part of others. He says that they were involved in evasions-some may have been; many, one suspects, were not because they were the vendor shareholders. Once again, as is the case with many members of the Opposition, the honourable member has demonstrated a determined incapacity not to draw any distinction between the positions of those who sought to avoid and those who were involved in evasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are hearing further debate in the Committee stage on the distinction between avoidance and evasion. I prefer the term used by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for the time being-that the term is 'stolen funds'. I think that is the term the Australian people can understand. In supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) I am encouraged in this course of action by the fact that this amendment was in the original Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill circulated to honourable members and to the public by the Government of the day. This Government must have acted on the advice of its legal officers, on the advice of the Solicitor-General and on the advice of the Commissioner of Taxation. It is the Government's duty to act on the advice of these officers because it is dealing with $580m of revenue-not its money, not the money of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) or the Liberal Party, but money that belongs to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: In clause 4 we note that the taxpayers who are caught up by this recoupment tax have rights of appeal. The whole clause deals with the rights of taxpayers who are assessed for company tax and who are unhappy with the assessment. It details at some length the provisions in the amending Bill before the chamber. The Commissioner's office, unfortunately, does not deal expeditiously with appeals to boards of review or, for that matter, the courts in this nation. The Commissioner's office has been shown to be able to deal expeditiously when dealing with the tax assessment or the tax liability of the businessman, Mr John Reid, who was mentioned in this chamber. That gentleman was allegedly cleared of his tax liability in one evening. Between the time of leaving this chamber and coming in the next day a letter was circulated to honourable members, typed in the Department of the Treasury, clearing Mr Reid.

The difficulty that is before the chamber and before the whole of the Australian nation is that the appeal section in relation to taxation assessments for company tax, personal income tax or any variety of tax, has ground to a halt and is no longer functioning. This Government has let this appeal procedure run down. There is no statement at all, no mention, by the absent Treasurer as to what the Government proposes to do in relation to these appeals. The traditional procedure of the Commissioner in relation to an appeal against an assessment on company tax or any other sort of tax is that half of the assessed tax must be paid. This legislation has other provisions in relation to the payment by instalment of taxes assessed, but it is unclear whether, in the event of an appeal against an assessment, the Commissioner will rely on the old established procedure of requiring only half the tax to be paid pending the outcome of the court proceedings. Of course, this whole system of requiring company taxes to be only half paid has discriminated against the great mass of taxpayers in our land , those who come under the pay-as-you-earn scheme. Those personal income taxpayers have already paid their tax. The Commissioner holds the amount of tax in dispute until a board of review has determined the appeal.

I draw the attention of the Committee to another article in the Australian Tax Review Volume 10 No. 4 of December 1981 in which the editor, I. C. F. Spry, Q.C. , draws attention to the grave concern relating to the roles of boards of review . The editor states:
. . . boards of review are intended to provide inexpensive, quick, confidential and impartial resolutions of disputes between taxpayers and the commissioner.
He continues:
The present constitution and operation of the boards of review is in certain respects very unsatisfactory.

He then deals with the delays that occur before boards of review. This whole clause before the Committee details at great length all of the provisions for appealing to boards of review. These appeal procedures make a mockery of the truth because they do not operate. In this day and age the accountants, the solicitors and the ordinary taxpayers know that taxation boards of review cannot function. They have been allowed to wind down and additional boards have never been appointed. The whole system of appeal has ground to a halt. What are Government members doing about it? Nothing. They are not even interested in it. They cross the floor and carry on with the charade of alleged opposition to these provisions but they are totally indifferent to the rights of ordinary taxpayers who have to go before these boards of review together with all the other--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. I submit that the honourable member's comments are irrelevant to the clause we are debating. We are considering the naming provisions and he is talking about appeals. I submit that it is irrelevant.
—Clause 4 is a fairly wide clause.
—It is not; it is the naming clause.

—Order! The Chair is making the ruling, not the honourable member for Braddon. I ask the honourable member for Lowe to make sure he keeps within the bounds of the clause. Naturally I will be listening to how he addresses the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Chairman. I was dealing with clause 4 of the Bill . I draw the attention of the honourable member for Braddon to sub-clause (7) of clause 4 which is a quite extensive sub-clause dealing with appeals. Obviously he has not looked at page 9 of the Bill.
—What about the amendment?

—I have already dealt with the amendment. As I understand it, we are in Committee and the Committee is dealing with clause 4. I have spoken in support of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) and I am proceeding to deal with another section of this clause which I think is of great importance. It is of importance to Australians who have been unfortunate enough to be involved with bottom-of-the-harbour promoters. I feel very sorry for these people. I have a genuine interest in them and their ability to take action if they want to appeal. The Government is legislating against many of these unfortunate people. Many are the Government's own supporters, members of the Liberal Party. It is saying: 'Here is an appeal system. If you do not like what is going to happen you can go to court or to a board of review'. I am saying they cannot go to a board of review and the Treasurer knows this. He has had letters from me and from other honourable members to the effect that the board of review system is not operating any longer. It has collapsed. The Committee has before it a Bill, clause 4 of which deals at great length with the appellate procedures for taxpayers who are unhappy with an assessment made by the Commissioner of Taxation. That is why I am drawing the attention of the Committee to these matters tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members are at all interested in tax matters I suggest that they go to the Parliamentary Library and have a look at this fine Australian publication, Australian Tax Review, and look at the situation of small taxpayers who take their cases to boards of review. These cases are about self-education expenses, travelling expenses and perhaps people who carry their tools in the boot of a car. These people will be thrown in higgledy-piggledy with all the bottom-of-the-harbour people waiting their turn. It might take two years for the matter to come before the Commission of Taxation and then they have to get in the queue at the board of review. That might take another three or four years. We do not even know whether they will have to pay all their tax, seeing that it is company tax that has not been paid. I believe this is a scandalous state of affairs. I believe the Treasurer must inform the nation of just what the Government proposes to do about this appellate system which has ground to a halt . It is a disgrace that members of the Government are totally indifferent to the rights of ordinary taxpayers who wish to lodge appeals against decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some pleasure that I follow the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) because I happened to walk into this place one evening to respond to his own reaction to a particular tax avoidance scheme which he seemed to be supporting on behalf of one of his constituents. It related to the Customs Act. As he explained-it is all in Hansard-this gentleman did not really want to cheat on his taxes; the only reason he sewed gold and silver chains into the lining of his coat before he came through Customs was that he was scared of losing them on a Qantas or Air India flight.
—A point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman.
—If that is not tax avoidance, I would like to know what it is.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

—The honourable member for O'Connor is referring to another debate on another occasion which involved, on his own admission-Hansard will establish this-the Customs Act. It had nothing to with taxation legislation. The honourable member said, on his own admission, that the debate was on Customs legislation.
—Customs comes under the Tax Act, and I have not finished on that subject.

—Order! A point of order was taken earlier by the honourable member for Braddon. It raised the matter of whether the clause is narrow or reasonably broad. It is a reasonably broad clause. I suggest to the honourable member for O'Connor that if the matter to which he refers deals with Customs-
—It deals with naming, which I think is the subject of the amendment.

—While the Chair is giving a ruling the honourable member will resume his seat. This is a naming clause. The Customs Act and duties payable under that legislation or avoidance of them has nothing whatsoever to do with this clause or this Bill. I ask the honourable member to make sure his remarks are addressed to the clause. The clause is quite broad and I am happy to give him reasonable latitute. I think he is going beyond reasonable latitude at this point of time.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Chairman. I will get to the subject. I now address myself to the amendment proposed by the Opposition. The Opposition has already made an offence of a situation that does not even exist in the law yet. There is no tax liability on the people we are talking about tonight and there will be no tax liability until this Bill is passed. If there is a tax liability at that time those people will be treated as any other people under the tax Act. This is the basis of our argument. There are people who cannot pay and people who will not pay.
—Are they tax evaders?

—They are not tax evaders because, at this moment, no tax is applicable to the shareholder of a company that has not paid its tax. The honourable member knows that; I know that. When this Bill is passed and we discuss the intention of this Government in bringing this tax down under section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act we might ask ourselves whether there is a responsibility, in accordance with the intention of this Parliament, to collect tax from a shareholder on account of a tax liability of a company. At the moment there is no tax liability. When this legislation creates a tax liability that person will be entitled to be treated like any other person who today incurs a tax liability. The Opposition wants to make a villain of such a person. The point I made at the beginning is that there seems to be great hypocrisy. If a constituent of the honourable member for Lowe seeks to avoid tax, namely Customs duty, by sewing gold and silver chains inside his coat before going through Customs, that is not tax avoidance according to the honourable member for Lowe. If honourable members read Hansard further they will see that the honourable member for Lowe got that person off. He was never convicted. This is great hypocrisy from the Opposition.
—Order! As I have said before, the matter that the honourable member is dealing with has nothing whatsoever to do with this clause or this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to some of the comments made by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), whose attempt to defend what the Government has done in taking out sub-clause (3A) was one of the most pathetic defences I have ever heard. The honourable member for North Sydney may know something about the law but it is quite obvious that he knows absolutely nothing about morality. He mentioned that it was not relevant that public pressure should be brought to bear on persons to pay their taxes under the legislation. He argued that public pressure was an irrelevant phenomenon and that it was somehow immoral that public pressure should be brought into the matter. I remind the honourable member that if it had not been for public pressure we would not even have this legislation before the place. If it had not been for the media, the Costigan report and public pressure the Government would never have done anything in relation to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record of prosecutions by this Government in relation to other tax avoidance and evasion measures. It is absolutely pathetic and disgraceful. If there is no public pressure how are we to know whether sensible action will be taken in relation to these matters? The threat of naming the person who have refused to pay tax is a very reasonable one indeed and it is a necessary pressure. Let us go back to the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in relation to what we are talking about here. He said that these actions are thoroughly immoral, disgraceful and cannot be justified. Under those circumstances what is wrong with bringing public moral pressure to bear so that people pay their taxes? There is absolutely no justification whatsoever for taking out this clause. I contrast the sudden morality of honourable members opposite who talk about these poor rich persons-they are nearly all extremely rich persons-being smeared or having their names published as not wanting to pay up their due share of tax. This Government does not seem to have had too much worry about printing the names of social security beneficiaries who, for example , have been brought before a court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are discussing clause 4, and a proposal to insert new sub-clause (3A). There is nothing in the clause or the amendment about naming persons. I would like you to ask the honourable member what clause he is talking on.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The following sub-clause is the one which it is proposed should be added:

INTERJECT.PARA: (3A) A report of the Commissioner under section 14 of the Assessment Act may-
(a) draw attention to the failure of a person to pay recoupment tax or late payment tax due and payable by the person; and
(b) disclose the identity of the person.
I think the naming of a person does come into it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments I made were entirely relevant to and, in fact, support that amendment which, as has been pointed out, was in the original draft of the legislation but was taken out by the honourable members opposite. Before I was interrupted I was referring to the double standards that this Government has in relation to naming people. I refer to some poor unfortunate persons who were supposed to be in breach of the social security legislation. They were charged in the so-called Greek conspiracy case. I remind honourable members that not a single person was convicted in that case. This Government did not worry about those people being named in the newspapers.
—Order! The honourable member for Burke will not refer to naming in other cases but confine his remarks to naming under the proposed new sub-clause.

—I am pointing out the Government's double standard in taking out this sub-clause. When rich people, friends of the Liberal Party, are involved the Government has qualms about people being named in reports. On the other hand , when certain unfortunates who are perhaps on pensions or benefits are involved , the Government has no worries about naming them. It is this double standard which needs to be exposed. In conclusion the morality of this situation has been made clear by the Prime Minister and other Government spokesmen opposite. These actions were thoroughly immoral and fraudulent. Therefore there is absolutely nothing wrong with us naming these persons if they refuse to pay their due taxes after this legislation is enacted. I urge the House to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Opposition's attitude to this clause is very consistent with its general attitude to naming people in the Parliament. We are here dealing with the right of the Commissioner of Taxation to name people in this Parliament.
—No, we are dealing with the report.

—Yes, the report which is tabled in the Parliament. Honourable members opposite say: What is wrong with applying public moral pressure by naming people in this Parliament? Look what they have done over the last few weeks, during this session of the Parliament.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. I did not say anything of the kind in relation to this matter. I was talking about the report of the Commissioner--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. That is not a point of order.

—I quoted exactly what the honourable member said because I wrote it down when he said it. He said: 'What is wrong with applying public moral pressure?' We are dealing here with the right of the Commissioner to include in his report the names of certain people who have not paid their tax by the due date. The honourable member says 'What is wrong with that?' I suggest that the people should do something wrong-they should evade tax or breach the law-before the Commissioner has the right to include their names in a report to be tabled in this Parliament. The Opposition's attitude is completely consistent. It does not need any evidence of wrongdoing before it names people in this Parliament. I believe that the Australian community is sick and tired of the Opposition's attitude, which is evidenced in the comments that the honourable member has made in this debate. The people of this country are sick and tired of the Australian Labor Party naming people day after day in this Parliament without any evidence at all to back up its claims. Clause 4 (3) of this Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of section 14 of the Assessment Act, this Act shall be deemed to be part of the Assessment Act.

Under that provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act the Commissioner of Taxation has the right in his report to draw attention to people who have broken the provisions of that Act or who have evaded tax in contravention of the Act. I believe that is a reasonable provision. The amendment proposed by the Opposition is the big stick, the big threat. It is the sort of attitude which we expect from the Labor Party and which has been evident in recent weeks. I believe it is the sort of provision which should not be supported. I was against the provision being included in the original legislation because I believed it was inappropriate. I will certainly oppose the amendment proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found unbelievable the remarks of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) about the Australian Labor Party smearing people by naming them in Parliament. This matter arose from an inquiry established by the Fraser Government into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in an attempt to smear the Australian Labor Party. We found that the ship painters and dockers were not simply involved in criminal activities, but were representing the remnants of Australia's failed upper class in their tax avoidance practices. The smears, if they are to be so called, were established first of all by the Liberal Party which raised smearing to an art form in 1975 by its unprincipled attacks upon Dr Cairns, Mr Connor and everybody associated with them. Not only did members of the Liberal Party do that; they also wrote out cheques for dud information with which to smear people. I lived here in those days; do not tell me about smearing. Honourable members opposite are a political rump representing the establishment in this country. They see that as their job. They are the lackeys of the remnants of Australia's failed upper class. What they are about is protecting people who have evaded taxation.
—Tell us about your socialist aims.
— Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will remain silent.

—Honourable members opposite are about protecting people who have fraudulently misappropriated funds which belong to the Commonwealth of Australia . They are the people honourable members opposite are seeking to protect. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Braddon, and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) seem to argue with convoluted logic that people who evade tax through criminal practices and who then fail to pay under a liability established by the Commissioner of Taxation should not have their failure to pay recoupment tax or late payment tax drawn attention to by the Commissioner. The amendment proposed by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) provides expressly for the Commissioner to draw attention to such failures to pay. If people are assessed and they do not pay, why should they not be exposed as participants in the scheme?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite think it is their job to protect those they see as members of their own class and who have been involved for years in criminal activities to avoid taxation. Some of the wealthiest private citizens of this country and some of the wealthiest private companies in this country, which this country has been very kind to, descended to the depths by taking on these obviously criminal schemes to evade and avoid income tax. Yet when the Government writes this provision into the legislation, all the hacks on the Government back bench who represent such people want this provision removed from the Bill before it is presented. We want to get the provision back to keep pressure on those people who have participated in these fraudulent and contrived tax avoidance schemes. We say that if they are finally assessed as having a liability and do not pay-they have been given 12 months in which to pay, a provision we do not approve of-they should be mentioned by the Commissioner. Many people whom honourable members opposite represent in this Parliament will not want to be disclosed as being participants in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and other schemes of criminal import. I do not know how honourable members opposite, as representatives of the Australian public, can argue that people should be able to rip off the revenue, not pay when they are assessed as being liable and then not be mentioned. That is what honourable members opposite are arguing. First of all, such people avoided tax. Then they were assessed. Honourable members opposite are saying that such people, having been assessed, should never be named by the Commissioner if they do not pay. Honourable members opposite are trying to equate naming by the Commissioner with smearing by the Labor Party. It is not a matter of a smear of the Labor Party. It is to do with naming by the Commissioner in a report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you refuse to take their money?

—Order! I have already warned the honourable member for O' Connor for interjecting. He has tried unceasingly to interject since. I warn him to cease interjecting. I call the honourable member for Blaxland.
—The report of the Commissioner of Taxation for this year has been brought down in this House. The names of many people are mentioned in that report, as has been the practice for years.
—It has never been the practice.
—I have been here longer than the honourable member and I have seen the reports year in and year out.
—You don't know what you are talking about.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting or I will take action.

—I can assure the honourable member for North Sydney that quite often the Commissioner of Taxation has given lists of people who have either understated their income or not paid their tax. They are ordinary taxpayers. We are talking of a special class of taxpayer-the tax avoider, the person who evaded tax in the first place, which tax is to be recouped under special legislation which the Government has designed. We say that if they are assessed and still refuse to pay, there should be an express provision in the legislation to oblige the Commissioner of Taxation to bring the public sanction of exposure on to their heads. Why should there not be a sanction? Yet honourable members opposite use this argument about smearing. They have smeared people for years. They have always regarded themselves as having a God-given right to run Australia and now, like a lot of lackeys, they are trying to protect the people behind them in the establishment who have had their fingers in the public till. They are trying to protect reputations that such people do not deserve. We are about exposing them for the frauds that they are. The quicker this amendment is passed into law, the more pressure will be brought to bear more quickly on those people who do not want to be named as participants in schemes which they know full well they should never have been in in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Bourchier) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Willis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the question is put I wish to raise a matter relating to clause 4 (5). Clause 4 (5) reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Where-

(a) a person makes a request in writing to the Commissioner that the Commissioner disclose to the person information relating to an arrangement or transaction referred to in paragraph 5 (1) (h) or 2 (h); and . . .

This clause is about requests in writing to the Commissioner of Taxation for information relating to the nine trigger provisions contained in clause 5 of the Bill. I had intended moving an amendment, Mr Deputy Chairman, but, like one of your former colleagues from another place, while I may have the logic I certainly do not have the numbers. Whilst not moving the amendment, I raise the matter with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and ask him to respond before the vote is taken. What we are doing, in some cases up to 10 years down the track, is imposing a liability on people who hitherto had no such liability. We are giving them the right in this clause to write to the Commissioner to seek information about how and on what basis this liability was determined. We specify that they can seek information relating to the arrangement or transaction referred to in paragraphs 5 (1) (h) or 5 (2) (h), but what concerns me is that there are nine trigger provisions, not one. I believe that if we are to impose this liability on people retrospectively they should have a right to information about all of the nine trigger provisions. The explanatory memorandum at page 28 deals with this clause. As one skims down the page one sees that a person will be able to obtain certain information. It states:

The information which the Commissioner of Taxation is authorised to disclose to a person under this paragraph is information that is relevant to an assessment of that person's liability to pay recoupment tax.

Further down it refers to full knowledge, and then provides that the person will be able to obtain the identities of and details about the persons liable to pay promoters recoupment tax. It provides that a person will be able to obtain all information. Now, the words 'all information' are also included in sub-clause (5 ) (b) on page 9, but because sub-clause (5) (a) identifies only one of the trigger provisions, and that is specifically the arrangement or transaction, I have a doubt as to whether the person who will be receiving this assessment, if writing to the Commissioner, will in fact be able to obtain all the information. Leaving aside the rights or wrongs of imposing that liability on a taxpayer, surely we should-
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I shall report progress.

INTERJECT.PARA: Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Sir James Killen-Mr Deputy Speaker, I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.
TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT BILL 1982 [No. 2]
In Committee
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude my remarks on clause 4 by saying that if we are going to impose a liability on taxpayers surely we should give them right of access to all of the information which has led the Taxation Office to impose that liability in the first place. My amendment to clause 4, if I had moved it, would have read: 'The Commissioner shall disclose to the person information relating to any of the matters referred to in clause 5 (1) or (2)'. I would have included all of the nine trigger provisions, not just one. Before the question is put I would appreciate a response from the Treasurer on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) has raised this matter with me. I will try to respond to the points he has put. The first comment I make is that this particular provision, that is, the provision enabling the Commissioner of Taxation to make information available, in effect, about the affairs of the promoters and the activities of the promoters after the sale of shares in subject companies, was in fact put into the Bill prior to the Government's decision to include promoter provisions. It was put in the Bill against the background of there not being at that time contemplated action under this Bill against the promoters. In those circumstances the case for making the information available was that much stronger. The promoter provisions having been put in the Bill there has been some diminution of the need for this particular provision. Nonetheless, the Government perseveres with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the honourable member for Tangney that, as I understand what he is asking for, his suggestion would involve the provision of information which would go beyond what the High Court of Australia has in cases ordered the Commissioner of Taxation to provide to people who are in receipt of taxation assessments. There can be no argument, quite apart from this particular amendment, that under the existing law as enunciated on a number of occasions-as recently as 1977-by the High Court of Australia there is extensive obligation under that law for the Commissioner of Taxation to provide relevant particulars and information. It is, of course, a different thing when the particulars sought really amount to evidence. The courts have long drawn a distinction between requiring a plaintiff or an applicant to make available what constitutes reasonable particulars of the basis of a claim and what constitutes evidence in support of those particulars.

I encourage the honourable member for Tangney to accept my assurance that first , to the extent that there are now promoter provisions in the Bill, the original motivation for the change is perhaps not as great-although it is still a desirable provision. Secondly, the general law requires the Commissioner of Taxation to make full provisions available. Thirdly, as I understand what the honourable member has said, giving full effect to his request would result in vendor shareholders in this situation receiving information that in previous cases the courts, would not, as a matter of quite invariable practice, order the Commissioner to make available. I hope the honourable member might accept that that is a reasonable basis for the Government's not accepting his amendment, notwithstanding the question of numbers or anything else.
Clause agreed to.
Progress reported.

TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT BILL 1982 [No. 2]
In Committee
Consideration resumed.
Clause 5 (Primary taxable amounts).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 15, after sub-clause (3) insert the following sub-clause:

'(3A) A primary taxable amount shall not be taken to exist in relation to a person in relation to the sale of shares or of an interest in shares in relation to an amount of ordinary company tax or undistributed profits tax payable by a company in relation to a year of income unless, immediately before the time of sale of the shares or interest in shares, the person knew or believed, or could reasonably be expected to have known or believed, that-
(a) ordinary company tax or undistributed profits tax, as the case may be, was payable, or would become payable, by the company in relation to the year of income; and

(b) an arrangement or transaction had been or would be entered into or carried out for the purpose of securing or achieving the result that the company would not be able to pay to the Commissioner all of the ordinary company tax or undistributed profits tax, as the case may be, that was, or would become, payable by the company in relation to the year of income.'

It has long been a principle of common justice in this country that those who act within the law ought with certainty be able to be protected by that law. As so many speakers said in the debate on the second reading of the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 (No. 2) last night, there is a grave misgiving that the Bill as a whole breaches that longstanding commitment of the Government to the people of this country. I nevertheless made it clear to the Government-I want to make it quite public now-that I have been for some weeks prepared to compromise my position in relation to the rule of law and the certainty under which I believe people ought to be able to act within that law to the extent that I would be prepared to vote for this legislation if it could at least protect those people who are by any stretch of the imagination demonstrably innocent of a knowing act to defraud the tax. It is for that reason that I have moved the amendment.

I understand that there are still some classes of people who, once this amendment were inserted in the Bill, would still not be protected. Certainly those who knowingly sold, within the law, to those who later broke the law-in terms of this Bill or in terms of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act-would still be caught and I would still not be happy, not because I would condone that knowing act of tax evasion but simply because I respect the law. With my amendment inserted, that would tidy up-having had inserted clause 3 (12), already debated tonight-three other of the four possible classes of people, namely, those who knowingly sold to those who did not break the law; those who unknowingly sold to those who did not break the law and, with the so-called fairness clause as it has been called in the Press, those who reasonably would not have knowingly sold to those who broke the law. I simply want to extend the degree of fairness in this legislation so that reasonable, decent Australians can stomach it.

Many cases would be protected simply by the inclusion of this clause. I do not want to postulate a wide range of those cases. Despite the fact that some people have been publicly saying that everyone is guilty it is not for me or for any other politician to determine guilt. That is for the courts to decide. There are obviously, in my view, many people who could possibly have been innocent, such as minority shareholders who would not normally have known of all the transactions or all the deals. There are many cases in which people who were at arm's length could have been involved. If we look through the provisions of this Bill and at the way in which it chases companies, trusts or whatever down to a natural person, we will see that there will surely be some natural persons, or even one natural person, who could not reasonably be thought to have been implicated in conspiring towards an evasion of tax.

I appeal to the common decency of members on both sides of the House to support me in my endeavour to restore some legitimacy to this legislation; to restore the legislation to such a state that in 10 or 20 years we might at least be proud of it. The amendment, just in case people might think that it is too loose , places the onus of proof on the vendor shareholder who believes that he could come within its provisions to show that not only did he not know or not believe that subsequent to the sale of the shares the company would be placed in a position in which it could not deliberately pay tax, but also that he could not reasonably have been expected to have known or to have believed that. If that is not fair enough for those who are on a witch hunt, I do not know what is.

When I listened to what was said on the Opposition benches tonight and last night I was reminded of the mentality of the self-righteous people who, in the days of the Inquisition and of Joan of Arc, said that everyone in a class was guilty. I realised that civilisation has not reached the stage that I thought it had reached.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes this amendment. I must say that the heart-rending plea by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) on behalf of the tax dodgers finds no sympathy on this side of the House. The honourable member said that he wanted to ensure that reasonable, decent Australians-
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I want to raise a fundamental error of fact. I am not a friend of the tax dodgers. I am in favour of innocent people.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—The honourable member said that he wanted to ensure that reasonable, decent Australians can stomach this legislation. Let me tell him that millions of reasonable, decent Australians have been ripped off by this scheme. Millions of decent Australians have had to pay a lot more tax because of its operation. The honourable member's concern should be for them rather than for the people who benefited from the scheme. He made a passionate, heart rending plea on behalf of the people who benefited from the scheme and ignored those who have been ripped off by it. It seems to me that his priorities are absolutely perverted. The fact is that we on this side of the House reject this amendment because there are very few innocents indeed. Most of the people--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say quite openly that there may be some people who were so naive that they thought that Brian Maher was Father Christmas; that when he came along with his offer to give them much more than the company was worth they thought he was just a benign old gentleman who was going around handing out lots of money to nice people like them. There may have been some people who were so naive and innocent as to believe that that was the situation. Frankly we find that pretty hard to believe. We believe that such persons would be a minuscule proportion of those who benefited from the scheme. After all, we are talking about people who are shareholders in companies, people who presumably have some knowledge about their business interests and some concern for those business interests. They knew that their company was going through some substantial change and must have been interested in it. After all, companies were cashed up. In the typical situation other assets were transferred to another company, and that company often continued to trade under a different name. The shareholders in the company must have known that something curious was going on. They were also told not to ask any questions. That would make even the most innocent person fairly suspicious about what was going on. If one is told: 'Look, you have a buyer. Do not ask any questions, for God's sake. This is the best deal you will ever get. Take the money and run,' one would start to think: 'Gee, there must be something a little curious about what is going on'. To say that there are lots of innocents out there who will be unfairly afflicted by this legislation is an absolute absurdity.

SPEECH.PARA: If there are any such people they are incredibly naive people. Honourable members must also bear in mind that if there are any such people they have benefited from the scheme. That in the end is the basic point-whether or not they are innocent. Let me say that overwhelmingly they knew what they were all about. Whether or not they were innocent, they benefited from the scheme-a fraudulent scheme. The Government said it is a fraudulent scheme and that it is one against which it will legislate because of the element of fraud in it. It therefore said these people were participants in a matter of fraud and that they benefited from that fraudulent scheme. They have the capacity to pay the tax which is owing; they were the beneficiaries of the scheme. There is no reason to weep tears for people who benefited from a tax rip off because they have the capacity now to recoup that tax which was unfairly ripped off the rest of the Australian taxpayers. Honourable members should not come in here with their bleeding-heart stories on behalf of people who milked the system for what they could get out of it. Even if they were totally innocent and grossly naive those people were still beneficiaries of this device.

We believe it is ridiculous for anyone to contemplate this innocence clause. We commend the Government for not giving in to the pressures which have clearly been upon it to give in to them. I must say that had it done so it would have reduced a piece of legislation which is already a sham to an absolute absurdity. As I have said previously, this legislation will fail to get back a vast amount of the money which was lost under this scheme, but if we include this kind of clause every one of the participants will say: 'Gee, I did not know what was going on. I was innocent. I had no idea that there were nasty people who were going to throw the company into the harbour. I was innocent and therfore I should not have to pay the tax'. These sorts of pleas would be made by many of those people and we would be opening up a potentially massive breach in the legislation, depending on how the courts inerpret it. We can see no justification for giving in to this absurd amendment and we wholeheartedly reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss not so much the Opposition's opposition to this amendment-I actually agree that it is reasonable to recoup the money-but I find the argument that has been used offensive. There are people who are innocent. In fact, so far as this legislation is concerned they are all innocent. Does the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) really believe that an infant could have known what was happening? The question of guilt or innocence does not arise. The justification for not accepting the amendment is that a benefit was received and that benefit may be recouped. That is the end of the story.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a particular concern with the legislation which I believe would be overcome by the amendment. That is why I am prepared to support it although I accept that it could be argued that the amendment is wider than is necessary to cover my problem with the legislation. Whilst I have prepared an alternative amendment I think it would probably not be worthwhile putting that amendment as I believe the fate of this amendment which has been moved is already sealed. I also want to explain why I think the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) is quite wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation excludes vendor-shareholders who sold the shares of a company which was subsequently put into a tax avoidance scheme which could reasonably have been regarded at the time as being effective in its simple tax avoidance purpose. The Treasurer (Mr Howard), in his second reading speech to the amended legislation, said that in that type of situation it can be fairly put that because the avoidance scheme could not be said to be part of the arrangement to leave the company unable to meet its tax liability an element of fraud is not present. In other words, a vendor who sold his company, which was then subject to an avoidance arrangement, will not be caught by the legislation. My concern is with the vendor who was approached by someone who wishes to buy his company in a situation where the price offered was exceptionally good. The vendor may have said: 'I cannot believe this. The price appears to me to be too high.' If he then sought advice he could have been told that the purchaser would undertake a legal commercial arrangement with the company to minimise tax. The vendor may then have sold the company but the purchaser may not have undertaken a legal arrangement to reduce the tax liability but instead bottomed the company. That vendor will be subject to this recoupment tax. That person who undertook due inquiry to ensure that the purchaser would not act illegally will be caught by the legislation.

The honourable member for Gellibrand said quite rightly that the vendor- shareholder has received a benefit. The problem with his case is that if the vendor sold his company part way through a financial year and the company, unbeknown to him, despite due inquiry by him to ensure that it would not happen, was put to the bottom of the harbour, he is, under this legislation, liable for tax which will be assessed as at the time of sale. Let us say the financial year had three or four months to go. The vendor, if he had not sold, could have done a number of things with that company to alter his ultimate tax position at the end of the financial year. For example, if he was a farmer he could have bought some irrigation equipment which was subject to 120 per cent depreciation. He could have substantially altered his taxable position. However, he will now not have that opportunity because the purchaser, unbeknown to him, has acted illegally and has evaded the tax that was payable by that company.

A vendor may have been caught by a purchaser who has acted illegally. He will now have to pay the tax that was payable by the company at the time of sale. For the reasons I have stated, I believe that that is offensive and that the amendment which has been proposed would overcome that situation. I do not know whether there are any vendors actually in that position. I do not know whether there are people who made due inquiry. Quite frankly, I do not believe that those who were told not to inquire fall into this category. I do not believe that they made due inquiry, and they ought to be caught by the legislation. I will support the amendment and, if the amendment is not passed, I will accept the judgment of this place and I will still support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) and the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) both made the point that they find this legislation offensive. They said that people who were innocent would be punished . The contribution of the honourable member for Moore was fairly short and electrifying. I could not quite follow what he said in a very short time. He seemed to be saying that if an infant benefited he may be punished. It would not be the infant who would be paying the tax. There would be a trust arrangement of some sort. I found it difficult to follow what the honourable member was talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: When one considers the points made by both the honourable member for Moore and the honourable member for Barker one starts to have some reluctant sympathy for the Treasurer (Mr Howard). Honourable members opposite keep ducking away from the point that the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) made repeatedly. We have a package of four Bills which are designed to recover from vendor- shareholders, other former owners of companies stripped of pre-tax profits, scheme promoters and their associates the tax evaded by those companies. Why are honourable members saying that people will be punished because they have to pay tax that they were liable to pay anyway? That is the point that has been made over and over again. This legislation seeks to recoup tax that was in fact payable by people who have entered into some sort of extraordinary artificial scheme in an attempt to avoid that tax. It totally escapes me why people are concerned about the fact that people will be asked to pay tax which was due and owing. That is the view the Treasurer and most honourable members opposite have taken. However, an extraordinary attitude is taken by some members opposite who seem to be trying to protect people who they claim are innocent. Even if they did not know what was going on they nevertheless derived the benefit. It was a financial benefit on which they should have paid tax. Now, belated though it may be, the Government has decided it will attempt to recover the tax. It is absolute nonsense to talk about people being punished when they are being asked to pay what should have been paid anyway.

Another interesting point was made by the honourable member for Barker when he talked about vendor-shareholders. He conceded that that honourable member for Gellibrand was correct in saying that these people had received a benefit. But he then talked about someone selling a company which had accumulated profits half way through the year. He argued that, if such a person had known that he would be liable under legislation such as this to pay the tax that should have been paid anyway had it not been for the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme, he could have taken opportunities to do other things.

TALK.START.PARA: —They avoid it in other ways.

—The implication seemed to be that they avoid it in other ways. I do not know whether that is what the honourable member for Barker meant but it did sound that way. He may wish to clarify that. If these people had known that this was going to happen half way through the year they could have entered into other arrangements. I think that was the term that the honourable member for Barker used. I come back to the point on which the honourable member for Gellibrand started and finished. The fact is that the honourable members opposite who are arguing against this Bill ought to come back to the basic fact that it is designed to recover tax that was evaded by the companies. Honourable members opposite have talked about the fact that people are being punished in some way because they are innocent. All we are asking is for them to be liable for the recoupment of tax that was payable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the argument of the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), that innocent people can be hanged, so to speak, to get the guilty, obnoxious. He does not deny that there may be innocent people among those who will be asked to pay recoupment tax. Yet he said that they should all be caught with the same net and should all be treated equally. That was the greatest fallacy of his argument. He has applied 1982 standards to the standards which were applied by the Labor Party when in government. What happened? What demands were made on these people in 1975? Honourable members opposite should face up to the fact that this legislation goes back to the time of Labor administration. Those were the days when one could buy loss companies at 10c in the dollar and put those loss companies with profit companies. That was the legacy left to the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the people involved were advised by professionals to engage in what may or may not have later been bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. They were advised by professionals and, as vendors, many of them believed that the situation that belonged to the days of Labor would continue. A number of honourable members would have had constituents who had been innocently caught up in these schemes. I have such a constituent. Without naming him, I can give honourable members the circumstances surrounding the case. He is a person who finished his last year in business with a good profit. He was advised by his life long accountants that there were means of selling the company, for someone legitimately to buy the company and to put losses with that company. The accountant said however: 'We do not know fully the circumstances by which this can be accomplished. We advise you to go to the most reputable accountants in the land to get advice'. He went to the most reputable accountants and was so advised. He sold his company. Subsequently this legislation has been brought before the House.

He cannot be advised by anyone at the moment whether he will be liable to pay recoupment tax because he does not know what happened to his company. The Bill says that if his company was subsequently put into a legal avoidance scheme he will not have to pay recoupment tax but if it was put into a bottom-of-the- harbour scheme he will have to pay that tax. However, he knows that his company was liquidated several years later. He assumes that it was officially and properly liquidated and that it met the taxation requirements of liquidisation- but he does not know. No one in this House can tell him. It is an absurd situation for the honourable member for Gellibrand to oppose an innocence clause that would be required to put this man in a proper legal position-a man who had been advised by some of the most eminent professionals in the community.

In speaking to this measure yesterday I said that we as a government advise business people to go to professionals for their taxation requirements. This is to be found in government literature which is available in bookshops sponsored by the Government. We say to people in the business community that the taxation laws are too intricate to be involved in. We tell them to go to professionals. Now we are saying in this legislation that the professionals may have been crooked. But we also say that there will be no innocence clause to which to appeal. I think it is preposterous that the honourable member for Gellibrand, representing the Opposition, can deny that right to even one innocent person. What sort of Australian justice is this which denies the rights of one innocent person? Is not that what this legislation is about? Who would condemn one innocent person to get 99 guilty people? Let him speak if he will. I find this a betrayal of Australian justice. I vehemently support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to see the honourable member for Boothy (Mr Steele Hall) shedding crocodile tears for innocent constituents who are caught up in tax evasion. We are not talking about innocence or guilt but about tax evasion and recoupment and whether a person innocently, accidentally or knowingly evaded tax and pocketed the money. The constituent to whom he referred has had thousands of dollars, if not millions of dollars, put into his pocket which have been ripped off ordinary Australian taxpayers. But what is the position of honest workers who have no way in which to avoid paying their taxes- nor do they wish to do so. No one likes to pay tax, but the workers do not even see that tax. It is taken out of their pay packets before they get them. It is taken out by the law of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other people whom honourable members opposite try to protect. They are the more blatant tax avoiders and evaders. I put all these people in the same category, irrespective of what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) had to say about the law being framed in this way or that way. The intent is to defraud and to rip off the ordinary taxpayers and workers in this country. That is what these people were doing all the time. Now honourable members opposite are trying to defend those few who are getting caught up with this legislation that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) so belatedly had to introduce under public pressure. Today it is difficult to tell the difference between the Queen's birthday honours list and the report of the Commissioner of Taxation. I would not know the difference any more. This Government discredited the tax system which was not much good because it was used by the wealthy to rip off the ordinary Australian taxpayers. I oppose this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee should look logically at this issue of fairness and innocence. The basis of my concern, that innocent people might be involved in transactions that come within the ambit of this legislation, arises because we are dealing with retrospective legislation that applies over a period of 10 years back to 1 January 1972. I am sure that not one honourable member would have a word to say in favour of tax evaders, tax cheats and people who break the law. But we are dealing with legislation which creates a new tax to apply to transactions which might go back over a period of 10 years.
—To collect an old tax.

—No, it is a new tax; a tax payable by another entity, namely, the company. The company did not pay that tax for reasons which are obvious. This legislation suggests that individuals should be responsible for that tax. Honourable members opposite have said that no one involved in these schemes could be innocent. But of course this legislation is suggesting-honourable members should please listen to this-that people should have the right to go forward and prove their innocence. The onus of proof is upon them. If there are no innocent people that is an end to the matter. But they should have the right to go forward and establish their innocence, to prove that they had an innocent state of mind and that they did not know what was going to happen to these companies. On the information that I have available to me, I believe that there were people who had an innocent state of mind, who believed that they were acting properly and within the law. There were wives who simply signed documents and who were not principal actors in the events. There were sons and daughters, infant children. There were ordinary people who did not take an active interest in the running of the affairs of the company in which they held shares, not in which they were officers. This legislation covers shareholders. There were people who did not know what was happening. There were others who went to what they believed were respected lawyers and advisers, who said that, because of the High Court's decision in Slutzkin's case, this was a lawful scheme. On that basis they entered into the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members are saying that this is simply an attempt to recover the tax and that there is no penalty. I suggest to them that people will suffer-listen to those words-because under this legislation they will be required to pay, or repay, money to the Government which companies should have paid some years ago. These people have spent that money, in most cases. The money is not just lying idle in the bank, it has been invested in a business. It may have been used to create jobs for people in this country. It may have been spent in one way or another or invested in some form which is creating employment in this country, and now these people will suffer if they are asked to repay that money. If Opposition members cannot understand that point they cannot understand the sense of justice. These people acted, they believed, within the law, because the basis of this amendment is an innocent state of mind. They must have an innocent state of mind to gain the benefit of this amendment. That is a point that I am sure honourable members on the other side will not understand.

We are dealing here, as the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) said , with innocence and with a fair go. This is Australia. We have got a sense of fair go in this country. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) said: 'Ah yes, I admit there are some innocent people.' I assume he suggests that there are innocent people within the meaning of this amendment we are suggesting . He said: 'That is too bad. We cannot be concerned about innocent people. We are not concerned that innocent people might suffer.' That is what this is all about-innocence. Opposition members should read it. The obligation, the onus, is upon the taxpayer to go forward and establish only that he had a state of mind which was innocent, but, and I read the words 'could reasonably be expected to have known or believed.' That is an objective test. I suggest it is a test that will not be very easy to get around despite what honourable members opposi te say. It is a difficult test because it is an objective test. The court might well say on the evidence before it, on the documents, on the general situation, that these people ought to have known, despite the fact that they might plead subjectively that they did not know. The court, on the objective test, can look at all the evidence. The honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) shakes his head. I believe he will understand what I am talking about; he will see sense in what I am talking about.

Why can we not allow these people, these innocent people-it has been admitted that there are innocent people-to have the right to go forward and establish their innocence? If they are not innocent, that is it. I agree with the honourable member for Boothby that if there is one innocent person this amendment is justified. We are talking about people who will suffer. As I said before, honourable members opposite may not see it but people who believe they are acting properly and within the law may have gained a benefit from acting within the law. They have used that money, spent that money. They have invested that money in some way and maybe have created jobs. I know that the Labor Party is not concerned with the question of retrospectivity. If this is prospective, that is okay, but we are talking about a matter that goes back 10 years. I know that Opposition members will not understand it.

They have a philosophical hang-up about this. They are out to get these people. It is a witch hunt. They do not care whether these people are innocent or guilty . As I have said, that is what this is all about. If people are not innocent, what are we concerned about?
