If they are all guilty-I know Opposition members believe everyone involved is guilty-they have no concern. This only gives them the right to go ahead and try to establish that they are innocent. I base my argument on the fact that we are dealing with retrospective legislation. I have a fundamental objection to retrospective legislation. If these people acted against the law, let them be dealt with according to the law which applied at that time. As was said earlier, we are talking about 1972, 1973, 1974 and 1975, when the Opposition was in government. We go back 10 years. If these people were acting unlawfully, they should have been dealt with according to the law; or if there are laws that apply now under which they can be dealt with, let them be dealt with according to that law.

This whole issue concerns a very fundamental principle, as I said in my speech on the second reading of the Bill, that is, the rule of law. I know we can say: 'Why worry about the rule of law?' I believe principles are still important. I know there are some members opposite who say that, the only principle is to win votes and to win government, but there are principles with which we have to be concerned, and a fundamental principle is the need to obey the rule of law. I have no brief for tax evaders. I say: 'Let us get tough on tax evaders, but let us do it prospectively, in the future. Let us not go back 10 years.' Certainly the least we can do is to protect innocent people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how many more of the tax dodgers 11 are going to get up and address us tonight. What is intriguing about their remarks is that they are addressing them to the Opposition. They seem conveniently to overlook the fact that a substantial majority of people on their side are also going to oppose this amendment. Here, for once, I am able to have common cause with a majority of the Liberal Party in this House. The Treasurer ( Mr Howard) and the majority of the Liberal Party, and apparently most of the National Party in this House, recognise the shallow idiocy of the arguments that have been put up tonight by speaker after speaker. I challenge some of the others who are going to vote with us to defeat this clause to get up and express their views on this matter as well.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well to talk about the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). The honourable member for Gellibrand is not the only one who is opposed to this proposition. Every member on this side of the House is opposed to it, and the vast majority of those on the other side of the House are opposed to it as well. That is because there is a simple fallacy in the argument of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) and, more particularly, in the argument of the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). What they have overlooked -we know what they are up to-is that this is simply a back door method of exonerating people from the tax liability which they had, always had, and knew they had. That is the simple truth. It is not a question of innocence or guilt, it is a question of tax liability and whether they were beneficiaries. If they got the money, they ought to pay it back.

The argument put forward by the honourable member for Braddon is that they have spent it. I know they have spent it. They have spent it in Gold Coast apartments , I dare say. They have had the interest free use of it for years and years, in many cases, and now all that is being asked of them is to get back the 1977-78 value in money terms, which of course is much less in real terms now. They do not have to pay the interest, and they have had the interest free use of that money for all that period. In any event, what difference does it make? The tax man has always reserved the right to go back and issue new assessments if, in the course of events, he has discovered that a mistake was made. There is no finality about the tax assessment that the honourable member for Braddon might have received last year. If one gets a revised tax assessment it is no good excusing oneself on the basis of saying: 'Oh, I am sorry. I spent the money and I can't pay it back'. One would be laughed out of court by the tax man and everyone else.

I am not sure what year the honourable member for Boothby is talking about when he talks about the revered businessman who found a sneaky tax lurk hanging around which allowed him to avoid tax. This businessman, presumably shrewd, apparently successful, knew that he had a tax liability. Yet he wanted to arrange his affairs in such a way as to avoid that tax liability. If he got the benefit then he ought to be forced to pay up now. That is really the only issue that is involved in this matter.

I daresay that Denis Horgan has about seven million bucks hanging on the fate of this clause. His simple defence has been that he did not know. Denis Horgan, one of the most 'successful' businessman in Western Australia in recent times, managed to dodge $7m as a result of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the smear again.

—Whenever one exposes some facts, some misconduct on the part of prominent members of the Liberal Party, then of course it is smearing. I would have thought it was disclosure in the public interest. I would have thought that every elector was interested in who was running the Liberal Party in Western Australia, who was raising the money for the Liberal Party and, more particularly, how they were raising the money for it. I would like to know how much of the $7m the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party got. Maybe it is one of the innocents who are trying to be protected from this clause as well. I daresay that some pretty grubby money found its way into the coffers of the Liberal Party in Western Australia. There are some pretty shamefaced people in Western Australia as a consequence. Denis Horgan's simple defence in this whole matter has been that he did not know. I find that a breathtaking proposition. I daresay that the amendment is designed to provide an excuse for Denis Horgan actually to prove the fact that he did not know what he was doing and, therefore , to get out of the responsibility for paying back the $7m which he knew he should have paid but which he did not pay and which the Government in a belated, half-hearted, weak-kneed way is now attempting to get from him.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important point that has to be made in relation to all these matters is that, I suppose, the least innocent person in this whole exercise is the poor old Treasurer. If the Treasurer had taken one of about three or four actions back in 1978 or 1979 we would not be faced with this problem to the extent that we are now. It was the negligence on the part of the Treasurer in taking 2 1/2 years to act in relation to this scheme which caused the mushrooming of the scheme during 1979 and 1980. One has only to look at the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to discover the way in which this scheme mushroomed.

What the honourable member for Boothby said was quite instructive in that regard. It is quite true that the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme did become quite fashionable and quite acceptable in accounting and legal circles. The reason for that quite simply was that as soon as it was known that some people had got away with it-one would expect that the Government knew that they had got away with it -and as soon as the Government failed to act in relation to those schemes, failed even to indicate that in the future it might act against them, failed even to move against those schemes under the provisons of the existing law, others wanted to do the same. Even if the existing law was not entirely adequate at least it would have been a nice idea to test it; at least that would have put a few people on notice about how risky the operations they were involved in might have been. But the Treasurer took none of those actions. So, of course, the schemes mushroomed.

The one point that I am prepared to accept is that these schemes did become blessed with some sense of respectability by the accounting profession and the legal profession as a result of the Government's failure to act. But that does not exonerate the people who participated. In any event, it certainly does not relieve them now of the obligation to pay the money which the Government failed to collect from them at the time by acting in any of those three ways which I have already indicated. I must say that a number of lawyers-I am delighted to say that I am not one-have got up tonight to preach to us the virtues of the rule of law in the sense that we will penalise innocent people. The Government is not going to put them in prison. The Opposition on this occasion is only helping the Government to defeat this, the most crazy of the propositions that have been put in relation to this proposal. It does not matter if they were infants. What differences does it make whether they were infants? If the infants got the benefit from the scheme, knowingly or unknowingly, why should they not pay it back?

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they did not get a benefit?

—The whole point is that if they did not get a benefit there will not be a question. What will happen is that the company will get an assessment in relation to this matter. The amount assessed would have already been paid if the company was in the position to pay it. If the company is not in a position to pay it then the people who stood behind that company would be approached to pay. That is right. The people who will be approached will be the people who benefited from it. There may be some people like the poor unfortunate associates of Denis Horgan who were left high and dry after he had dumped the companies. A number of people did not receive the same sort of benefit that he got. Certainly , they did benefit and they ought to pay the money back now.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) because he has referred, as have many of the other speakers tonight, to the crime being the receipt of a benefit. Of course, that is a moral position. Of course, the honourable member for Fremantle is able to separate the morality of gypping the Government of millions of dollars and gypping it of thousands! He can separate the morality of a person claiming that he did not know the distinction of something for which he gained a capital gain and a person sending a telegram to the Minister claiming that his wife was in London when, in fact, she was in Samoa.

SPEECH.PARA: At this very moment in Australia there is no tax on capital gain made after a 12 month-period. If Australian Labor Party members want to stand up at this moment and change their current published policy that there should not be a capital gains tax I invite them to do so. I know that a large number of them are in favour of a capital gains tax. But there is no capital gains tax. At this very moment there is no tax on a capital gain made by selling a property. There is, nevertheless, a law against stripping a company so that it is unable to pay its debts, whether those debts be to the individual or to the Government in terms of its tax revenue. There is a lawyer sitting on the Opposition benches. Can he tell me whether there is a law by which one pays tax on a capital gain made after 12 months?

I heard the proposition that the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) made to this Parliament. He knows that if he had made it to a judge he would have been laughed out of the court. He tried to put a proposition to this Parliament that does not represent the law as it stands today. The fact of life is that at this moment there is no tax liability to vendor-shareholders of any company; there is no tax liability for taking a capital gain. The people who broke the law were those who stripped the companies. They happen to be a very small percentage of the people who are considered in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 [No. 2]. We have suggested that it was wrong in 1973 to take a capital gain even if that capital gain appeared to be excessive. There are plenty of examples of that, day by day. But let us get back to the morality of certain taxes. We have had for many years in this country a tax on diesel fuel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable member come back to the particular clause and amendment.
—My example relates to the morality of a retrospective tax.

—Order! The Chair has listened to one example that the honourable member has offered. It did maintain a tenuous relevance. I ask him not to stretch the patience of the Committee by being too expansive in his illustrations.

—I make the point that at the moment we are discussing the fact that people could have had no knowledge of what they were doing. We are debating whether every person who sold a company should profit any more than someone who sells a house that was later used for all sorts of bad procedures about which the person who sold it knew. I wish to give a relevant example.
—Tell us how you rigged the contracts.

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie has been cautioned against interjecting. I warn the honourable member that if he persists I will have to deal with him.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. With all respect, I really must object. I was merely trying to help the honourable member jog his memory as to how he rigged the contracts.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.

—The point I am trying to make-it is quite relevant-is that tonight we are discussing a brand new tax aimed at collecting tax relative to previous action. I wish to give an example of other taxes levied in that fashion. For many years certain sections of the community have paid a tax on diesel fuel. Many other consumers have not. Recently we changed that situation, as we are proposing to change the situation relative to taking the profit on a capital gain, which is basically what this tax is about. I am wondering, when we change that rule, whether members of the Opposition will suggest that all those people who did not pay their tax up to that point, who obviously got a benefit-they have used the word 'benefit' time and again without interruption-relative to those who paid, should now be told that they should pay a tax because they gained a benefit. That basically is the proposition put to us in opposition to this amendment-that there was a benefit gained. I had to advise a constituent today that certain items of manchester will attract a tax of 7 1/2 per cent on 1 January. Should we go back to our mothers and tell them that they should pay a tax because they received a benefit when they bought sheets 25 years ago? I put the point-some honourable members will argue against it-that we are creating a new tax and there can have been no benefit. We laid down certain criteria to calculate that tax.
—You ought to be certified.
—Only because I keep company with you. The fact is that we are creating a new tax and we are creating criteria for calculating that tax.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I make it quite clear that I have never kept company with that man and never would.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—We have gone this far in creating a new tax and a method of calculating that tax, and we are entitled in this place to raise criticisms of that method of calculation. We say the method of calculation has a purpose. The purpose is to catch people who joined with other people and knowingly set about stripping a company and taking away its ability to pay tax. We on this side are saying that we will accept that point of view, even though it is retrospective, if they joined together. The purpose of this amendment is that if they did not join together they accepted a capital gains tax legitimately under the laws of Australia and there is no reason in the world why they should be clubbed with those who joined with other persons and chose to create a circumstance whereby that company that changed hands could not pay its tax. There is a vast difference. I do not care if they spent the money or what they did. I do not support some of the other points of view.

SPEECH.PARA: On the law as it is today there is no tax. We are creating a new tax which is no different from a new sales tax or diesel tax. We have a method of calculating it and the method says that if a person joined with someone in dishonesty he should pay the tax. My colleague's amendment says that there should be the right to say: 'I did not join'. The Opposition always stops and says: 'Mr Horgan did not know'. Mr Horgan has said he did not know that when he sold his property it would go to someone who would do other things. Under this amendment it is up to him to prove that. That is the point. That is contrary to my belief of justice. I believe that it should be up to the Commissioner of Taxation, the police or whoever to prove that. However, we are going that far with this amendment. If honourable members say that there should be a benefit and they do not support a capital gains tax, then they must accept the fact that all other forms of new tax should be retrospective as far back as the year dot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Since I have been in this Parliament I have heard some incredible things. Most of those incredible things have been said by honourable members who sit on the Government side. Tonight I heard the most incredible thing that I have heard at any time in my life. I heard it from the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom). He said that the reason why this money that belongs to the Australian Treasury, that belongs to the Australian nation and to the Australian people should not be given back is that the people who gained it may have spent it. How did they spend it? What have they done with it? They have put it in their pockets; they have put it into bank accounts; they have put it into share portfolios; they have put it into luxury homes on the Gold Coast; they have put it into a Rolls Royce and other luxury cars in their garages; and they have put it into their yachts. These are the people who got some financial advantage from the fact that tax which was due and payable to the Australian Treasury was not paid. So what they are attempting to do now is to build into this legislation what they choose to call an innocence clause. Innocence or not is not the issue. There has been no suggestion by the Opposition that there may be a small number of people who did not really know what was happening. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) referred to them as the naive people who believe that the Brian Mahers of Australia are Father Christmases who came along and hand out to them large sums of money in excess of the real value of the things that they are selling.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us put it in blunt terms. Here is an example. We have a straw company that has made $100,000 taxable profits in one year. At the end of the 12 months, at the end of the financial year, the amount from that $100,000 that is owing to the Australian Taxation Office is $46,000. So the maximum which can be left with the people who own the company is $54,000. Then, along comes Brian Maher and says to these people: 'I will give you $90,000 for the company'. He is Father Christmas, and these people are innocent! These people who accept the $90,000 for the company on which they themselves could realise only $54,000, because $46 ,000 had to be paid to the Taxation Office, are the people who are innocent! These 11 friends, defenders and protectors of the tax dodgers, who identified themselves last night by sitting along these front benches, want to build into this legislation an innocence clause to make sure that these people who owe the money do not have to pay it back. One of the main reasons for that is because they have spent it and it will cause them some degree of hardship if they have to pay it back.

Let us imagine that one of these people has to sell his $100,000 unit on the Gold Coast. Just look at the bleeding hearts on the Government side. How dare Government supporters come into this chamber and speak such offensive nonsense not only to the members of the Parliament but also the Australian people. Let us get the $100,000 from the people who may have to sell their units on the Gold Coast and let us build four homes so that we can reduce the number of families on housing commission waiting lists in Australia from 40,000. Let us do something for those people. I say to Government members: Don't you dare talk about hardship being imposed on all these tax sharks, dodgers, thieves and crooks!

Of course honourable members know what their motivation is. About 6,200 companies have been sent to the bottom-of-the-harbour. Imagine the number of shareholders who will flood into the courts and say to the courts and to the Treasurer (Mr Howard): 'I did not know what was happening and I could not reasonably have been expected to know. I am innocent'. Where is the motivation for what some Government members choose to call an innocence clause? What they want to do is jam up the system to make sure that the cases will not even be heard and to make sure that all of the money that their tax dodging friends ripped off this nation will never be collected. We are not talking about pin money; we are talking about hundreds of millions of dollars. If such a clause were introduced into this legislation do honourable members think there would be any chance in the world that that money would be recovered? The skilled and dedicated officers of the Australian Taxation Office have recently spent long hours trying to devise legislation to catch up with these sharks. I think that the Treasurer would have preferred to support the legislation that they suggested originally. But all the Government back bench members, not only the 11 friends of the tax dodgers, put pressure on the Treasurer to knock over the legislation that the tax officers prepared in the first place to make sure that the friends of the Liberal Party would not have all of this money taken back from them. The Treasurer knows that the legislation that we are dealing with now is not and will not be as effective as the legislation that the tax officers- dedicated and capable men-initially proposed.

I would not be surprised if more officers flooded out of the Taxation Office. Why should they stay in the Taxation Office applying their time, skills, energy and dedication to devising legislation to catch the sharks and then have that legislation knocked over by the Government? Why should there not be low morale within the Taxation Office? Why should there not be frustration on the part of these dedicated tax officers? They now know the guilty men, the men who have been responsible for detecting and defending tax sharks, tax dodgers and tax thieves. The legislation has been watered down. The 11 identified friends of the tax dodgers on the Government side want to water down the legislation even more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order.
—The honourable member is one of them.

—I submit that that is a reflection on members on this side of the chamber. The honourable member refers to the 11. The 11 are known. I demand that he withdraw those remarks. He should read the speeches. We are certainly not friends of tax dodgers or tax evaders and that point has been made in our speeches.
—Of course you are. On the point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman-

—Order! Allow the Chair to say something. If the honourable member would get a little less emotional perhaps we could get back to a rational debate. I do not think that by name calling we get very far. The only way-
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not quite finished. When I have I will call the honourable member. We have to get back to a more rational debate. The honourable member for Hunter is not the only member who is using fairly extravagant language. If the Committee could try to get itself objectively involved I think it would be to the benefit of the chamber. The honourable member for Braddon raised a point of order. I do not uphold it because the remark to which he took offence was directed at members in a collective sense.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am not going to continue, regardless of the clock, until peace is restored in the chamber.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I find your observations offensive. You have accused the honourable member for Hunter of irrational conduct when, in fact, his conduct has been thoroughly rational. His arguments have been rational, passionate perhaps; but there is nothing offensive about being passionate where tax crooks are concerned. The honourable member, according to rulings which have been made in this Parliament on many occasions, is thoroughly justified in referring to 11 people collectively in the way in which he has. If you are going to argue that because it is 11 people he has transgressed the ruling then you have to accept that, because, in the past the Opposition as a group of people has been condemned by spokesmen from the Government side and the Speaker has ruled that because it is a group of members in the Opposition it is therefore not offensive, you are changing the rules.
—Would the honourable member leave it at that so I can answer him?
—No, I will not. Mr Deputy Chairman, what I am putting to you is that you have been-
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—I am putting to you that you have been unduly offensive. It cannot be justified and you have exceeded your authority in accusing the honourable member of being irrational.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—He has been thoroughly rational in dealing with tax crooks-
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Some of their friends, I expect-

—That is highly offensive to me as Deputy Chairman of this Committee and I do not accept what the honourable member has said at all. I did not accuse the honourable member for Hunter solely of being irrational and he knows very well-
—I will not accept that.
—If the honourable member wishes-
—I will not accept your accusing one of my members of being irrational when he is putting up a thoroughly documented case against-
—Order! If the honourable member wishes to take action against the Chair he can. He knows the forms of this place.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. I apologise but I found it difficult to hear the reference that was apparently applied by you as Deputy Chairman to me. I understand that the Leader of the Opposition may have taken exception to the reference. Because I missed it, would you advise me of the nature of the reference?
—I thank the honourable member for the opportunity of giving my version of it. I think what the Leader of the Opposition was referring to is that I said that the debate was getting too emotional-
—You accused him of being irrational.
—I did not. I used the word 'irrational' but not in respect of the honourable member solely, and I stick to that. That is the truth of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) to include in the legislation a fairness or an innocence clause. I believe that the legislation casts its net too wide and that genuine innocent people who have sold shares will be caught by the legislation-people who did not have an illegal purpose or intent. The amendment proposed by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro is about intent. It refers to a person who knew or believed, or could reasonably be expected to have known or believed, that circumstances applied. In my view those who did not intend fraudulently and illegally to evade a liability to pay tax should not be caught by the operation of the legislation. They are innocent.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal now with the comments made earlier in the debate by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). He clearly showed that the Australian Labor Party cannot see a difference between innocence and guilt. The honourable member for Gellibrand said that anyone who got the benefit of a scheme, whether innocent or not, will be caught. Innocence or guilt does not matter to the Australian Labor Party. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) who commented about the 11 honourable members who voted last evening against the second reading of this Bill ought to read and re-read the speeches of every one of those honourable members. They will find that what they said about those 11 honourable members is totally false . I reject the accusations made by the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Hunter. The Leader of the Opposition again engaged in this debate in the political smear-something he knows only too well and something that is costing him votes in the greater Australian community. Tonight in this chamber he made false allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which clause is this?

—If the honourable member re-reads my speech in the second reading debate on this Bill last night, he will be enlightened and he will understand that his leader's statement in this chamber tonight was totally untrue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several honourable members opposite have talked about a fair go. Let us take this concept of the fair go really seriously. When these several hundreds of millions of dollars were lost to the Australian taxpayers, it meant that there was less money to be spent on such things as social services, pensions and benefits for the poor. I remind honourable members opposite that in the period from 1975 to 1981-82 the number of poor people in this country increased from one million to 2.5 million. Is this their idea of a fair go for Australians? What do they mean when they talk about a fair go? They want a fair go when it is applied to one particular group-the wealthy, the top 10 per cent, who already own nearly 60 per cent of the wealth of this country. These people own more than the other 90 per cent put together. Why do they not think about the bottom 10 per cent who own only 0.27 per cent of the wealth of this country? What has happened to them? Those people have failed to get any benefit because of the rip-off activities of these other people.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite are trying to tell us that a person who, before paying tax, sold a company to a tax promoter for much more than it was worth had no idea that that was a way of avoiding tax. That is absolute nonsense. In the overwhelming majority of cases such a person knew very well what he was doing unless he was extremely naive or somebody else did it on his behalf. If this amendment were passed, the whole of the retrospective tax legislation would be totally emasculated because virtually everyone would be able to claim that he did not know the purpose of such schemes.

Let us assume that this amendment becomes law. A person could say to a court: ' I did not know anything about the scheme and I was acting in good faith'. Who would be produced to give evidence in that situation? The tax promoter would be produced to give evidence in a court of law. He would be asked: 'Did you inform this poor chap that this company was to go to the bottom of the harbour?' Of course, the tax promoter will not be too keen to put in his mates and prejudice possible future business. Will he say: 'Of course, I informed him?' Of course he will not say that. He will say: 'I did not inform him. He did not know the nature of the scheme'. So the suggestion in this amendment about establishing whether a person knew or believed he was acting legally is absolute nonsense. It is a clear absurdity.

The people who would be the principal witnesses in such a situation are the very people who promoted the schemes in the first place. What kind of argument is that? That kind of argument has been put forward by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). I am amazed at his intelligence in relation to this matter. He tried to make an appeal on the principle of innocence. The fact is that this is a matter not of innocence or guilt but of tax being evaded illegally. The Australian public has suffered in a very serious way. The legislation does not propose criminal penalties. These people will not be thrown in gaol. Nothing will be done to them except that they will be required to pay the tax liability which they had in the first place. As the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) mentioned, in many cases the real value of the money they will have to pay back will have been substantially reduced. They will be required to pay only its face value. If they had put it in a bank, interest rates being what they are, they would have ripped off a handsome profit anyway. In my view, this legislation is a very lenient way with which to deal with people who knew that they were trying to evade tax in a very serious way. Let us come back to the principle of fairness. The fairness principle applies to the whole community and not to a small group. The fair go principle demands that this money be collected from those who benefited. It is on that principle that we totally reject this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the most extraordinary demonstration of histrionics by members of the Opposition. We have become accustomed to the usual fictitious outrages we hear from them when we are debating matters of high principle. Those of us who served in the Opposition when the Australian Labor Party was in government will remember quite cleartly that, although there were three Treasurers in that preiod, no serious attempt was made to reduce tax avoidance or tax evasion. Yet honourable members opposite tonight cast aspersions on my colleagues, attack them as the tax dodgers 11, and throw around the most extraordinary insults and smears. At the same time they expect the Australian people to believe in the integrity of the Australian Labor Party in relation to tax avoidance. The record of their administration will not stand up to the closest scrutiny. They failed to do anything during that period.
—That's a lie.
—What did the Labor Government do about the Curran scheme?
—Order! I remind the honourable member for Bradfield that we are dealing with an innocence clause. We are not engaged in a second reading debate. I invite him to come back to the clause.

—Because the gauntlet was thrown down by members of the Opposition, I want to clarify that I do not support the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury). However, I emphasise that I certainly defend his right and the right of my other colleagues to support such an amendment. They believe there is a need to protect those people who they see as the innocents in this case. It is my frank opinion-this is a view expressed by the Treasurer (Mr Howard)-that it is not an issue of guilt or innocence. It is simply a question of whether tax recoupment should be required because profits were made over a period of years as a result of a specific type of scheme which was directed at avoiding the need to pay taxes on profits made on the sale of companies.

SPEECH.PARA: I should emphasise one thing to those who have some difficulty in understanding this point. Let us take, for example, a situation in which a company is sold and the possessors of the shares of that company go to their accountants or to someone else for advice. In many cases the honest person would say: 'We wish to close down this company; we have no further use for it'. It is quite clear that in some cases their advisors tell them: 'Do not close down the company. It is possible to sell it. I will possibly be able to arrange for that sale but I do not know any details about the purpose to which the company will be put. I do not even necessarily know who will purchase the company and I would advise you not to ask any questions about it. Simply take the arrangement as I make it and take the profit with you'. That is the essence of the type of program which is found in this scheme.

The error lies in the fact that as a matter of normal practice in accountancy a statement of assets must be prepared between the purchaser and seller of assets in a company. Normally the statement of assets, if it is to be a legal transfer, must take into account the provision for taxes due on profits made by the company during the relevant financial period. What happened in this case-that is why we call it a form of tax avoidance-is that the statement of assets did not include provision for taxes to be paid, and that additional element was then passed back to the shareholders and shared among those who had the advantage of being able to benefit from the sale. The question, therefore, is not whether the persons involved are innocent or guilty in that they profited from the sale but simply whether they profited from the sale. Where it can be established that such a profit was made, the question of whether they are innocent in the sense of being juniors or whether they are necessarily the unknown beneficiaries-they may be the wives or the relations of persons who have shares in a company-as far as I can see is basically immaterial. The question is: Did they gain from the sale? If they did so gain, then it is perfectly legitimate of the Government to expect those people now to be prepared to meet the taxation requirement to the taxes not then paid although, indisputably in my opinion, due. I draw attention to the Budget Speech of the Treasurer in 1978 in which he said:

The time is long since past when Governments or the community should tolerate the blatant, artificial and contrived means whereby certain sections of the community seek to pay little or no tax to the detriment of the general body of taxpayers and the equity of the tax system.

Surprisingly enough, perhaps, I think at least some members of the opposition would support that proposition. I emphasise for the benefit of honourable members who have spoken in this debate, especially the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), that the ladies and gentlemen of the Opposition are supporting the legislation of this Government. We are not joining the Opposition on this Bill; the Opposition is joining us. Let us make that point quite clear. It is not satisfactory for members of the Opposition to come into this chamber and attack my colleagues, who believe that they have the right, as they see it in accordance with their conscience, to express the views which they believe are important. They do not belong to the Australian Labor Party because they are not locked in to the outmoded nonsense that members of the Opposition go on with. They can argue in their Caucus, but somehow or other when they represent the people of Australia they have to come into this chamber like so many white mice and do exactly what they are told. While we have conscience in this chamber it will be demonstrated by members of the Liberal and National parties in this Government. It has never been demonstrated by the Opposition and I doubt that it ever will be.

Let us make the point quite clear. The Treasurer has emphasised in this chamber time after time, as have other Ministers of the Government, that it is the Government's intention to clarify once and for all that, in regard to the argument between retrospectivity on the one side and equity on the other, while we do not support the question of retrospectivity as a general rule, there are on occasions exceptions. The benefit of the nation must be given priority. Clearly, we are facing such a situation at this moment. I emphasise once again that we have heard tonight nothing but scurrilous innuendoes. So many speakers on the Opposition side have come into this chamber and suggested that my colleagues, because they are exercising their conscience--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member had better go back to the clause; otherwise I will ask him to resume his seat.

—I am referring to the amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury). I am simply supporting the right of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro and those who may wish to support him to express their views in this chamber. I am simply emphasising to honourable members that when they attack my colleagues and accuse them of being tax dodgers or of supporting people who are tax dodgers they are missing the absolute point. If any member of the Opposition can honestly look through the whole Labor Party and say that it has among its thousands of members a group of saints, all I can say is that my nine years in politics have taught me nothing. They have taught me one important thing. I would not trust members of the Labor Party any further than I can see them through the chamber door. On these sorts of issues the question is whether they demonstrate integrity, whether they believe in what they are saying, or whether they are simply trying to lead the Australian people once again down the path to absolute and utter national oblivion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has learnt nothing from the past nine years; rather, I think he has learnt just a little. It is significant that he is the only Government member who has risen so far in this long debate to oppose the amendment. That point needs to be driven home to the Australian community. He is the only Government member who has risen to oppose this amendment, moved by his colleague. Even he addressed himself in an ambivalent manner in his argument against the amendment, if it was an argument against the amendment. This legislation would not have been necessary if the Treasurer (Mr Howard) had fulfilled his responsibilities in the past. Let me refer honourable members to the Costigan report. The point that Commissioner Costigan made-
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman. Are we not debating a particular clause of the Bill? I did not think we were debating the Costigan report.
—The honourable member has no point of order. There has been plenty of looseness in the debate so far. If the honourable member returns to the point in three or four minutes I will be delighted.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I was joining in a response to the points that had been made by those on the Government side in the early part of the debate.
—I ask the honourable member to try to keep his comments as brief as he can.

—I will. Commissioner Costigan said that it was not a matter of developing or creating new laws but simply a matter of applying the existing law . That was not done, and the guilty men are those who sit opposite, including the Treasurer (Mr Howard), who sits at the table. I do not believe that the Treasurer, with his competence-he is a Liberal and a lawyer, as he has told us- could not have been aware of the magnitude of the loss to revenue resulting from the rackets that were going on, the evasion and the avoidance. I cannot accept that he was not aware of the magnitude of what was happening. The matter of tax avoidance was mentioned. It was said that we did nothing about tax avoidance.

—Order! I must butt in. I apologise for doing so but this is not a second reading debate. This debate involves the innocence clause. I ask the honourable member for Shortland to try to maintain some little relevance.
—I appreciate what you have said, Mr Deputy Chairman. I just want to give the Opposition a chance to respond to the points that were hammered against us a few moments ago. I will do it very briefly.
—This is the problem. It is self-perpetuating.

—I realise that. I will do it very briefly. The point is that under the administrations since 1975 the number of identified participants in tax avoidance schemes has risen by some 2,600 per cent. We had two short periods of government-16 months and 19 months. We issued instructions in August 1975 for prosecutions to proceed, prosecutions that would have negated the need for this legislation and this debate. Honourable members opposite have to answer to the families out there who have been paying an extra $35 a week in income tax and an extra $8 in sales tax as to why they did not proceed with those instructions, as to why those prosecutions were canned in the bottom drawer. That is the case they have to answer. There is no defence for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to compare this whole question of pseudo-innocence that I detect coming from the brave 11 opposite. Let me compare their innocence, in the case they put , with the manner in which two innocents-my constituents-have been treated by this Government, by that same Treasurer and those who sit behind him. Case one concerns a breadwinner with three children and a dependent spouse. He was employed in one of the industries in the Newcastle region until he was injured at work and went on compensation. The family could not carry on under the compensation payments. The wife had to go to work for the latter part of the financial year. When the husband submitted his income tax return for that year he overlooked-as an ordinary wage-earner would do-deducting from his claim for spouse rebate the amount that his wife had earned to keep the family together in the last few months.

What was the result? He was summoned and dragged down to a court in Sydney. He was on compensation; his wife was working trying to keep the house together, trying to keep up the rent and other payments and keep the children at school. He could not afford a solicitor. His return was re-assessed and levied an additional $600 tax. He was fined a 100 per cent penalty of $600. He could not pay it. He was on compensation, and his wife was working to pay the house payments and to feed the family. But that was not enough for this Treasurer and this Taxation Office and for those who are concerned now about innocence, concerned for the cheats and the rogues. A bit later, on a Saturday morning, along came a police sergeant from the local police station with a warrant for the father's arrest because he had not paid the fine and he had not paid the tax . He had sought time to pay but that was refused. That is the kind of justice with which honourable members opposite administer this country. That is the double standards they apply to those who are struggling to survive. So do not let me hear any more cant about pseudo-innocence and protecting the rogues.

I move to the second case of innocence. I am talking about real people, not the people honourable members opposite say should not be identified but, whose names unfortunately for honourable members opposite, are published in public documents such as the McCabe-Lafranchi report. Are honourable members opposite saying that the public of Australia should not read the McCabe-Lafranchi report because they might see some names there and associate them with the Liberal Party? Are honourable members opposite saying the public should not read or mention those names. They know what they can do with that kind of view.

The second case concerns a widow whose husband passed away in February this year. When he passed away he owed the Taxation Office $611. Despite the fact that his estate had not proceeded through probate-the estate was being handled by the solicitors in a normal and proper fashion and subject to the usual kinds of delays-this Treasurer and his Australian Taxation Office badgered that woman with constant requests for payment of the $611 owed by her deceased husband. in the finish she could not stand that any more. It is only the little people who worry about threatening letters from government departments and the Taxation Office, not the rogues, the thieves and the millionaires trying to be protected by this amendment. It is only the little and honest people-who are the salt of this country-who worry. That lady could not stand it any longer so she went to the estate solicitor and gave him a bank cheque for a lousy $611.

That was a few days before the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union was tabled in this chamber. Again that was not enough for this Government and the Australian Taxation Office because the day after the Costigan report was tabled, the bailiff's representative arrived at her door to collect the $611 which really was the responsibility of the estate. I say to honourable members opposite: That is the kind of justice you have administered. That is the kind of innocence that is genuine. That is the innocence of the ordinary, honest, hardworking, struggling Australian family. But honourable members opposite are not concerned about them. In this amendment they are concerned about protecting the thieves and the rogues who have profited under their jurisdiction and administration.

I read in the Courier Mail just a fortnight ago-a week last Friday-a big headline splashed across the top of the page. It read 'Fraser tax legislation strangles Gold Coast development'. That is what this amendment is about. That is what these people are trying to protect-not the ordinary, honest, God-fearing citizens and families of this country. They are trying to protect the rogues. I conclude by quoting from a letter I received from a lady in Grovedale. I have a similar letter from another lady in Paradise Waters in Queensland. This lady said in the letter sent to me, which is a copy of the letter addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), said:

You can be assured that if your Government proceeds with its intention of introducing retrospective legislation I will renounce my membership of the Liberal Party and use all my influence to induce as many other party members to do the same and campaign actively against the Liberal Party.

I hope she has resigned. I hope she is campaigning against the Liberal Party. I hope at some stage that those who present this mock innocence and concern about Australians convert their innocence to the genuine innocence of the real, honest , hardworking families who have suffered under this administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Tangney I must say that I do not regard the last three speeches as having been relevant to clause 5 of the Bill. I beseech honourable members to try to retain relevance to the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, it seems that by giving me the call you have selected me to wind up the batting for the 11. Without overplaying the analogy I must say it is certainly a bowlers' wicket. We are a long way behind on the score board and there is a hostile crowd. But, through you, Mr Deputy Chairman, I will play it with a straight bat and who knows, perhaps I may convince you. I turn to clause 5. I support the amendment of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) to seek to insert a fairness clause into this legislation. At the outset I say something to my friends opposite. There is abroad a political charge that my colleagues and I are friends of the tax dodgers. I will wear the political charge. I will face up to it in my own electorate and in the community at large. It may be that I will suffer a political sanction or penalty. But of one thing I am absolutely clear: I do not support this legislation because it is wrong in principle and it is wrong in practice. I am supporting the amendment only because it makes a bad Bill a little on the better side.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation seeks to recoup outstanding, legally payable company tax fraudulently and illegally evaded by way of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The only thing wrong with that is that this recoupment of an outstanding existing liability is being retrospectively transferred and imposed on vendor shareholders who, at the time of the sale of their shares, had no such liability and who, in the sight of the existing law, in the selling of their shares were totally and completely within the terms of the law. Whether we like that or not or whether we have a different judgment by way of hindsight, that happens to be the fact.

The legislation certainly gets around this awkward problem by doing three specific things. First, it creates an artificial tax year-from 1 July to the date of sale. Normally we have a tax year from 1 July to 30 June after which tax is assessed and then becomes due and payable. Through the definition of T, the company tax liability to be found in clause 5(1)(d) on page 11 of the Bill and the associated clause 5(9)(c) on page 17 of the Bill there is the arbitrary creation of an artificial tax year. That is the first thing done to get around this awkward problem about the vendor shareholders having no liability. Secondly , it removes the limited liability concept which has stood in business law for centuries. Thirdly, it makes vendor shareholders liable for the debts of others- the others being the purchasers and the strippers who carried out the fraudulent and illegal evasion of tax.

This is an arbitrary and extremely discriminatory change to the existing law and to the way of things. The most reasoned, rational argument in support of this legislation is that it is only recouping the benefit received. There is no guilt and there is no innocence. It is ony recovering the benefit received, and all people have to do is to give back the money. There is no guilt or innocence. Some honourable members submitted that this is an extremely arbitrary and unfair situation in that the vendor shareholders at the time of the sale of their shares had no such liability and that we are imposing a liability on them retrospectively by creating an artificial tax year, by destroying the concept of limited liability and by making vendor shareholders liable for the debts of others. Those supporting the legislation go one step further in almost every case and they say: 'They must have known'. In that very quick phrase they introduce the concept of guilt. On that basis they believe that this legislation and the three arbitrary and discriminatory things it does are justified. The most unreasoned supporters of this legislation believe that all those associated with bottom-of-the-harbour schemes are guilty--

TALK.START.PARA: —Crooks.

—Crooks-and therefore are liable. There are many who did not know. By means of this legislation we are able to retrace. We are starting off from the bottom-of-the-harbour and going up through the surface and further until we trace schemes right back to where we can recoup the outstanding moneys. Many people-completely innocent-right away from the cold face of fraud certainly received the benefit and did not know what was going on. The only point of this clause is to give those people an opportunity to say so and to prove that they did not know what happened to the company in which they were involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give two examples. Shareholder A and shareholder B were both approached by promoters. One promoter said to shareholder A: 'I am in a position to take your company off you; I can sell it to a public company that has a loss situation, and through a profit/loss arrangement I can deal with your company. There is nothing illegal or wrong in it'. The person then sold the company. Shareholder B was also approached by a promoter who said the same thing: 'I can buy your company and inject into it a profit/loss arrangement. It is supported by the law. It is supported by Queen's Counsels' opinions. The Government seems to accept decisions of the High Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of South Australia. It is completely above board'. The promoter who dealt with shareholder A did exactly what he said he would do, and shareholder A, under this legislation, has no liability. The promoter who dealt with shareholder B was a liar and a fraudulent evader, and he stripped the company and sent it to the bottom of the harbour. But the person who sold him that company was in the same position as the person who sold to the other promoter who did exactly what he said he would do. I cannot accept that that is fair.

I argued last night that existing law should have been used, and I still think it can and should be used now. It is likely that if existing law is used both for recoupment and criminal and civil charges there will be many guilty vendor shareholders. But they would have the opportunity to put their cases before their peers under our system of law and justice. They will duly find that they were in the wrong. By supporting this amendment we are seeking nothing more than that-to give all vendor shareholders, the guilty and the innocent alike, the opportunity to prove their cases. The onus of proof will be on them; the guilty will still be caught because they will have to prove that they were not guilty, and the innocent will perhaps have a better chance than they have at the moment. Honourable members must remember that there is always the threat of the late penalty which will work against people seeking to frustrate the legislation. I simply cannot abide by the argument that we must ignore the innocent because they will come rushing forward and block up this legislation. I cannot go along with that proposition.

We are debating this matter in the context of hindsight, and for political purposes we are stating that all people are guilty of fraud. Let me turn to no other source than the McCabe-Lafranchi report which, on the question of whether vendors had knowledge of the on-sale of the company by the dealer, at pages 12 and 13, states:

There is no evidence the vendor directors or shareholders or agents knew that the companies were on-sold by the dealer, that the remaining funds in the company were removed by the dealer, that the dealer made no attempt to treat the contingent taxation liability of the companies and that the dealer did not meet prior year tax provisions in respect of funds which had been handed over by the vendors.
That is what the McCabe-Lafranchi report states about these people. We are asking that they be given the opportunity to put their cases and to prove their innocence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to say a couple of things in response to those who have contributed to the debate on this amendment. I do not accept for a moment the charge made by the Opposition that all those who supported this amendment are friends of the tax avoidance industry or of tax evaders. Although, for reasons which I will explain, I do not agree with the reasoning, the argument or the views advanced by my friends and colleagues, including the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) who moved the amendment, and a number of other colleagues who spoke during the debate, I totally accept their right to argue as they have done. I think it does nothing to the sense and dignity of debate in the Parliament for them to be broadly labelled as friends of tax avoiders simply because they have dared to put a different argument on an issue which undoubtedly has attracted a great deal of interest in this House. It is now almost 12 midnight on a Thursday night at the end of a session and the House is substantially full of members who are interested in the debate. Frankly, that is because there has been some good argument. I think it does the institution a great service if occasionally we have a few debates such as this. The only matter that tends to put honourable members off the rails occasionally is language that is either extravagant or a touch irrelevant. Before I answer the arguments that have been put forward I should like to refer to the Concise Oxford Dictionary and quote the meaning of the word 'innocent'. The Concise Oxford Dictionary defines 'innocent' in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Free from moral wrong, sinless and unacquainted with evil.

That, of course implies very strongly that the concept of innocence is related to matters concerning offences, penalties and criminality. The basis of the Government's argument, and the reason I find myself unable to accept the amendment moved by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, is that this legislation relates to recouping unpaid tax. That tax is still legally payable; it is still outstanding. It cannot be recouped from the companies because the companies have been denuded of assets. By this legislation the Government is endeavouring to recoup it from those who have thus far enjoyed the financial benefit of its non-payment. Stripped of all the verbiage and all the emotive expressions, that is what the legislation is about. It is not about whether these people are guilty or innocent. That is why I have persistently reacted against the words 'crooks', 'rogues' and 'knaves' that have been used in this place to describe people who have been involved in these arrangements. Many and varied would have been the moral culpabilities or lack thereof of people who have been involved in these arrangements. It is simply a question of whether the legislation, according to its provisions, applies to their taxation liability. It is essentially on that basis and having listened to the debate throughout this evening and having previously discussed this matter at very great length with a large number of my colleagues the Government finds itself unable to accept this amendment.

We can go on all night. We can come into this place, give some examples of people who have had arguments with the Australian Taxation Office and try to construe from them some kind of punitive, selective and unfair approach by this Government towards the administration of the tax law. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) rejoiced in the fact that in August 1975 instructions were given for a prosecution. I have news for the honourable member for Shortland. From the way in which the system operated I bet that the Treasurer of the day, that is the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), did not even know those instructions had been given. Those prosecutions are handled at a departmental level.

I want to deal with one other issue that was raised seriously by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom); that is the economic consequences of applying this legislation to people who have made no provision for the tax. The Government is doing two things. It is providing for recoupment of the tax but it is also providing people who will be caught by this legislation with the opportunity to pay over a period of 12 months. That is the subject of debate later on. I make it clear that I make no apology for this legislation. I say to my friend the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) that the Bill that is now before the Parliament I support in every particular. I assure him that the only amendments to this Bill that I recommended to the Cabinet were amendments that I was satisfied, after a lengthy discussion with many people in my party and in the National Party who were interested in this legislation, would improve the Bill. I stand by all those amendments. I will defend them anywhere honourable members would like and very effectively. Of course, some of these people will have to dispose of assets in order to meet these liabilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—Perhaps the disposal of some of those assets will involve people being sacked. Does the honourable member say 'good' to that? Of course he does not. Therefore, the suggestion that some time should not be allowed is an absolute nonsense. It is not only under this legislation that that type of situation can happen. In a practical sense-this has something to do with the general argument about retrospectivity; I know, Mr Giles, that you will bring me back to the point if I get too far away from it-one of the arguments used is that there is a practical disturbance which has very significant economic consequences. It is not only legislation of this kind that can have that effect. Court decisions can sometimes have that effect. They can have a retrospective effect. A very well-known case in this country involved the so-called Gorton scheme. The Gorton scheme was an arrangement sanctioned by the High Court of Australia in 1964 in Abel's case. It provided for the avoidance of the payment of death duties. That particular arrangement went on for a period of eight or nine years. The High Court in a subsequent case in 1973 decided it could be done in a different way and issued a whole lot of gift duty assessments going back to the time of the original scheme. That, in practical terms, had precisely the same effect on people who had entered into those arrangements as this legislation will have on people who have entered into the arrangements it covers . With respect, I do not agree therefore with some of the things that have been said tonight about the consequences and the horrendous nature of this legislation, which I stress again is about liability for tax and is not about judgments of guilt or innocence or about whether people have been liable for any kind of criminality.

SPEECH.PARA: In concluding my remarks, let me say again that the Government has listened very carefully to what those of our number who have supported the amendment of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro have said. We find ourselves unable to accept that amendment for the reason that I have outlined. We reject utterly the collective branding of those of my colleagues as supporters of the tax avoidance industry simply because they have exercised their right to argue the point. They have argued it very well in this chamber tonight. But I have to say to them in all candour that I find their arguments unconvincing. The Government cannot accept them. We believe that, given the nature of this legislation, the Bill in this respect should stand and should be supported by the Committee.
Friday, 29 October 1982

That the amendment (Mr Sainsbury's) be agreed to.

''(2A) The promoters taxable amount, or the aggregate of the promoters taxable amounts, as the case may be, that exist by the application of sub-section (1) or (2) in relation to a purchase or purchases of shares under a scheme shall not exceed-

(3) Clause 10, page 42, lines 2 to 12 (inclusive), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
