In moving the amendments that have been circulated in my name I would like, if the Committee would so permit, also to speak to some other amendments. The various changes are ones that the Government has thought fit to propose in the light of views put to it and raised by speakers in the debate yesterday, particularly by members of the Government parties. These amendments essentially arise out of representations to me by the Government members' taxation committee . In each case, the amendments do not change the Bill in fundamental respects, but seek further to ensure that in achieving their essential purpose the recoupment measures do not operate in unfair or inappropriate ways.

The first group of amendments-amendments 1 and 2-is one that concerns the general extent to which the promoters class is to be liable to recoup the evaded company tax that is the subject of this legislation. Under the Bill, this class is generally to have a liability for 20 per cent of the evaded tax-that amount representing, on average, the share of evaded tax that promoters took in fees. It has been put to us that this could operate inappropriately where, in a particular case, the fee charged was at a substantially lower level. This could, for example, happen where the amount of profit stripped from a particular company was large, and the fee was, as a percentage of profits, somewhat lower. To meet this situation the amendments to clause 7 will place a ceiling on the total recoupment tax laibility that attaches to the promoters class for a particular scheme. That ceiling will be the amount of the gross fee charged by the promoter; that is, in the simple case the difference between the net worth of the company at the time of sale-now unpaid tax liabilities aside-and the consideration for the purchase of the shares.

I note the point that this ceiling is expressed in terms of total recoupment tax liability, such as in a case where there were a number of unpaid company assessments for the target company, perhaps involving more than one year of income. Of necessity, given that there was typically no dissection of fee between such different company tax liabilities of a company or, in a case where accumulated profits were also involved, between the amount charged for pre-tax and accumulated profits, the fee limitation expressed in the amendment is in terms of the total fee regardless of how it was calculated or on which profits it might have been based.

The next matter I would like to speak about is a related one and is the subject of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Additional Tax) Bill 1982. As I have just explained, there is to be a promoters' recoupment tax ceiling based on the gross fee charged on the acquisition of the target company. Such a fee would generally have the character of income in the hands of the promoter concerned, and it can be said that collection of both income tax and the recoupment tax would amount to a double imposition. The Government sees the strength of that argument. The board notion behind imposition of the recoupment tax on promoters is that the promoters should never have benefited by the evasion of company tax, and that the recoupment tax will return from them the fees that represent their share of the evaded tax. To put it another way, the promoters fee that was received will, by reason of the promoters recoupment tax, be required to be paid back.

In these circumstances, the Government believes it to be appropriate that the income tax law should be made to apply to promoters' own liability to income tax as though they had never received the amounts that they in fact pay back as recoupment tax. Accordingly, the Government proposes by the amendments to the further Bill to treat as an income tax deduction for a person the amount that he or she pays as promoters recoupment tax, or as a contribution towards the promoters recoupment tax that another member of the particular promoters class has paid. This deduction will be allowable for the year in which the shares in the target company were purchased, but will not be allowed to give rise to a carry-forward loss.

I turn now to amendment 3 to the main Bill, which also relates to the promoters recoupment tax. As the Bill is now framed, the persons in an eligible promoters class have a joint and several liability for the promoters recoupment tax, and a person in the class who is obliged by the Commissioner of Taxation to pay may recover, by action in the courts, an appropriate contribution from other members of the class. While that basic position is not to be disturbed, we have been persuaded that a person who, under the joint and several concept, is sued by the Commissioner ought not to be requested first to pay the tax before he or she seeks contribution from the others. This could be particularly so where the appropriate share of the person sued is a relatively small part of the total Bill.

Accordingly, the amendment will introduce into the Bill a provision under which a person in the promoters class who is sued by the commissioner for the unpaid promoters recoupment tax may act to have other members of the class joined as co -defendants in the recovery suit. Where that option is expected the court will, having regard to levels of participation and benefit enjoyed or to be enjoyed, have power to determine how much of the unpaid amount it is just and equitable that the person sued, and each of the persons joined, should be liable to pay as recoupment tax. I do not think I have leave to deal with the final group of amendments, that is amendments 4 and 5. They relate to major clauses. I will resume my remarks on those amendments later.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments were made available to the Opposition only when the debate commenced tonight. I understand that there were technical reasons for that. In those circumstances the Opposition has not had the proper time to give them consideration. At this stage I can say only that we will not oppose the amendments. As far as I can see, they are not amendments that we would want to oppose. However, we would like to look at them more closely. If we have any alteration to that attitude it will be expressed in another place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments. However, some difficulties still remain. The House should consider a person who was an agent, a financier, an adviser, who was in one way and another between the vendor- shareholder and the person who ultimately did something illegal with the company . Some of those people were in a position of ignorance as to what happened to the company later on. In fact, they are able to evidence that they were ignorant , having gone to some trouble to see that the companies were dealt with legally. Certainly the proposals that have just been introduced ensure that they have a defence. The beneficiaries under trust estates or the purchasers-the people who give financial assistance-can join others with them to have the liability apportioned. That is a very big step towards equity. The difficulty is that they have to take before a court a matter that would normally be a matter of assessment by the Commissioner of Taxation. Normally one would expect the Commissioner of Taxation to decide who owed what.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the difficulty has been that the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax ) Assessment Bill [No. 2] has been drawn around joint and several-the idea of a joint liability. Joint liabilities are difficult matters. A law that imposes a joint liability on a person where the liability is not incurred voluntarily is difficult. Joint liabilities in anyone's life are awkward and people who incur joint liabilities normally take a lot of care to do so with their eyes open. While there is a defence, that defence might take some time, it will be expensive, and some of the people who are involved will be difficult to find. I urge the Government to consider introducing further amendments-I appreciate this will involve serious redrafting-to overcome that joint liability problem in a more complete manner than it is doing with this amendment. It should introduce those amendments when this Bill is before the Senate. This will involve some substantial redrafting, but it will not involve any change in principle. It will just place those people, who are not guilty of any offence but find themselves faced with a situation that will still be hard to control, in a better position. I think that is reasonable and equit- able, and I ask the Government to consider it.

There is one further point that is more substantial in terms of principle but I suspect easier in terms of drafting; that is, that a person who acted, had a business introducing people and financing them, under the terms of this legislation is actually meeting not a 46c in the dollar tax rate but a 100c in the dollar tax rate. All the moneys that he received by way of fee he is being asked to hand over to the Australian Taxation Office. Further, he is in no way able to debit his expenses-the cost of running his office and so on-against those fees that he has received. So, this is more than a tax; it is the expropriation of the money that he has received. Two questions arise. I am advised that collection is doubtful on constitutional grounds-I will not comment further than that because I am not qualified to do so. But more than that, one has to ask the question whether it is reasonable that this person, who is in many ways in the same position as the vendor shareholders were, who received a benefit but was not a party to a stripping arrangement-not willingly anyway- should receive this very high rate of expropriation whereas the vendor shareholders will receive an account for tax payable at 46c in the dollar. This goes beyond recoupment. When the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [ No. 2] comes before the Senate I ask the Government to consider moving a Government amendment to overcome what I see as an inequity in that area also. I appreciate that any amendment that is moved in the Senate without the Government 's support is unlikely to succeed. All my effort will be devoted to encouraging the Government to consider those matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) in making a protest at this sudden submission of a whole number of amendments by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). Quite frankly, this is typical of the way the Government has acted in relation to debate on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2]. I said in the chamber yesterday that if the Government had issued instructions for prosecutions we would not be in the position we are in now. I pointed out, in fact, that no prosecutions have been issued. What did the Treasurer do yesterday? In fact, he misrepresented me. I just read the Hansard of yesterday's debate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: So when the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) comes in here and says: 'Have there been any prosecutions under Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act? Are there going to be any prosecutions under this Bill?', he frankly does not know what he is talking about.
I did not say that at all. I just refer, in fact, to what I did say. I said yesterday that unfortunately it is not enough for legislation to be passed in the Parliament to recoup--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for La Trobe will resume his seat. He is not entitled to resurrect a debate of another day. I ask him when I call him again to stick to the clauses. I call the honourable member for La Trobe. It is not a personal explanation.

—I understand that, but what I am saying relates to these amendments and this Bill. What I was trying to point out yesterday and what I am pointing out again today is that we would not need these complicated amendments if, in fact, instructions had been issued by the Government for prosecutions. I have fortunately had the opportunity to point out that the Treasurer was wrong when he said that I referred to the Income Tax Assessment Act. I was not referring to that Act at all. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) pointed out that in August 1975 the Australian Labor Party Government in fact issued prosecutions. That is something that this Government has not done.

SPEECH.PARA: I just make one small comment about what the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) had to say. It seems to me that the kind of argument that he used is the kind of argument that has been presented to us by Government members all night and, in fact, yesterday also, trying to make out that these agents are innocent. I am afraid that there has been no convincing of this side of the chamber about the innocence of agents, about the innocence of the shareholders.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are mixed up with guilt, not innocence.

—I am talking about agents whom the honourable member referred to. He said that these people were sitting between the shareholders and the promoters and that they knew nothing about what was happening, the illegality of the operations of the promoters. I say to honourable members on the other side of the chamber that these agents were guilty. Of course they were guilty. They understood what they were doing in the same way as the shareholders understood what they were doing when they got a higher value for their shares than they were worth on the market. This Government has been irre- sponsible in not pursuing prosecutions against these sorts of people. I think it is appalling that the Government should come here and submit a long string of amendments and not give the Opposition time to read them and time to comment on them. I support what the honourable member for Gellibrand has said. This matter will be taken up in the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that we are now debating clauses 6 to 20 as well as the Government's amendments. That being so, there are a number of comments that I wish to make on those clauses. First of all, I refer to clause 6(8). This provision relates to trusts. It appears in that clause which deals with secondary liability. This is briefly explained on page 49 of the explanatory memorandum. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Under sub-clause (8) a beneficiary of a trust estate to whom corpus of the trust is in fact paid or applied for his or her benefit after the time of sale of shares in a target company will, for the purpose of tracing the trust's liability to pay recoupment tax . . . be treated as having had a right to a distribution of corpus from that trust.

I appreciate that there are cases where the application of that provision will be perfectly fair. But it seems to me as well that there will be cases where the application of that provision may be manifestly unfair. Let me illustrate this by reference to a hypothetical example of an infant who is a beneficiary under a discretionary trust. I use this example because it is common for those who carry on businesses to have trusts for the purposes of holding assets and to nominate under the trusts-these are almost invariably discretionary trusts-various persons who can receive benefits. Included among those persons who can receive benefits one will almost invariably find members of the family of the persons who control the trust and who really control the profit-making enterprise which is the source of the tax liability which is sold and which gives rise to the liability to vendors' recoupment tax.

This is a hypothetical example, of course as it must be, but let us assume that there is a sale which is caught and that there has been a distribution of $100, 000 to infant children. This, of course, will frequently be a notional distribution only in the sense that the guardian of the children who will be the person who controls the sale of the company and the sale of the trust-once again , almost invariably, the parent-will apply the $100,000 in a number of ways; let us assume in investment. If the investment is lost all that the child has is a debt which is worthless. Yet it appears on the application of clause 6 by reason of sub-clause (8) that the infant will be liable to tax. It has no assets and yet it would have a large liability to recoupment tax. Nor would it appear, on a quick reading of the amendment that has been moved, to clause 10 that the infant would be able to apply successfully under clause 10 for the very good reason that notionally-that is to say, in the eye of the law-the infant has received a distribution. I find it very difficult to see how any child could be made liable in those kinds of circumstances-that is to say, in events which the infant was not able to control and in respect of transactions from which, in fact, the infant received no benefit.

I now move to clause 7. I said in the second reading debate that I hoped the Government would redress some problems. Whilst I have supported the general proposition that promoters, properly defined, should pay their fair share, I find it very difficult to see why promoters, as defined here, can be said to be properly described or properly assessed. The eligible promoters class is to be found in clause 7 (4). A wide number of people are included in that sub-clause who would not on any normal use of the English language be called promoters. Let us take a few of them-purchasers, agents of purchasers, including persons who had power of attorney, brokers who have acted in the transaction, and all shareholders or directors of a purchaser where the purchaser is a company irrespective of whether or not the shareholder is a nominee shareholder only and irrespective of whether or not the director in question acted in respect of the transaction which attracts the tax liability. For example, the director could be overseas. Regardless of the benefit actually received, on the face of things each is caught.

One could have as an example 10 transactions. Let us assume that the figure arrived at under the new formula is a benefit of $100,000 a transaction, which gives a total $1m. Let us assume further that someone acting under a power of attorney in each of those transactions and hence caught received a fee of $1,000 . Let us assume further that that person had not the least idea that what was involved was tax evasion of any kind at all and thought that he was acting properly and simply for the purposes of giving effect to certain perfectly legal arrangements. It would seem, therefore, that that person is, on the face of things, liable in this class liability to an amount of $1m. True it is that he is now able to apply to the court under the amendment which has been put forward by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) for an apportionment amongst others, and true it is that if he succeeds in that application he will have his liability reduced to what is just and equitable, which one assumes will be $1,000, but the cost of that exercise will be very great indeed.

It seems to me that there is a fundamental deficiency in the way in which the question of promoters liability is approached. First of all, one has this class liability and individuals, trusts and companies being caught on a joint and several basis. It seems to me to be quite wrong that anyone should be jointly liable for benefits which other persons have received, irrespective of rights to apply to the court for relief. In the first place, it must be fundamental that it is the duty of the Commissioner of Taxation to issue an assessment which in fact reflects the benefit received. The onus should not be on the taxpayer to exculpate himself at great expense-expense which, to a very large extent, he will not be able to recover because, even if successful on taxation of costs, he would probably get about two-thirds of what it cost him to run the action. If other members of the class are bankrupt, he has nobody from whom he can get his costs. I must confess that that strikes me as fundamentally unjust becuase we are not talking about promoters as a sub-species of slightly inhuman people; we are talking about a whole variety of individuals who are caught by these dragnet provisions. Hence I find the legislation, as presently framed, exceedingly difficult to support because the liability of individuals who are caught within the eligible promoters class is not defined by reference to the benefit received .

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak very briefly in response to the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I say to the honourable member for Moore that I will examine what he has put. I am not in a position to give, and I do not purport to give, any undertakings about further amendments. As he will know, we have already inserted a number of changes in the Bill. I remind him of the original provision in the Bill which provides for any member of a promoters class to seek a declaration from the Federal Court that it is just and equitable for him to be excluded from the class. That is relevant to a number of the matters raised by the honourable member. I also draw his attention to the amendments moved tonight .

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say to him, and also to the honourable member for North Sydney, that the joint and several liability concept is very difficult but the whole concept of making promoters liable under this Bill is also very difficult. It is one of those situations in which the politics and the equity of it are great but the legal drafting is extremely difficult. I have to say, in the interests of proper administration of this legislation, that one has to pay some regard to those practical considerations. It is just infeasible in most cases for the Australian Taxation Office to be sufficiently apprised, at the commencement of an assessment exercise, of the calculations that the honourable member for Moore, and the honourable member for North Sydney, by implication, ask to be done. That is entitled to draw the response-which it has had from both honourable members- that that is all very unfair and that we are dealing with putting liabilities on people. I will give consideration over the coming week to what both honourable gentlemen have said but they will know the situation well enough, and they know me well enough, not to construe that as a firm undertaking. As an ideal it would be much better if what both of them have suggested could be done. Through the original just and equitable provision, and again tonight through the amendments, the Government has endeavoured to strike some kind of rough compromise between the needs of administration and not be unfair to people who might be caught in the manner outlined by both of my colleagues.

One other comment-one other comment only-I make in respect of the speech of the honourable member for North Sydney: My understanding of the way the provisions of the Bill operate is that, in the trust case he cited involving the application of the benefit to the parents' business, there would be a new trust as a result of the investment of that money in the business. The Commissioner of Taxation in those circumstances would seek recovery from the parents and not from the children. The honourable gentleman has raised an important matter which is not just a technical one. The hour is late-for which he is not responsible- but certainly I will also give that very careful consideration. My initial advice is to the effect that I have explained. I will probe the matter further and if there is any further action that ought to be taken in that regard I will consider taking it.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a category of shareholder which could be unintentionally disadvantaged by the application of clause 6. It concerns shareholders in public companies which were also holding companies and which sold subsidiaries that were eventually disposed of fraudulently. Anyone who has ever invested in a public company, by purchasing shares through a stockbroker, will readily understand that he or she is not consulted by company directors before those directors take ordinary commercial decisions of benefit to the company and its shareholders. Advice from the Australian Taxation Office suggests that there may be as many as 63 public companies involved. Even if some of those public companies turn out to be not listed on an Australian stock exchange I think my comments will remain relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill does not expressly deal with the situation of public companies which became vendor companies; nor does it regard shareholders in public companies as being different from shareholders in private companies. Given the way in which the legislation is drafted, the Commissioner of Taxation has an option to require those shareholders in public companies to pay taxes resulting from a transaction about which they could not, in the ordinary course of events, have possibly known. I do not want to go over that argument; it has been done to death. But it is necessary to mention it in the context of a point or two that I want to make later.

In the explanatory memorandum reference is made to three triggers for tracing those to be assessed from the primary level to the next level and, if necessary, successively to further levels. The memorandum also indicates that the company or trustee to which liability will be allocated or traced will depend on whether any one of the public companies concerned 'now has different shareholders or beneficiaries as a consequence of sales of shares or beneficial interests'. That is provided for in clause 6 (2) However, the provisions of the Bill do not seem to apply as automatically as that provision would indicate. It is elsewhere stated in clause 6 (2) that, as a condition for the operation of these provisions, 'some or all of the shares in the relevant company were sold'. On top of that is superimposed a condition which stipulates that the operation of clause 6 provisions in certain circumstances is dependent on an opinion to be formed by the Commissioner. In other words, depending on the whim or judgment of the Commissioner some shareholders who may have derived no benefit from the sale of companies disposed of fraudulently may assume a liability for the new tax. That is the nub of the problem as I see it.

Unless the Bill is suitably amended liability for the new tax may very well be imposed on shareholders who purchased shares in the public holding company after the so-called offending or relevant sales of subsidiaries took place. By that I mean that unless the Bill is suitably amended, the Commissioner may very well be placed in a no-win situation. If he forms an opinion that the company should be assessed he runs the risk of imposing a penalty on shareholders who were not shareholders at the time of the relevant transaction or transactions and therefore shareholders who have enjoyed no benefits. Furthermore, where the Commissioner decides that a holding company must pay, individual shareholders at the time of the relevant transactions whose benefit would not attract a tax liability in excess of $100 and would otherwise be exempt from the new tax would in fact be indirectly taxed at company level, as would the estates of deceased persons which also would have been otherwise exempt. In this last respect-the Commonwealth could be gathering from companies taxes which it has expressly stated would not be collectable from individuals.

Where shareholders have purchased shares in public or even private companies since the relevant qualifying transactions took place and where the Commissioner decides the company is to be assessed and not individual shareholders, there will be further penalty of a commercial nature in that the value of the shareholders' investment is to be diminished. The creation of a new and unexpected tax liability payable by companies in these circumstances will naturally decrease the value of that company's shares. Furthermore the value of shareholders' investments will also be reduced by the need for the companies so assessed to finance that debt to Commonwealth revenues by borrowing, rationalising its operations, liquidating its assets or other means as may be necessary to pay the new tax.

People who have purchased and still hold shares in holding companies after previous shareholders derived benefit from tax minimisation schemes now being legislated against may be called upon to pay, directly or indirectly, taxes arising out of the benefits enjoyed by other earlier shareholders. On top of that they will be penalised by what could be a significant drop in the value of shares they still hold even though they did not derive any earlier benefit.

To overcome inequities which will inevitably accrue if the Commissioner decides , at his sole discretion, that a company shall be assessable rather than individual shareholders whose holdings were in place at the time the relevant transactions were concluded it should be mandatory that the company should first request the Commissioner to give effect to the other provisions of clause 6 (2). It is a choice of two courses and the company should nominate. If by suitable amendment a company becomes responsible for nominating one of only two courses of action not only will the Commissioner be relieved from making a no-win decision but also the company will then be required to discharge its duties as set out in section 229 (2) of the new company code, which provides:
An officer of corporation shall at all times exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence in the exercise of his powers and the discharge of his duties .

Given that obligation on a company and its directors, they will then have the duty of deciding whether that company should be assessed as a legal entity or whether it would be more equitable for the relevant shareholders to be assessed individually. Subject to any advice that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) may receive on the subject, there need be no difficulty in that. It would overcome the possibility of people who derive no benefit at all becoming liable for the new tax. I urge the Government to consider an appropriate amendment to remove the discretion in this area from the Commissioner of Taxation and to require the company or companies concerned to make that decision or nomination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be in extraordinarily rare cases, as I envisage it and as I understand the likely operation of this provision, that the Commissioner of Taxation would do otherwise than to exercise his discretion in favour of the situation that the shareholders at the time the transaction was put in place would be the people who were looked to for recoupment. I cannot envisage a case involving a public company where that would not occur. There could be other cases. I will take on board what the honourable gentleman has said. In the same context as the comments I made to his colleague, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), I will give further consideration to the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 21 (Instalment arrangements in relation to late payment of company tax).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition view on this clause is that it should be deleted from the Bill. It provides that persons liable for tax under this Bill will be able to pay the tax owing over a period of 12 months or such longer period than 12 months as the Commissioner of Taxation allows, provided they do not object to the assessment and they make a down payment of about 25 per cent. This provision was not in the original Bill which came before the House a month before these revised Bills were brought in. The original Bill provided 30 days for such people to pay after they received their assessments and, if they had not paid within 30 days, penalty tax was to apply at the rate of 20 per cent per annum, which was a substantial incentive to pay quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition opposes this provision to pay in instalments over a 12 month or longer period because we simply do not accept the argument that the new provision is required to ensure that hardship is not created by the need to pay recoupment tax. Clause 21 is a blanket provision. A taxpayer does not have to show hardship to get a year or more in which to pay; so people who have had the use of these stolen funds, to use the term the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser ), interest free for several years are to be given a further year in which to repay them. What an incredible situation that is; they do not have to prove any hardship to get that repayment period of 12 months or more. That situation should be compared with the position of an ordinary, honest, pay-as-you-earn taxpayer who has paid his taxes all year but who has a small amount of tax to pay at the end of the year because not enough was taken out of his pay. He is given 30 days in which to pay after he receives his assessment. If he does not pay in that time he is liable for penalty tax. He or she does not get a year in which to pay, but 30 days. They can get a month's extension if they can prove genuine hardship. If they want an extension of longer than a month, they have to provide the Australian Taxation Office with a full statement of assets and liabilities so that there is no doubt about the capacity to pay or about there being genuine hardship.

That is the situation that applies to the great majority of taxpayers in this country, but by this Bill people who have stolen funds from public revenue, who are tax evaders and who have had the use of that money for several years, will have another year in which to pay. Why do we discriminate in favour of tax evaders? That is what this Bill is doing. It is introducing discrimination in favour of tax evaders who have already had the use of the money for several years. It seems incredible to us that the Government says that thieves should be given more lenient treatment than honest taxpayers. If this instalment provision is eliminated, as we want to do by opposing this clause of the Bill, tax dodgers would be treated in the same way as honest taxpayers. If there was genuine hardship so that they could not pay in 30 days, the Commissioner could extend the period to pay without any penalty tax applying.

We appreciate that there may be situations in which there is no capacity to pay the money and in which genuine hardship arises. In that situation the same provisions that apply to honest taxpayers should apply to them. We do not need this blanket instalment provision in clause 21 to provide for the genuine hardship situation. That is the reality in this Bill. Clause 13 of the Bill provides that the situation that applies to normal taxpayers will apply in the situation of recoupment tax liability. We simply do not need this instalment tax provision to cover the situation of genuine hardship.

I also draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that the Government has budgeted on obtaining $255m of revenue this year from recoupment tax. There is clearly no possibility of achieving anything like that amount of money if this clause is in the legislation as finally passed by this Parliament. This instalment scheme will ensure that much less will be obtained this financial year than would have been obtained under the original Bill. The original Bill gave 30 days to pay on which the Government made its Budget assessment of $255m being collected this year in recoupment tax. Now we are going to give these people a year in which to pay. We will simply not be able to get anything like that amount of money back into the revenue this year.

The Treasurer (Mr Howard) said that he supported the Bill in every particular. I can understand that he supports this weakening of the Bill along with other weakening provisions of the Bill which have been debated here tonight. Given his record in this area, one would expect him to go along with the various weakening provisions. It took him 2 1/2 years from the time that he first knew about this bottom-of-the-harbour scheme to get around to doing anything about knocking it off. It took him another 1 1/2 years before he sought to get any of the money back. With that record of laxity, it is not surprising that he supports the various provisions which have been brought into this revised legislation and which weaken the original legislation substantially. Of course, that original legislation was weak in that it did not seek to get back a lot of the money that was ripped off under this tax avoidance scheme.

I also draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that yesterday the Treasurer tabled the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation. That annual report gives the lie to what the Treasurer said in this chamber as recently as last night about his having knocked off the tax avoidance industry-that because of his diligence there is no tax avoidance problem in this country. That is simply not the situation. The Commissioner of Taxation's annual report, tabled less than 24 hours ago, shows that the number of unidentified tax avoiders has risen by 65 per cent over the last two years while revenue losses have doubled. The number of participants in tax avoidance schemes identified in the year ended 30 June was 28,366 and the revenue losses amounted to $1,458m. This compares with 22,366 participants and $973m lost in revenue identified in the previous year, increases of 27 per cent in the number of participants and 50 per cent in the amount of money involved. They are the figures for the last year. The number of identified tax avoiders is now 33 times higher than it was in the last year of the Labor Government.

That is the kind of record that this Government has in respect of tax avoidance . It is a deplorable record, a record which has allowed a massive tax avoidance explosion to occur in this country. It finally ended up with a scheme which was the greatest rip-off of all and which the Government took two and a half years to do anything about. It took another one and a half years to do anything about getting back the money, and when it finally brought legislation before the House of Representatives it weakened that legislation considerably. We are now debating the one final provision of this Bill which ensures that instead of discriminating against people who are tax avoiders and law breakers, this Government is discriminating in their favour by providing for them much more favourable treatment than honest taxpayers received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Treasurer) (1.11 a.m.)-The Government supports this clause for a very simple reason. Given all the circumstances and given the fact that provision would not otherwise have been made, I do not believe and the Government does not believe that it is unreasonable to make this provision. I was interested that the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) said that it might well provide an incentive for earlier payment. I do not know. It may well have that effect. The arguments for and against this proposition have been fairly heavily traversed over the last few days. I will not join issue in detail with the honourable member's comments interpreting the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation. I have a suspicion that everybody wants to go home. I think the honourable member's remarks are wrong but I think we can get a unity ticket--
—They are dead right.

—I do not believe they are. I have put out a statement tonight indicating where they are wrong and where I reject them. I think we ought to vote on the clause. I seek leave to move two amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 21, page 58, line 33, omit ''sub-section 9(7)'', substitute ''sub- sections 9(6) and (7)''.
(5) Clause 21, page 59, lines 1 to 10 (inclusive), omit paragraph (1)(h).

The amendments are of an essentially technical kind. They are designed to carry fully into effect the policy of this clause, that is, the clause under which former owners may make arrangements to pay without dispute over a period of 12 months or so. I believe that the amendments proposed give effect to that. In framing this clause, one of the basic objects was to ensure that such desirable payments by former owners did not release promoters from their share of the recoupment tax liability. As a technical part of the measures to achieve that aim, there is a provision under which the Commissioner of Taxation is not to assess the promoters' recoupment tax before all payments by former owners under the arrangement have been made. To remedy any unintended effect of delaying the receipt from the eligible promoters class of an amount that, when received, would operate to reduce the former owners' liability, the provision calling for the promoters' assessment to be deferred is proposed to be omitted and additional provisions are proposed to be inserted in paragraph (f) of sub-clause (21)(1) to achieve the basic object I have spoken about.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons I have given for opposing the clause, we oppose the amendments as well.

(c) in a case to which paragraph (a) applies-the amount paid by the taxpayer reduced by any amount or amounts received by the taxpayer by way of contribution in respect of promoters recoupment tax payable on that promoters taxable amount; or
(d) in a case to which paragraph (b) applies-the amount paid by the taxpayer.

'(2) For the purposes of paragraph (1) (c), an amount shall be deemed to have been received by the taxpayer by way of contribution although it is not actually paid over to the taxpayer, but is re-invested, accumulated, capitalized, carried to any reserve, sinking fund or insurance fund, however designated, or otherwise dealt with on behalf of the taxpayer or as the taxpayer directs.

'(3) Where, at any time after the making of an assessment in relation to a taxpayer, the taxpayer considers that the Commissioner ought to amend the assessment to allow a deduction under this section, the taxpayer may post to or lodge with the Commissioner a request in writing for an amendment of the assessment to allow the deduction.
'(4) The Commissioner shall consider the request and shall serve on the taxpayer, by post or otherwise, a written notice of his decision on the request.

'(5) If the taxpayer is dissatisfied with the Commissioner's decision on the request, the taxpayer may, within 60 days after service on the taxpayer of notice of the decision of the Commissioner, post to or lodge with the Commissioner an objection in writing against the decision stating fully and in detail the grounds on which the taxpayer relies.

'(6) The provisions of Division 2 of Part V (other than section 185) apply in relation to an objection made under sub-section (5) in like manner as those provisions apply in relation to an objection against an assessment.

'(7) For the purposes of this section, expressions that are used in this section to which particular meanings are assigned by section 3 of the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982 have the respective meanings that are so assigned to them.'.
Limitation on certain deductions
''2D. Section 79C of the Principal Act is amended by inserting ', 78B' after ' 78'.''.
(3) After clause 3, page 2, insert the following new clause:
Amendment of assessments
''3A. Section 170 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from sub-section (10) 'or 78A' and substituting ', 78A or 78B'.''.

When speaking to the Government's amendments to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax ) Assessment Bill [No. 2], I indicated the main purpose of the amendments proposed to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Additional Tax) Bill. In short, the amendments will avoid double liability by authorising an income tax deduction for payments of promoters' recoupment tax that the taxpayer concerned has made. The more technical aspects of the amendments will mean that this deduction cannot give rise to carry forward losses. Again, a person who claims entitlement to the deduction but whose income tax assessment for the year was made some time ago will be able to have the assessment amended and to exercise the usual rights of objection and appeal should the Commissioner of Taxation decline the grant of deduction. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Acting Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the two part time members of the National Companies and Securities Commission have each had a direct interest in the subject matter of a public inquiry announced by the NCSC into possible breaches of the takeovers or securities industry legislation.

(2) In particular, is Mr John Nosworthy, a part time NCSC Commissioner, a director of McDonnell and East Limited which was one of the companies involved in the second of the public inquiries announced by NCSC.

(3) Further, is Mr John Uhrig, a part time NCSC Commissioner, the Managing Director of Simpson Holdings Limited which company was involved in the trading in shares of Cowells Limited which is the subject of the third public inquiry announced by the NCSC.

(4) Is it a fact that before taking office the three fulltime Commissioners of the NCSC resigned all company directorships and divested themselves of all company shares held by them; if so, pursuant to what requirement or direction did such resignations and divestments take place; if not, what directorships and /or shares are held by each fulltime Commissioner.
(5) Why is there no statutory requirement that fulltime Commissioners of the NCSC resign all directorships and divest themselves of all interests in company securities upon taking office.
(6) Will the Attorney-General recommend to the ministerial Council that such a requirement be inserted in the National Companies and Securities Commission Act.
(7) What was the reason for appointing part time Commissioners to the NCSC.

(8) In view of the need to avoid any actual or apparent conflict of interest on the part of any NCSC Commissioner in relation to any of the functions or activities of the NCSC, what action will the Attorney-General take to ensure that all NCSC Commissioners are subject to the requirement of resignation and divestment referred to in part (5).
(9) If it is impracticable for part time Commissioners to meet such a requirement, will the Attorney-General ensure that all NCSC Commissioners are in future appointed on a full time basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) has provided the following information which is relevant to items (1) to (4) of the honourable member's question:

'Mr J. R. Nosworthy and Mr J. A. Uhrig are part time members of the NCSC. Mr Nosworthy is a director of a number of companies, including McDonnell and East Ltd and its subsidiaries. Mr Uhrig is also a director of a number of companies, including Simpson Holdings Ltd and its subsidiaries. These appointments have been properly declared, in accordance with section 19 of the NCSC Act 1979, and neither member has participated in the Commission's deliberations concerning the affairs of the companies in which he is a director.

There is no statutory requirement that full time members of the NCSC should resign their company directorships or liquidate their holdings of company shares . Nevertheless, Mr L. Masel, Chairman of the NCSC and Mr J. A. Coleman, Deputy Chairman, resigned all company directorships on taking up their appointments to the NCSC. The other full time member, Mr A. B. Greenwood, did not have any company directorships. None of the 3 full time members holds any company shares.

In addition to the requirement of section 19 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act for a member of the NCSC to disclose on a public register any directorships or other pecuniary interests, the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities has:

(a) Directed the members of the NCSC to disclose to the Commission by declaration any direct or indirect known interest that may be seen to influence their consideration of any matter, when the member is first aware that the interest relates to a matter that is to be considered, and that this declaration need not be recorded on any publicly accessible register;
(b) directed the Commission to give written notice of any direct or indirect known interest to the ministerial council, such details to remain confidential to the ministerial council;

(c) informed the Commission that, subject to the approval of the Commission, members may continue to participate in the consideration of any matter in which they have declared a direct or indirect known interest.

The members and the Commission have complied with the above directions. The action taken by the Ministerial council is consistent with the recommendations of the report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest.'
I shall raise with the Ministerial council for companies and securities items ( 5) to (9) of the honourable member's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has any evidence that the United States State Department opposed the use of chemicals for defoliation and crop destruction purposes in Vietnam at any time between 1960 and 1972 been brought to his attention; if so, what are the details and sources of that evidence.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to any official protests made by United States diplomatic personnel on this matter between 1960 and 1972; if so, what are the details.

(3) On what occasions was this matter raised in the Australian Parliament and on how many occasions was the matter of Australia's specific responsibilities under the 1925 Geneva Protocol for the Prohibition of the Use of War of Asphyxiating, Poisonous or Other Gases, and of Bacteriological Methods of Warfare, referred to by Members of this Parliament between 1960 and 1972.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I understand that the attitudes attributed to the US State Department and members of the US Foreign Service are discussed in detail in a book entitled Operation Ranch Hand: The Air Force and Herbicides in Southeast Asia 1961-1971, published in August 1982. The book, written by Major William A. Buckingham, Jr. for the United States Air Force Office of Air Force History, is one of a series covering the US Air Force's involvement in the Vietnam war. A copy has been placed in the Parliamentary Library.
(3) Questions about the use of herbicides in Vietnam were raised in the Australian Parliament on the following occasions during the period 1960-1972:
31 August 1967, question without notice from Mr Kevin Cairns to the Minister for External Affairs, House of Representatives Hansard, volume 56, page 658;
15 October 1968, question without notice from Senator Cohen to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senate Hansard, volume 38, page 1237;
19 November 1968, answer provided by the Prime Minister to question on notice no. 641 from Senator Cohen, Senate Hansard, volume 39, page 2061;
14 May 1969, answer provided by the Minister for Defence to question on notice no. 1166 from Senator Keeffe, Senate Hansard, volume 41, page 1210;
7 April 1970, question without notice from Senator Cavanagh to the Minister representing the Minister for External Affairs, Senate Hansard, volume 43, page 535;
16 June 1970, answer provided by the Minister for External Affairs to question on notice no. 228 from Senator Cavanagh, Senate Hansard, volume 44, pages 2448-9 ;
17 February 1971, answer by the Minister for Defence to question on notice no. 2051 from Dr Cass, House of Representatives Hansard, volume 71, pages 215-6.

I am informed that the 1925 Geneva Protocol for the Prohibition of the Use in War of Asphyxiating, Poisonous or Other Gases, and of Bacteriological Methods of Warfare was referred to in Parliament on twenty occasions during the period 1960 -1972.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to growing concern within the academic world and the community as a whole at the Government's proposal to amalgamate certain tertiary education institutions.

(2) Has the Government taken into account the possible loss of employment not only among the teaching staff but also among the support staff such as ground and maintenance employees if this proposal is implemented.
(3) What does the Government expect to achieve by the amalgamations.
(4) Has the Government calculated any saving in the cost of running these institutions against the added cost of social welfare benefits that would have to be paid to employees who may be retrenched.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I take the honourable member's question to refer to the Government's decision of 30 April 1981 that 30 CAEs for which teacher education is the main activity should be consolidated by their incorporation into multi-purpose or multi-campus colleges with a single governing body or by integration with neighbouring universities. A total of 26 of these 30 CAEs have successfully achieved consolidation.

I am aware that some amalgamation proposals have been opposed by some members of the community and academic staff. However, most of the amalgamations have received the support of State Governments, members of the community and members of staff.

(2) It is not clear to which specific amalgamation proposal this question refers. Amalgamation itself is not likely to result in significant loss of employment. Not only do the larger institutions created as a result of amalgamation have more flexibility than small institutions in managing staffing difficulties, but also a number of the legislative arrangements made for amalgamation ensure the continued employment of staff at conditions which are no less favourable than their present conditions.

(3) The Government's policy is based on advice from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission which considered that amalgamated institutions would have greater flexibility in the management of resources, especially in the situation of change or decline in workload; would be able to offer students a greater range and improved quality of educational choices; and would result in longer term economies of scale.

(4) The question of added social welfare costs as a result of amalgamation does not arise. Some redundancies may occur in tertiary education institutions as a result of declining enrolments in teacher education programs but amalgamation will create larger institutions which have more staffing flexibility and are able to provide a wider range of opportunities to staff. The likelihood of redundancies occurring is therefore reduced as a result of amalgamation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Navy Submarines: Sub-Harpoon Missile

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report on page 29 of the Journal Defence of January-February 1982 that McDonnell Douglas has sold the Sub-Harpoon missile to the RAN.

(2) If so, (a) when was the decision to place a contract for the Sub-Harpoon (i ) made and (ii) announced, (b) when was the contract with McDonnell Douglas signed, (c) what is the value of the contract, (d) at what date is it expected that the system will become operational in RAN submarines, and (e) what offset arrangements have been made in the contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No Harpoon missiles are being purchased specifically for the RAN submarines . Missiles have been purchased for a common RAN/RAAF pool for use by all platforms capable of firing the Harpoon. These missiles were ordered through the US Foreign Military Sales (FMS) arrangements in 1976.

On 23 August 1979 my predecessor announced that RAN submarines would be provided with the facility to launch Harpoon missiles while submerged. On 19 February 1980 the Prime Minister included comment that the Oberon submarines would be fitted with Harpoon in a major statement on defence.
In June 1981 the necessary encapsulation kits where ordered from the US Government, again through FMS arrangements. The timing was arranged to coincide with a major US order.
The information requested on costs cannot be made available because of the security classification that details of numbers, deduced from overall costs, attract.

The modification of the RAN Oberon submarines for launching of Harpoon missiles will take place over a period of several years. However, the encapulated Harpoon operational capability will be finally proven by test firings scheduled for 1985 .

An offset agreement with McDonnell Douglas was signed in 1979 which requires the company to place offset work to 25 per cent the value of the contracts placed on the company between October 1979 and December 1990 for Harpoon missiles or associated equipment for Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How widespread in Australia is the practice of injecting sheep and cattle with hormones to promote body development leading to increased meat production.
(2) Are there any regulations relating to this practice; if so, what are they; if not, are any proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The only hormonal-type substance currently approved for growth promotion in Australia is a synthetic chemical, zeranol.
I understand that zeranol has been used quite widely in steers, the only category of cattle for which it has been approved.

A true hormone, testosterone has been widely used in wether sheep for disease control purposes in Australia. Some growth promotion may be obtained as a fringe benefit in this case but it is not intended that the drug should be used primarily as a growth promotant.

(2) Each State has a Stock Medicines Act (or some equivalent Act) which makes it an offence to sell any stock medicine or veterinary drug unless it is registered. The Commonwealth plays a co-ordinating role in the registration process. In this way we ensure that livestock producers have access only to approved products carrying approved labels.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How widespread in Australia is the practice of administering antibiotics to battery hens.
(2) Are there any regulations relating to this practice; if so, what are they; if not, are any proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Only one feed additive antibiotic, flavophospholipol, has been approved in Australia for use in the feed of laying hens to improve egg production. However, I am unable to say how widely it is used.
It may be necessary to administer other antibiotics to laying hens for disease control purposes but this should be done only on a short term basis and should only be under veterinary direction.

(2) Each State has a Stock Medicines Act (or equivalent legislation) which requires that antibiotics be registered before they can be marketed. Antibiotics must be shown to be safe and effective, and the label must be approved prior to registration. The Commonwealth plays a co-ordinating role in the registration process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he examined reports that the Jewish dissident Anatoly Shcharansky is dying in a Soviet labour camp from the hunger strike he started on 23 September 1982.
(2) If so, what steps has he taken to give assistance to Anatoly Shcharansky.
(3) Will he renew the Government's earlier appeal to the Soviet authorities to release gaoled dissidents and to implement the 1977 Helsinki accords.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The mother of Anatoly Shcharansky announced on 27 September in Moscow that her son, a prominent Soviet dissident, had commenced a hunger strike in prison in protest at the denial of his right to correspond with his family. The Government is gravely concerned at this further example of Soviet maltreatment of Mr Shcharansky and at the possible consequences of the hunger strike.

I know many Australians share this concern at the way in which Mr Shcharansky has been treated by the Soviet authorities. It was because of this that I met his wife, Mrs Avital Shcharansky, during my visit to Israel earlier this year. At that meeting I agreed to look at ways in which the Australian Government might help her husband.

Since then the Government has made a formal approach to the Soviet authorities on behalf of Mr Shcharansky. In making representations we expressed the Australian Government's concern about abuses of human rights in the Soviet Union and our particular interest in Mr Shcharansky's case. We asked that the Soviet authorities release him as soon as possible and allow him to be reunited with his wife in Israel.
I believe that our representations will add weight to widespread expressions of international concern for Mr Shcharansky's welfare.
